PREFACE 
    The Florence Municipal Code, originally published by Book Publishing Company in 1976, has been kept current by regular supplementation by Matthew Bender & Company, Inc., its successor in interest. 
    During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and indexed by the editorial staff of Book Publishing Company under the direction of William G. Cox, borough manager. 
    Beginning with Supplement 12, 1-09, Municipal Code Corporation will be keeping this Code current by regular supplementation. 
    The code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number designates, in sequence, the numbers of the title, chapter, and section. Thus, Section 2.12.040 is Section .040, located in Chapter 2.12 of Title 2. In most instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions. Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion. 
    In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table, following the text of the code, listing by number all ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification; and beginning with Supplement No. 12, 1-09, legislation can be tracked using the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
    A subject-matter index, with complete cross-referencing, locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers. 
    This supplement brings the Code up to date through Ordinance 02-04-2019A, passed March 4, 2019. 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
800-262-2633 
HOW TO USE YOUR CODE 
    This Code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials, city employees and private citizens. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this Code. 
Numbering System. 
    The numbering system is the backbone of a Code of Ordinances; Municipal Code Corporation uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this Code. It is based on three tiers, beginning with title, then chapter, and ending with section. Each part is represented in the code section number. For example, Section 2.04.010 is Section .010, in Chapter 2.04 of Title 2. 
Title. 
    A title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled. This Code contains about 15 to 20 titles. For example, the first title is Title 1, General Provisions, which may contain ordinances about the general penalty, code adoption and definitions. The titles in this Code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference. Some titles are Reserved for later use. 
Chapter. 
    Chapters deal with more specific subjects, and are often derived from one ordinance. All of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title. The chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material. For example, Chapter 2.06, City Manager, can be added between 2.04, City Council, and Chapter 2.08, City Attorney. 
Section. 
    Each section of the code contains substantive ordinance material. The sections are numbered by "tens" to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering. 
Tables of Contents. 
    There are many tables of contents in this Code to assist in locating specific information. At the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title. In addition, each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters and sections, respectively. 
Ordinance History Note. 
    At the end of each code section, you will find an "ordinance history note," which lists the underlying ordinances for that section. The ordinances are listed by number, section (if applicable) and year. (Example: (Ord. 272 § 1, 1992).) 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 12, 1-09, a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections. Ordinance history notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end. These history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index. 
Statutory References. 
    The statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality. As the statutes are revised, these references will be updated. 
Cross-Reference Table. 
    When a code is based on an earlier codification, the cross-reference table will help users find older or "prior" code references in the new code. The cross-reference table is located near the end of the code, under the tabbed divider "Tables." This table lists the prior code section in the column labeled "Prior Code Section" and the new code section in the column labeled "Herein." 
    As of Supplement No. 12, 1-09, this table will no longer be updated. 
Ordinance List and Disposition Table. 
    To find a specific ordinance in the code, turn to the section called "Tables" for the Ordinance List and Disposition Table. This very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code. The table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance. If the ordinance is codified, the chapter (or chapters) will be indicated. (Example: (2.04, 6.12, 9.04).) If the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified, such as budgets, taxes, annexations or rezones, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." If the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code, usually at the direction of the municipality, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." Other dispositions sometimes used are "(Tabled)," "(Pending)," "(Number Not Used)" or "(Missing)." 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 12, 1-09, this table will be replaced with the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 12, 1-09, a Code Comparative Table and Disposition List has been added for use in tracking legislative history. Located in the back of this volume, this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification. The Code Comparative Table and Disposition List specifies the ordinance number, adoption date, description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance. By use of the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List, the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
Index. 
    If you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code, start with the index. This is an alphabetical multi-tier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference, and cross-references where necessary. Look for the main heading of the subject you need, then the appropriate subheadings: 
BUSINESS LICENSE 
See also BUSINESS TAX 
Fee 5.04.030 
Required when 5.04.010 
    The index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended. 
Instruction Sheet. 
    Each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an Instruction Sheet. The Instruction Sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement. It will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted. Following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current. Removed pages should be kept for future reference. 
Page Numbers. 
    When originally published, the pages of this Code were consecutively numbered. As of Supplement No. 12, 1-09, when new pages are inserted with amendments, the pages will follow a "Point Numbering System". (Example: 32, 32.1, 32.2, 32.2.1, 32.2.2., 33). Backs of pages that are blank (in codes that are printed double-sided) will be left unnumbered but the number will be "reserved" for later use. 
Electronic Submission. 
    In the interests of accuracy and speed, we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible. We can accept most any file format, including Word, WordPerfect or text files. If you have a choice, we prefer Word, any version. You can send files to us as an e-mail attachment, by FTP, on a diskette or CD-ROM. Electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is error-free. Our e-mail address is: ords@municode.com . 
For hard copy, send one copy of all ordinances passed to: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
P.O. Box 2235 
Tallahassee, FL 32316 
Customer Service. 
    If you have any questions about this Code or our services, please contact Municipal Code Corporation at 1-800-262-2633 or:

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapter 1.01 - CODE ADOPTION* 

1.01.010 - Code adopted-Purpose. 
    The code of the City of Florence as promulgated by the City of Florence, Colorado, is adopted and enacted by reference. The purpose of this code is to codify the ordinances of the City which are of a general and permanent nature. The subject matter of this code includes provisions concerning the application and interpretation of the code, the administration and organization of the City animals, buildings, abandoned automobiles, peddlers, finances, streets, nuisances, traffic, offenses, civil defense, elections, and zoning. 
(Ord. 15-80 § 1, 1980). 
1.01.020 - Primary and secondary codes and building standards adopted by reference. 
    The following primary and secondary codes and building standards are adopted by reference as if the same were set forth in full in this code: 
A.  The Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities, revised 1995 Edition, published by the Colorado Department of Transportation, save and except for such amendments as are set forth at Chapter 10.04. 
B.  The International Building Code, 2006 Edition, promulgated by the International Code Council, save and except for such amendments as are set forth at Section 15.08.010. 
C.  The International Residential Code, 2006 Edition, promulgated by the International Code Council, save and except for such amendments as are set forth at Section 15.08.020. 
D.  The International Mechanical Code 2006 Edition, promulgated by the International Code Council, save and except for such amendments as are set forth at Section 15.08.030. 
E.  The International Energy Code, 2006 Edition, promulgated by the International Code Council, save and except for such amendments as are set forth at Section 15.08.040. 
F.  The International Existing Building Code, 2006 Edition, promulgated by the International Code Council, save and except for such amendments as are set forth at Section 15.08.050. 
G.  Flood Damage Prevention Resolution 5-2007, as the official flood plain development resolution of the City of Florence. 
H.  Flood Insurance Rate Maps dated September 19, 2007, published by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
I.  "The Standard Construction Specifications and Standard Details for the City of Pueblo, Colorado," Revised March 28, 2005 Edition, also known as the Florence Street Standards, save and except for such amendments as are set forth at Section 15.08.060. 
(Ord. 16-2008 § 1, 2008). 
1.01.030 - Title-Citation-Reference. 
    This code shall be known as the Florence Municipal Code and it shall be sufficient to refer to such code in any prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding at law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to, amending, correcting or repealing all or any portion thereof as an addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the Florence Municipal Code. Further reference may be had to the title, chapters, sections, and subsections of the Florence Municipal Code and such references shall apply to that numbered title, chapter, section, or subsection as it appears in the code. 
(Ord. 15-80 § 3, 1980). 
1.01.040 - Ordinances passed prior to adoption of code-Repeal of certain ordinances. 
A.  The last ordinance included in the initial Florence Municipal Code is Ordinance No. 4-79. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to Ordinance No. 4-79, but prior to adoption of this code, are adopted and made a part of this code: Ordinances No. 5-79 through 18-79; Ordinances No. 1089 through 14-80. 
B.  All ordinances and parts of ordinances of a primary and general nature passed prior to September 15, 1980, and in effect at the time the Florence Municipal Code is adopted, but not included in said code, are repealed. Ordinances passed on or after September 15, 1980, shall not be repealed or amended by the adoption of the Florence Municipal Code and the ordinance codified in this chapter and Chapter 1.12. 
(Ord. 15-80 § 4, 1980). 
1.01.050 - Matters not affected by repeal. 
    The repeal of ordinances and pats of ordinances by the ordinance codified in this chapter and Chapter 1.12 shall not affect any offense committed or act done, any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract, right or obligation established prior to the time when said ordinances and parts of ordinances are repealed. 
(Ord. 15-80 § 5, 1980). 
1.01.060 - Ordinances saved from repeal. 
    The repeal of ordinances of a general and permanent nature by the ordinance codified in this chapter and Chapter 1.12 shall not repeal any ordinance or part thereof saved from repeal specifically by the Florence Municipal Code, nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance: 
A.  Promising, guaranteeing or authorizing the payment of money by or for the City; 
B.  Authorizing or relating to specific issuances of bonds or other evidences of indebtedness; 
C.  Granting a franchise; 
D.  Establishing the compensation of City officers or employees; 
E.  Levying taxes, making appropriations or adopting a budget; 
F.  Creating specific local improvement districts; 
G.  Making special assessments for local improvements; 
H.  Vacating, accepting, establishing, locating, relocating or opening any street or public way; 
I.  Affecting the corporate limits of the City; 
J.  Which is of a special or temporary nature; 
K.  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision. 
(Ord. 15-80 § 6, 1980). 
1.01.070 - Severability of code provisions. 
    If any sections, section, subsection or provision of this code of ordinances, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by any competent court, such invalidity shall not affect the other sections, subsections, provisions or applications of this code if they can be given effect without the invalid sections, section, subsection, provision or application. 
(Ord. 15-80 § 8, 1980). 
1.01.080 - Codes kept on file. 
A.  At least three (3) copies of the Florence Municipal Code, and of each secondary code adopted in Section 1.01.020, all certified by the Mayor and the City Clerk to be true copies of such codes as they were adopted by this ordinance, shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk available for public inspection. One copy of each such code may be kept in the office of the chief enforcement officer thereof rather than in the office of the Clerk. 
B.  The City Clerk shall prepare and publish revised sheets of every looseleaf page in need of revision by reason of amendment, addition or repeal. The City Clerk shall distribute said revised looseleaf sheets for such fee as the City Council may direct. 
C.  In addition to those copies of this code specified in subsection A of this section, a copy of this code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk in which it shall be the express duty of the City Clerk to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which are intended to become a part of the Florence Municipal Code when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from such code all provisions which may from time to time be repealed. This copy of the Florence Municipal Code shall be available to all persons desiring to examine it and shall be considered the official Florence Municipal Code of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 15-80 § 13, 1980). 
1.01.090 - Sale of code copies. 
    The City Clerk shall maintain a reasonable supply of copies of this code to be available for purchase by the public at a moderate price. 
(Ord. 15-80 § 14, 1980). 
Chapter 1.04 - CITY SEAL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
 For statutory provisions on the city seal, see CRS 1973 § 31-4-110 (1975 Supp.) 

1.04.010 - Seal designated. 
    A seal, the impression of which is as follows: 
    In the center the picture of an oil derrick and the word "seal" and around the outer edge the words, "Florence, Freemont Co. Col., Incorporated Sept. 7, 1887," shall be and hereby is declared to be seal of the city of Florence. 
(Ord. 177 § 1, 1901). 
Chapter 1.08 - WARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
 For statutory provisions requiring the division of the City into wards, see CRS 1973 § 31-4-l04 (1975 Supp.). 

1.08.010 - Statutory authorization. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is authorized by the provisions of Section 31-4-104 of the Colorado Revised Statutes, 1973 as amended. 
(Ord. 13-80 § 2, 1980). 
1.08.020 - Ward One. 
    All that portion of the City lying east of the hereinafter described line shall be and constitute Ward One: 
    "Beginning at the intersection of the north line of the City limits with the center of North Robinson Avenue; thence southerly along the centerline of North Robinson Avenue to its common point with South Robinson Avenue, also known as Colorado State Highway 67 to the south line of the City Limits." 
(Ord. l3-80 § 3, 1980; Ord. No. 6-2012, § 1, 7-2-2012). 
1.08.030 - Ward Two. 
    All that portion of the City lying west of the boundary of Ward One and east of the hereinafter described line shall be and constitute Ward Two: 
    "Beginning at the intersection of the northern City limits with the center of West Seventh Street; thence westerly along the centerline of West Seventh Street to its intersection with North Santa Fe Avenue; thence southerly along the centerline of North Santa Fe Avenue to its intersection with West Second Street; thence westerly along West Second Street to its intersection with Church Avenue; thence southeasterly along the centerline of Church Avenue to its intersection with West Main Street; thence westerly along West Main Street to its intersection with Denver Street; thence southeasterly along the centerline of Denver Street and continuing straight along an extension of the centerline of Denver Street to its intersection with South Union Street; thence southerly along South Union Street to its intersection with Moore Drive; thence southwesterly along the centerline of Moore Drive to the south line of the City Limits." 
(Ord. 13-80 § 4, 1980; Ord. No. 6-2012, § 2, 7-2-2012). 
1.08.040 - Ward Three. 
    "All of that portion of the City lying west of the western boundary of Ward Two, as described in Section 1.08.030, shall be and constitute Ward Three." 
(Ord. l3-80 § 5, 1980; Ord. No. 6-2012, § 3, 7-2-2012). 
Chapter 1.12 - GENERAL PENALTY 

1.12.010 - General penalty provision. 
(A)  Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this code of ordinances, by doing any act prohibited or declared to be unlawful thereby, or declared to be an offense or misdemeanor thereby, or who fails to do any act required by any such provision, or who fails to do any act when such provision declares such failure to be unlawful or to be an offense or misdemeanor, or who pursues any business, trade, or calling, or does any act, for which a license, permit, or certificate is required thereby without having a valid license, permit, or certificate in effect, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor; and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding two thousand six hundred fifty dollars ($2,650.00) unless a specific penalty is provided for a particular misdemeanor plus court costs and any surcharges adopted by the city council. Each day upon which any such violation continues shall constitute a separate misdemeanor. 
(B)  The limitation on municipal court fines set forth in paragraph (A) above shall be adjusted for inflation in January 1, 2014, and on January 1 of each year thereafter pursuant to C.R.S. 13-10-113, as amended. 
(Ord. 27-92 § 1, 1992). 
(Ord. No. 9-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
1.12.020 - Secondary code infraction provisions. 
A.  Infractions of the secondary codes adopted by reference by the Florence Municipal Code as set forth in Section 1.01.020, except for infractions of the Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities, which are treated at Section 10.04.040, shall be a civil matter and result in a fine as set forth in subsection B of this section. Any penalty provisions contained within such secondary codes are expressly repealed in their entirety. 
B.  Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of any secondary code codified at Section 1.01.020, except for infractions of the Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities, by doing any act prohibited or declared to be an infraction thereof, or who fails to do any act required by any such provision, or who fails to do any act when such provision declares such failure to be an infraction, or who pursues any business, trade, or calling, or does any act for which a license, permit or certificate is required thereby without having a valid license, permit or certificate in effect, shall be subject to a fine not exceeding four hundred ninety-nine dollars ($499.00). Each day upon which any such infraction continues shall constitute a separate infraction. 
(Ord. 24-93 § 1, 1993). 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 
Chapter 2.04 - ADMINISTRATIVE ORGANIZATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
 For statutory provisions on the City Manager form of government, see CRS 1973 § 31-4-201 et seq. (1975 Supp.). 

2.04.010 - Chapter provisions to govern. 
    From and after the date of final passage and approval of the ordinance codified in this chapter, all administration of City affairs shall be provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 423 § 1, 1952). 
2.04.020 - Powers of City Council. 
    The City Council shall be the body of final responsibility and shall have all powers, and be subject to such responsibilities and limitations, which may now or hereafter be granted or imposed by law. 
(Ord. 423 § 2, 1952). 
2.04.030 - Powers of City Manager. 
    The City Manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the City and shall be responsible solely to the City Council for all affairs placed in his charge by law, ordinance or direction of the City Council. 
(Ord. 423 § 3, 1952). 
2.04.040 - City Attorney and Police Magistrate. 
    The City Attorney and the Police Magistrate shall be under the supervision of the City Council, and shall perform such duties as are imposed by law, ordinance or direction of the City Council. 
(Ord. 423 § 4, 1952). 
2.04.050 - City Manager-Departmental control. 
    All departments of the City, except for the City Attorney and the Police Magistrate, shall be under the direct control and supervision of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 423 § 5, 1952). 
2.04.060 - City Manager-Authority. 
    The City Manager is granted authority to establish such methods of handling details of administration as will, in his opinion, best promote efficiency in the municipal government. 
(Ord. 423 § 6, 1952). 
2.04.070 - Departments-Created. 
    There are created the following departments: 
A.  The Department of Finance, which shall be supervised by the City Clerk, which officer shall be ex-officio City Treasurer and Clerk of the Council. The City Clerk, as supervisor of the Department of Finance, shall keep and supervise all accounts and have custody of all public moneys of the City; apportion and collect special assessments; issue licenses; collect license fees; issue water statements; collect water accounts; make and keep a journal of proceedings of the Council; have custody of all public records of the City not specifically entrusted to any other office; and perform such other duties as may now or hereafter be assigned by law, ordinance or the City Manager; 
B.  The Department of Police, which shall be under the supervision and direction of a Chief of Police. The Department of Police shall cause the public peace of the City to be preserved and shall enforce all laws and ordinances and shall carry out other duties at the direction of the City Manager; 
C.  The Department of Fire, which shall be a volunteer department headed by a Fire Chief who shall be responsible for the supervision and direction of the department and for the prevention and suppression of fires and who shall perform other duties as the City Manager may direct; 
D.  The Department of Public Works, which shall be supervised and directed by a Director of Public Works. The Department of Public Works shall be responsible for the management, maintenance, repair and construction of all property of the City except as provided elsewhere in this code. Any function, or activity of the municipality not included elsewhere in this Code, shall come under the supervision of this department; 
E.  The Cemetery Department supervised by a Sexton, the functions of which department shall include cemetery construction, maintenance, landscaping and other necessary duties; 
F.  Health Department which shall be headed by a Sanitarian, which department shall perform all functions relating to the general health of the City. 
(Ord. 423 § 7, 1952). 
2.04.080 - Departments-Responsibilities. 
    All of the department created in Section 2.04.070 shall be under the direct control of the City Manager, and shall be responsible to him, and, in addition to the functions and duties herein described for them, they shall perform such duties as are now or hereafter assigned by law, ordinance or the City Manager. 
(Ord. 423 § 8, 1952). 
2.04.090 - Appointment of deputies. 
    The City Manager is granted authority to appoint deputies to the department heads referred to in Section 2.04.070, which deputies shall have the authority given their superiors in the event the heads of departments shall be absent or unable to act. 
(Ord. 423 § 9, 1952). 
Chapter 2.08 - CITY COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
 For statutory provisions on city council meetings, see CRS 1973 § 31-4-101 (1975 Supp.) and § 31-4-107(1) (1975 Supp.); for provisions on public meetings, see CRS 1973 § 29-9-101; for provisions on councilmen generally, see CRS 1973 § 31-4-106 et seq. and § 31-4-205 et seq. (1975 Supp.). 

2.08.010 - Meeting dates. 
    The regular meetings of the City Council of the City of Florence shall be held on the first and third Mondays of each month. 
(Ord. 292, 1920). 
2.08.020 - Councilmembers-Terms. 
A.  Councilmembers-Number. The City Council shall consist of seven (7) members, which number shall include the Mayor and two members from each ward in the City, elected in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  Mayor. The Mayor shall be elected from the City at large, by a plurality of votes cast for that office, at the regular municipal election held in November of odd-numbered years. The Mayor shall serve for a term of two (2) years. 
C.  Councilmembers. There shall be two (2) Councilmembers elected from each ward, each of which shall serve a four (4) year term. The terms of office shall be staggered so that one (1) Councilmember from each ward is elected every two (2) years. In the event that a vacancy in office occurs which requires the election of two (2) Councilmembers from a ward in the same election, the candidate receiving the highest number of votes shall be elected to serve a four (4) year term, and the candidate receiving the next highest number of votes shall be elected to serve a two (2) year term. At the next regular municipal election, and at each subsequent election thereafter, the Councilmembers to be elected shall serve four (4) year terms. 
(Ord. 7-97 § 1, 1997). 
2.08.030 - Vacancy filling. 
A.  Mayor-Vacancy. In case of the Mayor's death, disability, resignation, or other vacation of the office, the City Council shall declare a vacancy in the office of Mayor, and, upon such declaration, the City Council may order a special election as soon as practicable to fill the vacancy until the term of office of a successor elected at the next regular municipal election has commenced, as provided in CRS 31-4-105, and the City Council may appoint a registered elector in the City of Florence to act as Mayor until such special election. If the City Council does not call a special election, it shall, within sixty (60) days of the declaration of the vacancy, fill the vacancy by appointment until the term of the successor elected at the next regular municipal election has commenced. (CRS 31-4-103) 
B.  Councilmember-Vacancy. If any vacancy occurs in the office of a Councilmember because of death, resignation, removal or for any other reason, the City Council shall declare a vacancy in the office, and shall fill the vacancy by a majority vote of the City Council within sixty (60) days from the declaration of the vacancy, or by special election, as provided in CRS 31-4-108(b). A successor so appointed or elected shall serve until the term of a successor elected at the next regular municipal election has commenced. (CRS 31-4-106). 
(Ord. 7-97 § 2, 1997). 
2.08.040 - Commencement of term. 
    Following the regular municipal election, the term of all newly elected members of the city council, including the Mayor, shall commence at the first meeting of the governing body immediately following the survey of election returns. (CRS 31-4-105) 
(Ord. 7-97, § 3, 1997). 
(Ord. No. 1-2013, § 1, 2-4-2013; Ord. No. 5-2014, § 1, 3-3-2014) 
Chapter 2.12 - CITY ATTORNEY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
 For statutory provisions on city attorneys, see CRS 1973 § 31-4-208 (1975 Supp.). 

2.12.010 - Office created. 
    There is created the office of City Attorney in the City of Florence whose term of office shall be as by law prescribed. 
(Ord. 29-78 § 2, 1979). 
2.12.020 - Powers and duties generally. 
    The City Attorney shall prosecute all actions upon any ordinance of the City for the recovery of fines and penalties; and, as the case may be, shall prosecute or defend every action originating or pending before a justice of the peace or in any court, to which action the City shall be a party, or in which action the official acts of any of its officers or agents shall be involved; provided, that without the order of the City Council, said Attorney shall commence no action in the interest of the City except for the violation of a City ordinance. 
(Ord. 29-78 § 3, 1979). 
2.12.030 - Drafting of documents. 
    The City Attorney shall, when required by order of the City Council or any committee thereof or any City officer or officers proper in any particular case, draft any ordinance, contract, conveyance or other instrument in writing in relation to the execution of corporate powers or corporate business. 
(Ord. 29-78 § 4, 1979). 
2.12.040 - Legal advisory powers. 
    The City Attorney shall act as the legal advisor of the City Council, of the committees of said Council and of other City officers, in all matters relating to the official powers or duties of such officer or officers, or to the corporate business of the City, and shall, upon request of the mayor, furnish an opinion in writing upon any such matter. It shall be the duty of said Attorney to attend the meetings of the Council, of which he shall be entitled to notice in like manner as members of the Council. 
(Ord. 29-78 § 5, 1979). 
2.12.050 - Executions. 
    The City Attorney shall cause executions to be issued on judgments recovered in favor of the City and attend to their prompt collection. 
(Ord. 29-78 § 6, 1979). 
2.12.060 - Performance of other duties. 
    The City Attorney shall perform all such other services in the line of his profession, connected with the business of the corporation, as shall be required of him by resolution, order or ordinance of said council. 
(Ord. 29-78 § 7, 1979). 
2.12.070 - Salary. 
    The City Attorney shall be paid a salary to be determined from time to time by the City Council. Such payments shall be made on a monthly basis. 
(Ord. 29-78 § 8, 1979). 
Chapter 2.16 - MUNICIPAL COURTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
 For statutory provisions on municipal courts, see CRS 1973 § 13-10-101-13-10-125; for provisions on trial by jury for petty offenses, see CRS 1973 § 16-10-109. 

2.16.010 - Establishment and jurisdiction. 
    There shall be a Qualified Municipal Court of Record which shall keep a verbatim record of its proceedings and a Municipal Judge who, as a condition of holding this office, shall have been admitted to and at all times during his term shall be licensed in the practice of law in Colorado. Preference may be given to a qualified resident of Florence for the position of Municipal Judge. The Municipal Court shall have exclusive original jurisdiction to hear, try, and determine all cases arising under the ordinances of the City of Florence for the violation and enforcement thereof and there shall be no change of venue therefrom. 
(Ord. 8-92 § 1, 1992: Ord. 3-87 § 2(part), 1987). 
2.16.020 - Municipal Judge-Appointment-Term of office. 
    The Municipal Judge shall be appointed by the City Council after the general election in odd-numbered years. The term of office shall be for two (2) years from the date of appointment unless sooner terminated for cause as provided in the Colorado Revised Statutes in effect at said time. In the event of a vacancy in the office of Municipal Judge, prior to the expiration of a term of office as set forth herein, any appointment shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. City Council may also appoint such additional Assistant Municipal Judges as may be necessary to act in case of temporary absence, sickness, disqualification or other inability of the presiding Municipal Judge to act. 
    The term of such appointment of an Assistant Judge shall be for the term reasonably deemed necessary as based on the reason for the inability of the presiding Municipal Judge. 
(Ord. 8-92 § 2, 1992: Ord. 3-87 § 2(part), 1987). 
2.16.040 - Municipal Judge-Compensation. 
    The salary of the Municipal Judge shall be established by ordinance upon the appointment of said Judge. The salary shall be a fixed annual compensation which shall be payable on a monthly or other periodic basis. Any Assistant Municipal Judges shall receive such compensation as shall be determined at the time of their appointment 
(Ord 8-92 § 4, 1992: Ord. 3-87 § 2(part), 1987). 
2.16.050 - Clerk of the Municipal Court. 
    The Municipal Judge shall serve as ex-officio clerk of the Municipal Court who shall receive no further or additional compensation for the performance of said duties. The Municipal Judge acting as Municipal Court Clerk shall execute a performance bond as required by Colorado Revised Statutes the cost of which shall be paid by the City. 
(Ord 3-87 § 2(part), 1987). 
2.16.060 - Court facilities and supplies. 
    Space for court proceedings shall be provided as deemed appropriate by the City Council and may include limitations upon court times due to sharing of facilities with other City entities. The City Council shall provide necessary moneys for supplies necessary to conduct the business of the court through and at the time of the annual budget preparation. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2(part), 1987). 
2.16.070 - Fines and penalties. 
    The Municipal Judge shall be authorized to impose fines and penalties as provided by ordinances of the City limited by provisions of the Colorado Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2 (part), 1987). 
2.16.080 - Costs. 
    The Municipal Judge shall be authorized to impose costs of zero to three hundred dollars ($0.00 to $300.00) after conviction of an ordinance violation at a trial to the court, or to a jury, plea of guilty or plea of no contest. 
(Ord. 27-92 § 2, 1992). 
2.16.085 - Surcharge for purchase of police equipment. 
    A surcharge in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be imposed against a defendant, in addition to all other costs and fines imposed, after the defendant is convicted of a municipal ordinance violation at a trial to the court, or to a jury, plea of guilty or plea of no contests. Said surcharge is dedicated to the purchase of equipment to be used by the Police Department and shall be set aside in a separate category within the general fund for this particular purpose. 
(Ord. No. 02-21-2017K, § 1, 3-6-2017; Ord. No. 12-2012, § 1, 12-3-2012). 
2.16.090 - Payment of fines-Traffic violations. 
    The fine schedule set forth in Section 10.04.040 for violation of the provisions of the Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities may be payable as penalty assessments or, the defendant may appear before the Judge to enter a plea or have a trial. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2(part), 1987). 
2.16.100 - Fines and costs. 
    All fines and costs collected or received by the Municipal Court shall be reflected in a written receipt. A copy of said receipt shall be given to the person delivering the money to the Municipal Court, a copy shall be given to the City Clerk, and a copy shall be retained in the records of the Municipal Court. Each such receipt shall be identified by the name of the defendant and by the citation number. 
    All moneys received by the Municipal Court within one (1) calendar week shall be delivered on or before the close of the first business day of the next calendar week to the City Clerk or his authorized agent together with the City Clerk's copy of all written receipts. 
    In the absence of the Municipal Judge, the City Clerk, or his agent, shall be authorized to accept any and all moneys otherwise directed to the Municipal Court. In such case, the City Clerk or his agent shall prepare a receipt for said moneys with one (1) copy to the Municipal Judge, one (1) copy to the person delivering the money, and one (1) copy for the records of the City Clerk. 
    All moneys received by the City Clerk shall be deposited in the general fund of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2(part), 1987). 
2.16.110 - Payment of moneys. 
    In the event that moneys must be paid, the Municipal Judge shall request from the City Clerk a check drawn on the account of the City of Florence to a specific payee and designate the name of the defendant and case number. This check shall be ready to be delivered to the designated payee or the Municipal Judge no later than two (2) business days from the date of the request. 
(Ord. 387 § 2 (part), 1987). 
2.16.120 - Procedure. 
    The Municipal Court rules of procedure promulgated by the Supreme Court of the state of Colorado, from time to time, shall govern the procedures in Municipal Court. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2 (part), 1987). 
2.16.130 - Jury trial fee. 
    A defendant waives his right to a jury trial unless within ten (10) days of his arraignment or entry of plea he files a written demand for a jury trial and at the same time tenders to the Court a jury fee of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars, unless the fee is waived by the Judge because of the indigence of the defendant. If the action is dismissed or the defendant is acquitted of the charge, or if the defendant having paid a jury fee files with the Court, at least ten (10) days before the scheduled trial date a written waiver of jury trial, the jury fee shall be refunded. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2 (part), 1987). 
2.16.140 - Jury trials. 
    In any action before Municipal Court in which the defendant is entitled to a jury trial by the constitution or the general laws of the State, such party shall have a jury upon request. The jury shall consist of three (3) jurors unless a greater number, not to exceed six (6), is requested by the defendant. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2 (part), 1987). 
2.16.150 - Jurors-Payment. 
    Jurors shall be paid the sum of six ($6.00) dollars per day for actual jury service, and three ($3.00) dollars for each day of service of the jury panel alone. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2 (part), 1987). 
2.16.160 - Contempt. 
    The Municipal Court Judge shall have full power and authority to punish for contempt of court; provided, however, that for a juvenile found in contempt, imprisonment may not exceed forty-eight (48) hours in a facility approved for the detention of juveniles or a fine of three hundred ($300.00) dollars and for an adult the imprisonment may not exceed ninety (90) days and the fine may not exceed three hundred ($300.00) dollars. 
(Ord. 3-87 § 2 (part), 1987). 
2.16.170 - Collection of unpaid municipal court fees, costs and fines. 
    The City Manager, or his or her designee, is authorized to assign for collection to any agency or agencies authorized to do business in the State of Colorado, as determined by the City Manager, or his or her designee, all fees, costs, and fines which have been assessed by the municipal court of the City and which are unpaid to the City and are delinquent. 
(Ord. No. 08-06-2018B, § 1, 8-20-2018) 
2.16.180 - Addition of costs of collection. 
    The agency or agencies authorized pursuant to this article to collect on behalf of the City said fees, costs, and fines, is directed to add to the amounts assigned by the City for collection of any and all amounts charged the City for services rendered in collecting such delinquent fees, costs and fines, not to exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the amount assigned for collection. 
(Ord. No. 08-06-2018B, § 1, 8-20-2018) 
Chapter 2.20 - PLANNING COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
 For statutory provisions on municipal planning commissions, see CRS 1973 § 31-23-201 et seq. (1975 Supp.) 

2.20.010 - Commission created. 
    Pursuant to Title 31, Article 23, Part 2 of the Colorado Revised Statutes, 1973, as amended, there is created a Planning Commission for the City of Florence, Colorado. 
(Ord. 25-78 § 2, 1978). 
2.20.015 - Mayor defined. 
    As required by Colorado Revised Statutes, for purposes of membership on the Planning Commission, the word "Mayor" shall be defined as the Florence City Manager; thereinafter said member shall be called the City Manager. For purposes of providing the power to appoint members to the Planning Commission, the "Mayor" shall be understood to be the then duly elected Mayor of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 17-88 § 1, 1988). 
2.20.020 - Membership. 
    The Planning Commission shall be composed of seven (7) members. One (1) such member shall be the City Manager of the City of Florence. One (1) such member shall be a Councilman selected by the then duly elected Mayor of the City of Florence. The remaining members of the Planning Commission shall be bona fide residents of the City of Florence appointed by the duly elected Mayor of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 17-88 § 2, 1988). 
2.20.030 - Terms. 
    The City Manager shall serve in said capacity so long as he continues as City Manager. The Councilman selected by the duly elected Mayor of the City of Florence shall serve as a member of the Planning Commission until the term of office for which the Councilman was elected ends, unless he sooner resigns. In the event of a resignation, the duly elected Mayor shall appoint another Councilmember who shall fill the unexpired term of the person replaced. Both the City Manager and the Councilman selected by the duly elected Mayor shall serve as "ex officio" members of the Planning Commission. The terms of the five (5) appointed members of the Commission shall be for a period of six (6) years or until their successor takes office; except that the respective terms shall be as follows concerning further appointment to the Commission: 
(1)  Those members presently serving shall complete their unexpired terms; (2) one (1) of the members now appointed shall serve two (2) years; (3) one (1) of the members now appointed shall serve for four (4) years. 
(Ord. 17-88 § 3, 1988). 
2.20.040 - Salary. 
    All members of the Planning Commission of the City of Florence shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. 25-78 § 5, 1978). 
2.20.050 - Participation in other offices. 
    No appointed member of the Planning Commission may, during his term on the Commission, participate in any other municipal office. 
(Ord. 25-78 § 6, 1978). 
2.20.060 - Termination and vacancy filling. 
    Should any member of the Planning Commission cease to reside within the City of Florence, Colorado, his membership on the Commission shall terminate automatically. Members of the Commission, other than the ex officio members, may be removed, after a public hearing by the Mayor for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. The City Council of the City of Florence may remove either or both of the ex officio members for the reasons stated above. The Mayor of the City Council, as the case may be, shall file a written statement of reasons for such removal. Vacancies occurring other than through the expiration of a term shall be filled by the Mayor except that if the Mayor is removed, his vacancy shall be filled by the City Council. 
(Ord. 25-78 § 7, l978). 
2.20.070 - Meetings and rules. 
    The Planning Commission shall elect its chairman from among the non ex officio members of the Commission and shall create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine necessary. The term of the chairman shall be one (1) year, with eligibility for reelection. The Commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting each month. It shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations which shall be a public record. 
(Ord. 25-78 § 8, 1978). 
2.20.080 - Employees-Contract authority. 
    The Commission may appoint such employees as it may deem necessary for its work, whose appointment, promotion, demotion and removal shall be subject to the same provisions of law as govern other corresponding civil employees of the municipality. The Commission may also, with the consent of the council, contract with city planners, engineers and architects and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the Commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amount appropriated for the purpose by Council, which shall provide the funds, equipment and accommodations necessary for the Commission's work. 
(Ord. 25-78 § 9, 1978). 
2.20.090 - Statutory duties. 
    The Planning Commission shall have all the powers and shall perform all the duties and obligations set forth in Title 31, Article 23, Part 2 of the Colorado Revised Statutes, 1973, as amended. 
(Ord. 25-78 § 10, 1978). 
Chapter 2.22 - POLICEMEN'S PENSION FUND BOARD OF TRUSTEES 

2.22.010 - Statutory authorization. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is authorized by the provisions of Title 31, Article 30, CRS, 1973 as amended. 
(Ord. 3-82 §1, 1982). 
2.22.020 - Personnel of Board. 
    The Board of Trustees of the Policemen's Pension Fund of the City shall consist of the Mayor, the City Clerk as ex officio treasurer, and one (1) member of the Police Department who shall be elected by that Department. The Board shall elect from its members a president and a secretary. The City Clerk shall administer the funds of the Policemen's Pension as provided by Title 31, Article 30, CRS, 1973 as amended. The Board shall serve without salary. 
(Ord. 3-82 §2, 1982). 
2.22.030 - Authority of Board. 
    The Board of Trustees of the Policemen's Pension Fund shall make all necessary rules and regulations for managing and discharging its duties and shall decide all applications for relief or pensions and its action on such applications shall be final and conclusive. The Board shall keep a record of any action taken concerning matters properly before the Board. 
(Ord. 3-82 §3, 1982). 
Chapter 2.28 - RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS 

2.28.010 - Key employees defined. 
    For purposes of this chapter, key employees are defined as the City Manager, the Chief of Police, the Director of Public Works, and the Water Superintendent. 
(Ord. 9-2006 (part), 2006). 
2.28.020 - Residency requirements for key employees. 
    Key employees may be subject to reasonable requirements as to the maximum distance the key employee's residence may be from the place of work. Such conditions may be imposed by contract upon the City Manager by the City Council. The City Manager may impose such reasonable requirements upon the Chief of Police, the Director of Public Works and the Water Superintendent as, in his or her discretion, is deemed advisable and appropriate. 
(Ord. 9-2006 (part), 2006). 
2.28.030 - Sanctions. 
    The failure of any key employee to comply with the residency requirements hereunder may constitute sufficient grounds for termination of the employee's employment. 
(Ord. 9-2006 (part), 2006). 
Chapter 2.32 - SOCIAL SECURITY COVERAGE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
 For statutory provisions on public employees social security, see CRS 1973 § 24-51-701 et seq. 

2.32.010 - Findings and purpose. 
    It is the considered opinion of the City Council of Florence that the extension of the Social Security System to employees and officers of the City of Florence will be of great benefit, not only to the employees of the City by providing that said employees and officers may participate in the provisions of the Old Age and Survivors' Insurance System, and will also be of great benefit to the City of Florence by enabling it to attract and retain in employment the best personnel and thus increase the efficiency of its government. 
(Ord. 422 (part), 1952). 
2.32.020 - Statutory authorization. 
    The 38th General Assembly of the State of Colorado, in regular session, enacted a statute known as House Bill No. 291, which is the enabling Act provided for in Section 218 of Public Law 734, 81st Congress, which designated the Department of Employment Security, State of Colorado, to act as the department to implement the coverage of employees and officers under the said Old Age and Survivors' Insurance System. The City of Florence is authorized to execute and deliver to the Department of Employment Security, State of Colorado, a plan or plans and agreement, required under Section 5 of said enabling Act and the Social Security Act, to extend coverage to employees and officers of the City of Florence and do all other necessary things to effectuate coverage of employees and officers under the Old Age and Survivors' Insurance System. 
(Ord. 422 (part), 1952). 
2.32.030 - Payroll deductions. 
    The Clerk is authorized to establish a system of payroll deductions to be matched by payments by the City of Florence to be made into the Contribution Fund of the Social Security Act through the Department of Employment Security, and to make charges of this tax to the fund, or funds, from which wage or salary payments are issued to employees of the City of Florence. Such payments are to be made in accordance with the provisions of Section 1400 of the Federal Insurance Contribution Act on all services which constitute employment within the meaning of that Act. Payments made to the Department of Employment Security, State of Colorado, shall be due and payable on or before the eighteenth (18th) day of the month immediately following the completed calendar quarter, and such payments which are delinquent shall bear interest at the rate of one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) per month until such time as payments are made. 
(Ord. 422 (part), 1952). 
2.32.040 - Payment into contribution fund. 
    Appropriation is made from the proper fund or funds of the City of Florence in the necessary amount to pay into the contribution fund as provided in Section 3 (c) (1) of the enabling Act and in accordance with the plan or plans and agreement, authority is given to the Mayor and the Clerk of the City of Florence to enter into an agreement with the Department of Employment Security, State of Colorado, which agreement shall be in accordance with House Bill No. 291 and with paragraph 218 of the Social Security Act. Such plan and agreement shall provide that the participation of this City of Florence shall be in effect as of January 1, 1952. 
(Ord. 422 (part), 1952). 
Chapter 2.34 - MATCHING RETIREMENT PROGRAM 

2.34.010 - Participation. 
    The City of Florence shall participate in a matching retirement program with the employees of the City of Florence effective February 1, 2002, as hereinafter set forth under the existing deferred compensation plan established under Internal Revenue Code 457 entitled The United States Conference of Mayors Deferred Compensation Plan For Public Employees as Restated effective January 1, 2002, together with any amendments thereto (hereinafter the "Plan" or "Deferred Compensation Plan".) 
(Ord. 1 §1, 2002). 
2.34.020 - Appropriation. 
    Appropriation is made from the proper fund or funds of the City of Florence in the necessary amount to pay into the retirement account of the Plan as hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. 1 §1, 2002). 
2.34.030 - Contributions. 
    The Finance Officer of the City of Florence is authorized to establish a system of payroll deductions from an eligible employee's base pay for each pay period to be matched by a contribution from the City of Florence of not greater than three (3) percent of such employee's base pay, unless the matching contribution is required by law or the Plan to be less, for all regular full-time employees of the City who are otherwise eligible to participate in the Plan. To be eligible for the City's matching contribution, an eligible employee must contribute one (1), two (2) or three (3) percent of his/her base pay to the Plan, or no less than the combined minimum amount required by the Plan. In addition, an eligible employee may contribute more than three (3) percent of his or her base pay but he or she will receive no further matching contribution from the City for employee contributions above three (3) percent. This section does not apply to police officers. 
(Ord. 1 §1, 2002). 
2.34.040 - Eligibility. 
    Only "regular full-time" employees, as defined at Section 3.01 of the City of Florence Personnel Policy, and are otherwise eligible under the Plan, who have one (1) full year of continuous service with the City, are eligible to receive the City's matching contribution defined in Section 2.34.030. Any employee who resigns, or otherwise ceases to work for the City for any length of time, and then returns to work as a regular full-time employee, shall only be eligible to receive the City's matching contribution after one (1) year of continuous employment following such severance from service. 
(Ord. 1 §1, 2002). 
2.34.050 - Base pay. 
    Base pay shall include vacation and sick leave pay taken in the normal course of employment. Base pay shall not include overtime pay, uniform allowance, accumulated sick leave pay, accumulated vacation pay (except as noted above), or any other form of extra pay. 
(Ord. 1 §1, 2002). 
2.34.060 - Police officers. 
A.  The police officer ("member") and the City ("employer") contribution rate to the FPPA defined benefit system for members who are active in the Statewide Hybrid Plan and who have selected either the defined benefit component and money purchase component or the money purchase component only on January 1, 2006 will be eighteen (18) percent of base salary and shall be split ten (10) percent member and eight (8) percent employer. In addition, City shall contribute one and two-tenths (1.2) percent of the member's base salary to the City's 457 deferred compensation plan. 
B.  The employer elects to offer the members who are active on January 1, 2006 the option of participating in the Statewide Defined Benefit Plan at a contribution rate of twenty (20) percent of base salary that shall be split ten and eight-tenths (10.8) percent member and nine and two-tenths (9.2) percent employer. 
C.  The City of Florence elects to cover all members hired after January 1, 2006 under the Statewide Defined Benefit Plan at a contribution rate of sixteen (16) percent of base salary that shall be split eight (8) percent employer and eight (8) percent member. An additional two (2) percent of base salary shall be contributed by the member to the City's 457 deferred compensation plan for all members hired after the date of entry pursuant to Resolution 15-2005, and one and two-tenths (1.2) percent of the member's base salary shall be contributed by the City to the City's 457 deferred compensation plan. 
(Ord. 10-2006, 2006). 
2.34.070 - Safety clause. 
    The City Council finds, determines, and declares that this chapter is necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health, and safety of the residents of the City. 
(Ord. 1 §1, 2002). 
Chapter 2.36 - INITIATIVE, REFERENDUM AND RECALL[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
 For statutory provisions detailing initiative and referendum procedures, see CRS 1973 § 1-40-115 et seq.; for provisions on the recall of city officers, see CRS 1973 § 31-4-501 et seq. (1975 Supp.) 

2.36.010 - Powers of the people. 
    The legislative power of the City of Florence shall be vested, as heretofore, in the City Council subject to the general laws of the State, but hereafter the people of said City shall have the power to propose ordinances and to adopt or reject the same at the polls, independent of the City Council, and also shall have the power, independent of the City Council, at their own option, to adopt or reject, at the polls, any ordinance or part of any ordinance adopted by the City Council. 
(Ord. 265 § 1, 1913). 
2.36.020 - Initiative procedure. 
    The initiative power referred to in Section 2.36.010 may be exercised by the legal voters of said City whenever fifteen percent (15%) of the legal voters desire to propose any ordinance by petition, and every such petition shall include the full text of the ordinance proposed. Such initiative petitions shall be addressed to and filed with the City Clerk at least sixty (60) days before the election at which they are to be voted upon. 
(Ord. 265 § 2, 1913). 
2.36.030 - Referendum procedure. 
    The referendum power referred to in Section 2.36.010 may be ordered against any ordinance, section or part of any ordinance of the City Council by a petition signed by at least ten percent (10%) of the legal voters of said City. Referendum petitions shall likewise be addressed to and filed with the City Clerk of the City not more than ninety (90) days after the adoption of the ordinance on which the referendum is demanded. The filing of a referendum petition against any section or part of any ordinance shall not delay the remainder of the ordinance from becoming operative. 
(Ord. 265 § 3, 1913). 
2.36.040 - Elections to be held at general election. 
    All elections on matters of ordinances initiated or referred to the people of the City shall be held at the general election for city officers and all such ordinances shall become a law of the City when approved by a majority of the vote cast thereon and not otherwise, and shall take effect from and after the date of the public announcement of the vote thereon by the Mayor of said City, but not later than thirty (30) days after the vote thereon has been canvassed. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to deprive the City Council of the right to adopt any ordinance subject to the right of referendum herein reserved. The whole number of votes cast for Mayor of said City at the regular general election last preceding the filing of any petition for the initiative or referendum shall be the basis on which the number of legal votes necessary to sign such petition shall be counted. 
(Ord. 265 § 4, 1913). 
2.36.050 - Petitions. 
    The City Clerk shall submit all ordinances initiated or referred to the people of said City for adoption or rejection at the polls in compliance therewith. Such petitions for initiating or referring ordinances shall be signed by qualified electors in their own persons only, to which shall be attached the residence address of such person and the date of signing the same. To each of such petitions there shall be attached an affidavit of some qualified elector of said City that each signature thereon is the signature of the person whose name it purports to be and that to the best of the knowledge and belief of the affiant each of the persons signing said petition was, at the time of signing, a qualified elector of said City. Such petition so verified shall be prima facie evidence that the signatures thereon are genuine and true and that the persons signing the same are qualified electors. 
(Ord. 265 § 5, 1913). 
2.36.060 - Ordinance style. 
    The style of all ordinances adopted by the people through the initiative shall be: "Be it ordained by the People of the City of Florence." 
(Ord. 265 § 6, 1913). 
2.36.070 - Recall-Established. 
    Every elective officer of the City of Florence may be recalled from office at any time by the electors entitled to vote for his successor, and such procedure shall be known as the recall, and it shall be an additional method for the removal of officers in addition to other methods provided by law. 
(Ord. 265 S7, 1913). 
2.36.080 - Recall-Procedure. 
A.  The procedure to effect the recall of any elective officer shall be as follows: 
    A petition signed by electors qualified to vote for a successor of the incumbent, equal in number to twenty-five percent (25%) of the total vote cast at the last preceding election for all candidates to the office which the incumbent sought to be recalled occupies, demanding the removal of said officer and the election of his successor as provided by law shall be filed with the City Clerk; and such petition shall contain a general statement in not more than two hundred (200) words of the ground, or grounds, on which such recall is sought, which statement shall be made for the information of the electors, and the electors shall be the sole judges of the legality, reasonableness and sufficiency of the ground or grounds assigned for such recall, and said ground or grounds shall not be open to review. 
    Signatures need not be all on the same page of paper but if more than one page is necessary they must be securely fastened, and the ground or grounds must be read by the signers each separately, and the signer must subscribe after his name the date of his signing and the number or place of his residence, and he must sign the same of his own free and voluntary act and without intimidation, payment or promise of reward, and the person circulating such petition must make and subscribe an oath on each sheet of signatures thereof, that the signatures thereon are genuine, and a false oath, wilfully so made and subscribed by such person, shall be perjury, and be punished as such. All petitions shall be deemed and held to be sufficient as they appear to be signed by the persons whose names are subscribed and a sufficient number of signers appear thereon, giving the dates of their signature and their street number, providing the same shall be within the territory required as above provided, and all signers shall be deemed to be qualified electors unless a protest in writing, under oath, shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk within fifteen (l5) days after the petition is filed. After such protest is filed setting forth the grounds thereof, the City Clerk shall forthwith mail a copy of such protest to the person or persons named, and against whose signatures protest is made, with a notice of the time for hearing such protest, which shall not be less than five (5) nor more than ten (10) days after the mailing of such notice. Such hearings shall be before the Mayor of the City, unless he should be a party affected by said recall, in which event it shall be before the Police Magistrate of the City. All testimony offered on hearing of protests shall be under oath. The proceedings shall be prompt and without delay, and be determined within not more than three (3) days from the date set for hearing. The sufficiency of the grounds of the petition for recall shall in no manner be considered by the Mayor or Police Magistrate and their finding as to the qualifications or sufficiency in number of signers shall be final. If the number of qualified signers is found to be insufficient the petition may be recalled and again filed with sufficient additional names, if the same be done within fifteen (15) days, and it shall then be considered as a new petition filed. 
B.  The above petition for recall having been filed, and there being no protests to the sufficiency of the signers thereon, or the same having been disposed of as herein provided, so leaving the petition unchallenged, the said petition shall, at the first meeting of the City Council occurring not less than fifteen (15) days after the filing of said petition, be referred to the City Council and a record thereof shall be spread upon the minutes of their proceedings. 
C.  If the person or persons against whom recall petition has been filed shall tender their resignation, the same shall be accepted and the vacancy filled as provided by statute for the filling of such vacancies. But if such officer sought to be recalled shall not resign within five (5) days after said petition of recall is submitted to the City Council, the City Council shall, by resolution, call a special election to be conducted in accordance with the laws governing elections in municipalities, to vote upon the question of the recall of such officer or officers against whom petitions of recall are on file and for the election of their successors. 
(Ord. 265 § 8, 1913). 
2.36.090 - Statutes adopted. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the laws, rules and regulations provided by the statutes of the State of Colorado for the initiative and referendum and the recall of officers and the election of their successors are adopted,(so far as the same may be applicable), and are made the law, rules and regulations governing the initiative and referendum and the recall of elective municipal officers and the election of their successors in the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 265 § 9, 1913). 
Chapter 2.40 - SALE AND PURCHASE OF CITY PROPERTY 

2.40.010 - Purchasing authority. 
    All purchases of materials, supplies and equipment of every kind and character for any and all departments of the City shall be made by or at the direction of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 423 § 10, 1952). 
Chapter 2.44 - SALARIES 

2.44.010 - Statutory authorization. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is authorized and required by the provisions of CRS, 1973 as amended, Title 31, Article 4. 
(Ord. 6-85 (part), 1985: Ord. 18-83 (part), 1983: Ord. 2-82 (part), 1982). 
2.44.020 - Compensation of Mayor and Councilmembers. 
A.  Compensation of the Mayor and Councilmembers. The salary or compensation of the Mayor of the City of Florence shall be two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per month. The salary or compensation of the Councilmembers shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month. 
B.  Pursuant to C.R.S. 31-4-405 and C.R.S. 31-4-109, the compensation of any Councilmember or Mayor shall not be increased nor decreased during his or her term of office. 
C.  Any person appointed to fill a vacancy in the office of Mayor or Councilmember shall receive the same compensation as the person who created the vacancy. 
D.  A person who has resigned as Mayor or Councilmember cannot be reelected or reappointed during the same term if the compensation for said office has been increased during that term. 
(Ord. No. 06-19-2017A, § 1, 7-10-2017; Ord. 1-2007, 2007). 
2.44.030 - Compensation of employees. 
    The employees of the City of Florence shall be paid a salary within the attached schedules of compensation. The City Manager may grant an increase to an employee within the limits provided in this schedule at any time upon the basis of efficiency and/or seniority provided, however, that no increase shall be granted which exceeds the budgetary allotment for salaries for the specific department that year without the consent and approval of the City Council. 
(Ord. 1-91 § 2, 1991). 
2.44.040 - Compensation of the City Manager, City Attorney, and Municipal Judge. 
    The compensation to be paid to the City Manager and City Attorney shall be determined and set by the City Council from time to time as deemed appropriate by said City Council. The compensation to be paid to the Municipal Judge shall be determined as provided by Section 2.16.040. 
(Ord. 1-91 § 3, 1991). 
Chapter 2.48 - TREE BOARD 

2.48.010 - Creation and establishment. 
    There is created and established a City Tree Board for the City of Florence, which shall consist of five (5) members, citizens and residents of this city, who shall be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council. 
(Ord. 6-84 § 1, 1984). 
2.48.020 - Term of office. 
    The term of the five (5) persons to be appointed by the Mayor shall be three (3) years except that the term of two (2) of the members appointed to the first board shall be for only one (1) year and the term of two (2) members of the first board shall be for two (2) years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Ord. 6-84 § 2, 1984). 
2.48.030 - Compensation. 
    Members of the Board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. 6-84 § 3, 1984). 
2.48.040 - Duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the Board to study, investigate, counsel and develop and update annually a written plan for the care, preservation, trimming, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in public ways, streets and alleys. Such plan will be presented annually to the City Council and upon their acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the City. The Board, when requested by the City Council, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Ord. 6-84 § 4, 1984). 
2.48.050 - Operation. 
    The Board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. 6-84 § 5, 1984). 
Chapter 2.50 - CIRSA WORKERS' COMPENSATION INSURANCE COVERAGE 

2.50.010 - Contract authorized-Purpose-Coverage authorized-Effective date. 
A.  The CIRSA is approved, and the Mayor and City Clerk are authorized to execute the contract on behalf of the City. 
B.  Participation in and coverage through CIRSA shall be for workers' compensation coverage only. 
C.  Participation in and coverage through CIRSA as set forth in this chapter shall take effect on the 1st day of January, 1993. 
D.  A copy of the ordinance codified in this chapter and the executed contract shall be transmitted to CIRSA at 950 South Cherry Street, Suite 800, Denver, Colorado 80222. 
(Ord. 32-92 § 1(part), 1992). 
2.50.020 - Necessary clause. 
    It is deemed necessary to the immediate preservation of the public health and safety that the ordinance codified in this chapter take effect before thirty (30) days after publication on second reading to avoid a lapse in workmans compensation insurance coverage for city employees. 
(Ord. 32-92 § 1(part), 1992). 
Chapter 2.51 - CIRSA PROPERTY/CASUALTY INSURANCE COVERAGE 

2.51.010 - Approval of contract. 
A.  The CIRSA contract is approved and the Mayor and City Clerk are authorized to execute the contract on behalf of the City. 
B.  Participation in and coverage through CIRSA as set forth herein shall take effect on the 8th day of December, 1996. 
C.  A copy of the ordinance codified in this chapter and the executed contract shall be transmitted to CIRSA at 950 South Cherry Street, Suite 800, Denver, Colorado 80222. 
(Ord. 10-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
2.51.020 - Necessary clause. 
    It is deemed necessary to the immediate preservation of the public health and safety that the ordinance codified in this chapter take effect before thirty (30) days after publication on second reading to avoid a lapse in the property/casualty insurance coverage for the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 10-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
Chapter 2.52 - EMPLOYEE LEGAL DEFENSE POLICY 

2.52.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to create a local policy for the legal defense of employees of the City of Florence named as defendants in civil suits to the extent such a policy is consistent with Colorado Revised Statutes, as amended, and the Colorado Constitution. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.020 - Scope and definitions. 
A.  The Colorado Governmental Immunity Act (the "Act") provides that the City, under certain circumstances, must assume the cost of defending its employees and paying judgments and settlements against its employees. This policy implements the provisions of the Act and applies to the same extent as the Act. This policy also applies to claims brought under federal law as provided by the Act. 
B.  As used in this policy, "claim" means a civil action brought in state or federal court, which is subject to the Act or which is based on a federal law and lies in tort as defined in the Act. 
C.  As used in this policy, "employee" shall have the same meaning as provided in Section 24-10-102(4), C.R.S., as amended, and shall include a former employee of the City. 
D.  By adopting this policy, the City is expressly not waiving any immunities or monetary limits under C.R.S. Section 24-10-101 et seq., as amended, (Colorado Governmental Immunity Act), or any other immunities as are established by law. 
E.  This policy is to be construed consistent with Article X, Section 20 of the Colorado Constitution (TABOR); and is not to be construed as a multi-year obligation, but rather as a policy to be reviewed on an annual basis. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.030 - Policy. 
    Cost of Defense. The City shall be liable for the reasonable costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, of the defense of an employee against a claim if: 
A.  The City Attorney determines that the claim arose out of injuries sustained from an act or omission of the employee occurring or alleged in the complaint to have occurred during the performance of the employee's duties and within the scope of the employee's employment with the City; and 
B.  The City Attorney determines that the employee's act or omission was not willful or wanton; and 
C.  The employee does not compromise or settle the claim without the written consent of this City Council; and 
D.  The employee provided written notice to the City Council, through the City Attorney, of the incident or occurrence which led to the claim, within a reasonable time after the incident or occurrence, if the incident or occurrence could reasonably have been expected to lead to a claim; and 
E.  In the case of an action to which the City is not a party defendant, the employee provided written notice to the City Council, through the City Attorney, of existence of the action against the employee within fifteen (15) days after the commencement of the action. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.040 - Legal representation for employee. 
    The City shall have met any responsibility it may have under Section 2.52.030 through the services of the attorney assigned by the insurance entity which provides a defense for the claim, or through the services of the City Attorney or a different attorney selected by the City. Nothing herein shall prohibit an employee from retaining the services of his or her own attorney, but, except as otherwise provided in Section 2.52.090, the fees and costs of those services shall be borne solely by the employee. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.050 - Payment of judgments and settlements of claims against City employees. 
    The City shall be liable for the payment of all judgments and settlements of claims against a City employee under the circumstances specified in Section 2.52.030 (A) through (E), but only if sovereign immunity would not bar the action against the City. However, if such immunity would otherwise bar the action against the City, the City shall still remain responsible, pursuant to this section, to pay any judgment or settlement of a claim against an employee where the action arose out of the employee's operation of an emergency vehicle and the employee was operating the vehicle within the provisions of Section 42-4-106(2) and (3), C.R.S. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.060 - Employee responsibility. 
A.  Any employee involved in an incident or occurrence in which any person may have been injured or any physical damage to property may have occurred as a result of an act or omission of the employee occurring during the performance of the employee's duties, shall, as soon as practicable but in any event within seventy-two (72) hours following the incident or occurrence, notify or have a supervisor notify the City Council, through the City Attorney, of the incident or occurrence. 
B.  If a civil action is filed against a City employee and the action contains any claim of injury to a person or to property from an act or omission of the employee occurring during the performance of the employee's duties or within the scope of the employee's employment with the City, the employee or the employee's supervisor shall provide written notice to the City Council, through the City Attorney, of the existence of the civil action within fifteen (15) days after the commencement of the action. The employee or the employee's supervisor shall promptly transmit to the City Council, through the City Attorney, a copy of the complaint served on the employee. 
C.  The employee shall not compromise or settle any claim unless the City Council has notified the employee in writing that the City will not bear the cost of the legal defense of a civil action against the employee. If an employee violates this provision, the City will not be responsible for payment of the employee's costs, attorney fees, judgments or settled claims. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.070 - Notification to employee. 
A.  Within a reasonable time after receipt by the City Council of any written notice provided pursuant to Section 2.52.060, the City Attorney shall notify the employee in writing whether the City will assume the defense of the employee. 
B.  If the City is made co-defendant with an employee in a civil action, the City Attorney shall notify the employee in writing within a reasonable time after the commencement of the action whether the City will assume the defense of the employee. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995).
