2.52.080 - Reimbursement of expenses. 
    If a defense is provided pursuant to this policy in an action filed against an employee and the trial court determines that the injuries did not arise out of an act or omission of the employee occurring during the performance of the employee's duties and within the scope of the employee's employment, or that the act or omission of the employee was willful and wanton, the employee shall reimburse the City for reasonable costs and reasonable attorney's fees incurred in the defense of the employee. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.090 - Conflicts of interest. 
    In the event that an attorney who represents both the City and the employee pursuant to Section 2.52.040 determines that representation of both would create a conflict of interest, separate counsel shall be appointed pursuant to Section 2.52.040 for each party. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.100 - Reimbursement of punitive damages. 
    The City is not liable for punitive damages which are awarded against an employee nor is the City required to defend an employee against a claim for punitive damages, unless the City Council, in its sole discretion, determines otherwise pursuant to the procedure set forth in Section 24-10-118(5), C.R.S., as amended. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
2.52.110 - Severability clause. 
    If any section or sections of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect other sections of this chapter, or their application, if they can be given effect without the invalid section or sections, and to such extent the sections of this chapter are declared severable. 
(Ord. 6-95 (part), 1995). 
Title 3 - REVENUE AND FINANCE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 3.04 - FISCAL YEAR* 
Sections: 

3.04.010 - Fiscal year designated. 
    The fiscal year for the City of Florence shall correspond with the calendar year, each beginning with the first day of January of each year. 
(Ord. 339 § 1, 1932). 
Chapter 3.08 - SALES TAX 
Sections: 

3.08.010 - Purpose and statutory authority. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to impose a sales tax on the sale of the tangible personal property at retail, or the furnishing of services as provided in Article 2, Title 29, and Article 26, Title 39, Colorado Revised Statutes, 1973, as amended, upon every retailer in the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 1, 1978). 
3.08.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, words contained in this chapter shall be defined in Section 102, Article 26, Title 39, Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended, and such definitions are incorporated herein by this reference. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 2, 1978). 
3.08.030 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person or legal entity to engage in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail within the incorporated City without first having obtained a license therefor. Such license shall be granted and issued by the City Clerk and shall be in force and effect until the thirty-first (31st) day of December of the year in which it is issued, unless sooner revoked. The initial license for persons engaged in business (as defined in Section 3.08.020) on January 1, 1978, shall be obtained prior to January 1, 1978. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 3-1, 1978). 
3.08.040 - Application for license. 
    Such license shall be granted and renewed only upon application stating the name and address of the person desiring such a license, the name of such business and the location and such other facts as the City Clerk may require. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 3-2, 1978). 
3.08.050 - Renewal of license. 
    It shall be the duty of each licensee on or before January first (1st) of each year during which this chapter remains in effect to obtain a renewal thereof if the licensee remains in the retail business or liable to account for the tax herein provided; nothing herein contained shall be construed to empower the City Clerk to refuse such renewal except revocation for cause of the licensee's prior license. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 3-3, 1978). 
3.08.060 - Separate license required for each place of business. 
    In case business is transacted at one or more separate premises, by one person, a separate license for each place of business shall be required. 
(Ord. l-78 § 3-4, 1978). 
3.08.070 - Selling without license deemed violation. 
    Any person engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in the City of Florence, without having secured a license therefor, except as specifically provided herein, shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 3-5, 1978). 
3.08.080 - Contents of license. 
    Each license shall be numbered and shall show the name, residence, place and character of business of the licensee and shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the place of business for which it is issued. No license shall be transferable. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 3-6, 1978). 
3.08.090 - Certain commodities deemed exempt. 
    No license shall be required for any person engaged exclusively in the business of selling commodities which are exempt from taxation under this Ordinance. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 3-7, 1978). 
3.08.100 - Statutes adopted by reference. 
    For the purpose of collection, administration and enforcement of this chapter by the Director of Revenue, the provisions of Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended, Section 39-26-114 (exemptions, disputes, credits or refunds), shall be deemed applicable and incorporated into this chapter. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 4-1, 1978). 
3.08.110 - Amount not to include State Sales and Use Tax. 
    The amount subject to tax under this chapter shall not include the State Sales and Use Tax imposed by Article 26, Title 39, Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 4-2, 1978). 
3.08.120 - Consummation of sales. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, all retail sales shall be considered consummated at the place of business of the retailer, unless the tangible personal property sold is delivered by the retailer or his agent to a destination outside the City of Florence or to a common carrier for delivery to a destination outside the limits of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 4-3, 1978). 
3.08.130 - Gross receipts to include delivery charges. 
    The gross receipts from sales shall include delivery charges, when such charges are subject to the State Sales and Use Tax imposed by Article 26, Title 39, Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended, regardless of the places to which delivery is made. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 4-4, l978). 
3.08.140 - Retailer with no permanent place of business-Consummation of sales. 
    In the event a retailer has no permanent place of business in the City of Florence, or more than one place of business, the place or places at which the retail sales are consummated for the purpose of this sales tax shall be determined by the provisions of Article 26 of Title 39, Colorado Revised Statues 1973, as amended, and by the rules and regulations promulgated by the Department of Revenue. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 4-5, 1978). 
3.08.150 - Building materials-Exempt from sales tax when.* 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the value of construction and building materials on which a use tax has previously been collected by the City of Florence shall be exempt from the City sales tax if the materials are delivered by the retailer or his agent to a site within the limits of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 4-6, 1978). 
* For provisions on the building materials use tax, see Ch. 3.16 of this code. 
3.08.160 - Ownership taxable items deemed exempt. 
    All sales of personal property on which a specific ownership tax has been paid or is payable shall be exempt from the City sales tax when such sales meet both of the following conditions: 
A.  The purchaser is a nonresident of, or has its principal place of business outside, the City of Florence; and 
B.  Such personal property is registered or required to be registered outside the limits of the City of Florence under laws of the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 4-7, 1978). 
3.08.170 - Tax imposed-Rate. 
    There is imposed on all sales of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services as provided in Article 26, Title 39, Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended, a tax equal to two and one-half (2 1/2) percent of the gross receipts. The tangible personal property and services taxable by this chapter shall be the same as the tangible personal property and services taxable pursuant to Article 26, Title 39, Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended. The imposition of the tax on individual sales shall be in accordance with schedules set forth in the rules and regulations promulgated by the Department of Revenue or by separate ordinance of the City of Florence. If any vendor, during any reporting period, shall collect as a tax an amount in excess of two and one-half (2 1/2) percent of its total taxable sales, it shall remit to the Director of Revenue the full amount of the tax herein imposed and also such excess. 
(Ord. 19-2005 § 1, 2005: Ord. 1-78 § 5-1, 1978). 
3.08.172 - Contributions. 
    The revenue raised from one-half (1/2) percent of the sales and use tax authorized for collection under Section 3.08.170 of this chapter on and after January 1, 2016, shall be set aside and dedicated to the construction, reconstruction, repair and maintenance of streets and all other public rights-of-way within the corporate limits of the City of Florence. The City Finance Officer is directed to take appropriate bookkeeping measures to ensure such funds collected are shown to be dedicated for such purposes. 
(Ord. 19-2005 § 2, 2005). 
(Ord. No. 9-2015, § 1, 12-21-2015). 
3.08.174 - Sunset. 
    The one-half percent sales and use tax provided for in Section 3.08.172 shall sunset and expire on December 31, 2025, and upon said date the sales and use tax shall revert to two (2) percent on all sales of tangible personal property and services as provided at Section 3.08.170 and Article 26, Title 39, C.R.S., as amended. 
(Ord. 19-2005 § 3, 2005). 
(Ord. No. 9-2015, § 2, 12-21-2015). 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9-2015, adopted Dec. 21, 2015, repealed and reenacted § 3.08.174 to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 3.08.174 pertained to tax increase and derived from Ord. No. 19-2005, 2005. 
3.08.180 - Collection, administration and enforcement. 
    The collection, administration and enforcement of this sales tax shall be performed by the Director of Revenue of the State of Colorado in the same manner as the collection, administration and enforcement of the Colorado State Sales Tax. The provisions of Article 26, Title 39, Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended hereafter, and all rules and regulations promulgated by the Director of Revenue shall govern the collections, administration and enforcement of the Sales tax imposed by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 5-2, 1978). 
3.08.190 - Deduction for vendor's expenses. 
    Each and every retailer or vendor responsible hereunder for the collection and remittance of said tax on sales of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services as herein provided is authorized to deduct three and one-third percent (3- 1/3 %) of the sum so remitted to cover the vendor's expenses in the collection and remittance of said tax; but, if any vendor is delinquent in remitting said tax, other than in unusual circumstances shown to the satisfaction of the Executive Director of the Department of Revenue, the vendor shall not be allowed to retain any amounts to cover his expenses in the collection and remittance of said tax. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 5-3, 1978). 
3.08.200 - Amendments. 
    The City Council may amend, alter or change the ordinance codified in this chapter, except as to the two percent (2%) rate of tax herein imposed, subsequent to adoption by a majority vote of the City Council. Such amendment, alteration or change need not be submitted to the electors of the City of Florence for their approval. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 6-2, 1978). 
3.08.210 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 1-78 § 7, 1978). 
Chapter 3.12 - TELEPHONE UTILITY TAX[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
 For statutory provisions authorizing cities to tax any lawful occupation or business place, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-501(c) (1975 Supp.) 

3.12.010 - Tax levied. 
    There is levied on and against each telephone utility company operating within the City of Florence, (hereinafter called the "City") a tax on the occupation and business of maintaining a telephone exchange and lines connected therewith in the City of Florence and of supplying local exchange telephone service to the inhabitants of the City. The annual amount of tax levied hereby shall be equal to thirty-five cents ($0.35) per telephone account per month for which local exchange telephone service is provided within the corporate limits of the City of Florence on the effective date as provided in Section 3.12.020 and upon each anniversary of the effective date. 
(Ord. 585 § 1, 1976). 
3.12.020 - Due date-Effective date. 
    The tax levied by this chapter shall commence on October 1, 1976, and shall be due and payable in twelve (12) equal monthly installments with the first such installment due thirty (30) days after the effective date. 
(Ord. 585 § 2, 1976). 
3.12.030 - Filing statement. 
    Within thirty (30) days after the effective date as provided in Section 3.12.030, each telephone utility company subject to this chapter shall file with the City Clerk, in such form as the Clerk may require, a statement showing the total telephone accounts for which local exchange telephone service was provided within the corporate limits of the City on the effective date. Such statement shall be filed within thirty (30) days after each anniversary of the effective date showing such accounts on the anniversary date. 
(Ord. 585 § 3, 1976). 
3.12.040 - Inspection of records. 
    The City, its officers, agents or representatives shall have the right at all reasonable hours and times to examine the books and records of the telephone utility company which are subject to the provisions of this chapter and to make copies of the entries or contents thereof. 
(Ord. 585 § 6, 1976). 
3.12.050 - Tax in lieu of other taxes. 
    The tax herein provided shall be in lieu of all other payments by or fees and taxes on any telephone utility subject to the provisions of this chapter, other than ad valorem taxes, and in addition shall be in lieu of any free service furnished the City by any telephone utility. 
(Ord. 585 § 9, 1976). 
3.12.060 - Local purpose. 
    The tax provided in this chapter is upon occupations and businesses in the performance of local functions and is not a tax upon those functions relating to interstate commerce. It is expressly understood that none of the terms of this chapter shall be construed to mean that any telephone utility company is issued a franchise by the City. (Ord, 585 § 7, 1976). 
3.12.070 - Failure to pay. 
    If any telephone utility company subject to the provisions of this chapter fails to pay the taxes as herein provided, the full amount thereof shall be due and collected from such company, and the same together with an additional ten percent (10%) of the amount of taxes due shall be and is declared to be a debt due and owing from such company to the City. The City Attorney upon direction of the City Council shall commence and prosecute to final judgment and determination in any court of competent jurisdiction an action at law to collect the debt in the name of the people of the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. 585 § 4, 1976). 
Chapter 3.16 - BUILDING MATERIALS AND MOTOR VEHICLE USE TAX 
Sections: 

3.16.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the words herein contained shall be defined in Section 39-26-201 Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, and said definitions are incorporated herein by this reference. The word "City" shall be deemed to mean the City of Florence, Colorado, and the term "tangible personal property" shall be deemed to mean building and construction materials and motor vehicles. 
(Ord. 599 § 1, 1977). 
3.16.020 - Exemptions. 
    In no event shall the use tax imposed by this chapter extend or apply: 
A.  To the storage, use or consumption of any tangible personal property, the sale of which is subject to the retail sales tax imposed by Chapter 3.08 of this code; 
B.  To the storage, use or consumption of any tangible personal property purchased for resale in the City, either in its original form or as an ingredient of a manufactured or compounded product, in the regular course of a business; 
C.  To the storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property brought into the City by a nonresident thereof for his own storage, use or consumption while temporarily within the City; however, this exemption does not apply to the storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property brought into this State by a nonresident to be used in the conduct of a business in this State; 
D.  To the storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property by the United States Government, or the State of Colorado, or its institutions, or its political subdivisions in their governmental capacities only, or by religious or charitable corporations in the conduct of their regular religious or charitable functions; 
E.  To the storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property by a person engaged in the business of manufacturing or compounding for sale, profit or use any article, substance, or commodity, which tangible personal property enters into the processing of or becomes an ingredient or component part of the product or service which is manufactured, compounded or furnished and the container, label or the furnished shipping case thereof; 
F.  To the storage, use or consumption of any article of tangible personal property, the sale or use of which has already been subjected to a sales or use tax of another county, city or town equal to or in excess of that imposed by this chapter. A credit shall be granted against the use tax imposed by this chapter with respect to a person's storage, use or consumption in the City of tangible personal property purchased by him elsewhere. The amount of the credit shall be equal to the tax paid by him by reason of the imposition of a sales tax or use tax of another county, city or town on his purchase or use of the property. The amount of the credit shall not exceed the tax imposed by this chapter; 
G.  To the storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property and household effects acquired outside the City and brought into it by a nonresident acquiring residency; 
H.  To the storage or use of a motor vehicle if the owner is or was, at the time of the purchase, a nonresident of the City and he purchased the vehicle outside of the City for use outside the City and actually so used it for a substantial and primary purpose for which it was acquired and he registered, titled and licensed said motor vehicle outside of the City; 
I.  To the storage, use or consumption of any construction and building materials and motor and other vehicles on which registration is required if a written contract for the purchase thereof was entered into prior to the effective date of such use tax; 
J.  To the storage, use or consumption of any construction and building materials required or made necessary in the performance of any construction contract bid, let, or entered into at any time prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. 599 § 2, 1977). 
3.16.030 - Building and construction use tax. 
A.  There is imposed on the privilege of storing, using or consuming any construction and building material of every kind and form purchased outside the City, for use, storage or consumption within the City of Florence, a use tax of two percent (2%) of the retail purchase price of said construction or building materials. 
B.  The use tax based upon the retail price of construction or building material shall be paid to the City Clerk by every applicant for a City building permit. The applicant may elect to pay a deposit against the amount ultimately determined to be the use tax owed by the applicant for the project for which the application is sought. Such deposit shall equal the tax imposed by subsection A of this section, multiplied by one-half of the total cost of the project (which fifty percent (50%) of the project cost as determined by the building inspector shall be deemed the cost of the construction and building material) and said amount shall be indicated on the application for the building permit and shall be evidenced by the issuance of a building permit by the City building inspector. 
C.  Should either the building permit applicant or the City feel that the deposit provided for in subsection B of this section does not accurately reflect the actual amount of the use tax owed by the applicant when the calculation of the use tax shall be made based upon an affidavit which shall be submitted to the City Clerk sworn to by the building permit applicant and supported by adequate documentation to verify the amount of tax owed. The building permit applicant shall be required to maintain and preserve detailed receipts and purchase records which shall be subject to inspection and audit by the City Clerk, or his authorized designee. Taxes due shall be subject to collection, prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or prior to final inspection if a certificate of occupancy is not required. 
D.  The administration of the ordinance codified in this section is vested in and shall be exercised by the City Clerk who shall prescribe forms and reasonable rules and regulations in conformity with the ordinance codified in this section for the making of returns, for the ascertainment, assessment and collection of the taxes imposed under the ordinance codified in this section and for the proper administration and enforcement of the ordinance codified in this section. 
E.  Any person, firm or corporation who knowingly files a false report regarding the purchase of or payment of taxes on the purchase of building and construction materials shall, upon conviction of such offense, be punished as provided in Chapter 1.12. 
(Ord. 10.84 § 1, 1984; Ord. 599 § 3, 1977). 
3.16.040 - Motor vehicle use tax. 
A.  There is imposed upon the privilege of using or storing any motor vehicle purchased outside the City by any resident of the City for the purpose of use or storage within the City, a use tax in the amount of two percent (2%) of the retail purchase price of said motor vehicle. 
B.  The use tax shall be applicable to every motor vehicle for which registration is required by the laws of the State of Colorado. 
C.  No registration shall be made of any motor vehicle for which registration is required, and no certificate of title shall be issued for such vehicle by the Department of Revenue or its authorized agents until any tax due upon the use or storage thereof pursuant to this chapter has been paid. 
D.  The use tax imposed by this section shall be collected by the authorized agent of the Department of Revenue in any county in the State of Colorado where such vehicle is registered. 
E.  The proceeds of the use tax shall be paid to the City periodically in accordance with an agreement entered into between the City of Florence and the authorized agent of the Department of Revenue of the State of Colorado. 
F.  The City Clerk and the Mayor are empowered to enter into and execute on behalf of the City of Florence any agreements necessary for the administration and enforcement of this chapter in accordance with the laws of the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. 599 § 4, 1977). 
Chapter 3.20 - CONTINGENCY FUND 
Sections: 

3.20.010 - Created-Appropriations-Expenditures. 
    There is expressly created a contingency fund for the City of Florence pursuant to the provisions of Colorado Revised Statutes, 1973, as amended, Title 29, Article 1, Section 111. Before the beginning of the fiscal year, the City Council may enact an ordinance or resolution making appropriations to the contingency fund. Expenditures from the contingency fund shall be permissible only in cases of emergency. 
(Ord. 10-80 § 1, 1980). 
3.20.020 - Emergency defined. 
    For the purpose of this chapter an "emergency" is defined as an unforeseen event or series of events which requires immediate action or remedy or expenditure of municipal funds. An "unforeseen event or series of events" is defined as a contingency which could not have been reasonably foreseen at the time of adoption of the fiscal municipal budget. 
(Ord. 10-80 § 2, 1980). 
Chapter 3.24 - EQUIPMENT REPLACEMENT FUND 
Sections: 

3.24.010 - Created. 
    There is created an equipment replacement fund for the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 2-81 § 1, 1981). 
3.24.020 - Deposits. 
    All revenues received by the City from the severance tax direct payment program of the Mineral Severance Tax Law of the State of Colorado shall be deposited into the equipment replacement fund of the City. In addition, the City Council may specify in the City budget that municipal general revenues be deposited into the equipment replacement fund. 
(Ord. 2-81 § 2, 1981). 
3.24.030 - Administration. 
    The City Clerk, as the ex officio City Treasurer, shall manage and administer the equipment replacement fund. Records of account pertaining to the equipment replacement fund shall be kept separate and distinct from other municipal finances. The City Clerk shall, in his discretion, invest the assets of the equipment replacement fund pursuant to Colorado Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 2-81 § 3, 1981). 
3.24.040 - Expenditures. 
    Revenues of the equipment replacement fund shall be used for the sole purpose of purchasing machinery or equipment for the City to be used for municipal purposes upon the affirmative vote of the majority of the City Council. 
(Ord. 2-81 § 4, 1981). 
Chapter 3.28 - DELINQUENT DEBTS 
Sections: 

3.28.010 - Statutory authority. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is authorized pursuant to the provisions of Section 31-20-105, CRS 1973, as amended. 
(Ord 6-81 § 2, 1981). 
3.28.020 - Certification for collection. 
    The City, in addition to any other means provided by law, may cause any or all delinquent municipal charges, assessments or taxes made or levied by the City to be certified to the Treasurer of Fremont County to be collected and paid over by the Fremont County Treasurer in the same manner as general property taxes are collected. 
(Ord 6-81 § 1, 1981). 
Chapter 3.30 - DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY 
Sections: 

3.30.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property which is in the possession of or under the control of the municipality. 
(Ord. l8-92(part), 1992). 
3.30.020 - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise required by context or use, words and terms shall be defined as follows: 
    "Municipality" means the city of Florence, Colorado. 
    "Owner" means a person or entity, including a corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity other than this municipality, or a duly authorized legal representative or successor in interest of same, which owns unclaimed property held by the municipality. 
    "Unclaimed property" means any tangible or intangible property, including any income or increment derived therefrom, less any lawful charges, that is held by or under the control of the municipality and which has not been claimed by its owner for a period of more than five years after it became payable or distributable. 
(Ord. 18-92 (part), 1992). 
3.30.030 - Procedure for notification of owner. 
A.  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of fifty dollars ($50.00) or more, the City Manager shall send a written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address, if any, of any owner of unclaimed property. The last known address of the owner shall be the last address of the owner as shown by the records of the municipal department or agency holding the property. The notice shall include a description of the property, the amount or estimated value of the property, and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held, and designating a place and time for the public sale of said property, if a sale is necessary. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the City Manager with a written claim for the return of the property prior to the time fixed in said notice for the public sale of said property, or within sixty (60) days of the date of the notice if a sale is not necessary, the property shall become the sole property of the municipality and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
B.  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or having no last known address of the owner, the City Manager shall cause a notice to be published one time in the municipality's official newspaper. The notice shall include a description of the property, the presumed owner of the property, if known, the amount or estimated value of the property and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held, and designating a place and time for the public sale of said property, if a sale is necessary. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the City Manager with a written claim for the return of the property prior to the time fixed in said notice for the public sale of said property, or within sixty (60) days of the date of the publication of the notice if a sale is not necessary, the property shall become the sole property of the municipality and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(Ord. 18-92 (part), 1992). 
3.30.040 - Delivery to owner. 
A.  In case any property shall come into the custody of the City and be claimed by any person as provided in Section 3.30.030 above, it shall be the duty of the City Manager to make such inquiry and examination as to the ownership of the property as he or she may deem necessary, and if he or she is satisfied that the property belongs to the person claiming the same, he or she is authorized to release the property to such owner upon the owner giving a proper receipt therefor 
B.  In the event that there is more than one claimant for the same property, the City Manager may, in the City Manager's sole discretion, resolve said claims, or may resolve such claims by depositing the disputed property with the registry of the District Court in an interpleader action. 
C.  Any legal action filed challenging a decision of the City Manager shall be filed pursuant to Rule 106 of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure within thirty (30) days of such decision or shall be forever barred. If any legal action is timely filed, the property shall be disbursed by the City Manager pursuant to the order of the Court having jurisdiction over such claim. 
D.  No property subject to return shall be released to any owner until the municipality has been reimbursed for all reasonable expenses of custody and handling thereof, including costs of mailing and publication. 
(Ord. 18-92(part), 1992). 
3.30.050 - Sale of property. 
    In general, if property in the possession of the municipality is not claimed by the rightful owner as provided in Section 3.30.030 hereof, the property shall be sold at public sale at the time and place mentioned in the notice. It shall be the duty of the City Manager to sell all such unclaimed property for the highest and best price the same will bring in cash, to receive from the purchaser of each and every article the amount paid by such purchaser for the same, and to deliver the article, together with a bill of sale for the same, to the purchaser. 
(Ord. 18-92(part), 1992). 
3.30.060 - Report of sale and disposition of proceeds. 
    The City Manager shall from time to time make reports to the City Council as he or she deems necessary of sales provided for in this chapter. Such reports shall give a description of articles sold and the amount of money received for the articles, which money shall be placed in the general fund of the municipality. 
(Ord. l8-92(part), 1992). 
3.30.070 - Disposition of unsold property. 
    The City Manager is authorized to dispose of any and all property not sold at a public sale conducted as provided in this chapter, at any time thereafter, at his or her discretion, any proceeds derived therefrom to be placed in the general fund of the City. 
(Ord. 18-92(part), 1992). 
3.30.080 - Disposition of property with minimal value. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the contrary, certain items of property having a minimal value which are not suitable for sale in the discretion of the City Manager, and which can be used for the public's benefit may be donated to a recognized charitable institution, if directed by the City Manager, without having to comply with the provisions of this chapter. Such items may include, but are not necessarily limited to: toys, clothing, bedding and personal care items. 
(Ord. 18-92 (part), 1992). 
3.30.090 - Disposition of unclaimed intangible property. 
    All intangible property subject to disposition under this chapter which is held in any fund of the municipality at the time such property becomes the property of the municipality under Section 3.30.120 hereof, shall be distributed to such fund. All other intangible property held by the municipality which is subject to disposition under this chapter shall be distributed to the general fund. 
(Ord. 18-92 (part), 1992). 
3.30.100 - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to: the sale of abandoned automobile as governed by Title 42, CRS (1973 as amended); the disposition of lost or stray animals as governed by Title 35, CRS (1973 as amended); the disposition of property seized, confiscated or forfeited by a municipal seizing agency governed by Title 16 and Title 18, CRS (1973 as amended). 
(Ord. 18-92 (part), 1992). 
3.30.110 - Failure to claim property. 
    Failure to timely make claim of ownership within the time prescribed in Section 3.30.030 hereof shall forever bar the owner, or any person claiming ownership by, through, or under the owner, from any property rights in the property in issue. 
(Ord. 18-92 (part), 1992). 
3.30.120 - Escheat. 
    If no person establishes a right to any property as required under Sections 3.30.030 and 3.30.040, the property shall escheat to the municipality and the owner or any person who alleges that he or she is entitled to the property shall be forever barred from any and all claim or right to such property or the proceeds of sale therefrom. 
(Ord. 18-92 (part), 1992). 
3.30.130 - Severability. 
    If any part, section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of the ordinance codified in this chapter, is for any reason held to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the validity of the remaining sections of this ordinance. The City Council declares that it would have passed the ordinance codified in this chapter, including each part, section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase hereof, irrespective of the fact that one or more parts, sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases may be declared invalid. 
(Ord. 18-92 (part), 1992). 
Chapter 3.32 - CHECKS AND WARRANTS 
Sections: 

3.32.010 - Payment of municipal charges. 
    Warrants and checks issued for the payment of municipal charges shall be signed and disbursed only after prior approval by the Florence City Council at any regular or special council meeting. 
(Ord. 15-82 § 1, 1982). 
3.32.020 - Checks and warrants. 
    All checks and warrants drawn upon the various accounts of the City Treasurer shall be signed by the Mayor and countersigned by the City Clerk as ex officio City Treasurer and shall state the particular fund or appropriation from which the same is chargeable and the person to whom payable. Disbursement may be made by check in lieu of warrant. In the event that the Mayor is unavailable to sign municipal checks and warrants then any other City Councilmember may sign in his stead as Mayor. 
(Ord. 15-82 § 2, 1982). 
Chapter 3.34 - SEIZURE/FORFEITURE FUND 
Sections: 

3.34.010 - Establishment. 
    There is established for the convenience and proper administration of the affairs of the City a fund of the City, which shall be known as the "seizure/forfeiture fund." 
(Ord. 13-97 § 1(part), 1997). 
3.34.020 - Composition. 
    The seizure/forfeiture fund shall consist of such sums of money that are delivered to and received by, or on behalf of, the Florence Police Department with respect to law enforcement activities that resulted in the seizure or forfeiture of real or personal property pursuant to applicable federal or state laws. The moneys to be deposited in this fund may include, without limitation, any sums payable to and received by, or on behalf of, the Florence Police Department, as a seizing agency, from State of Colorado sources identified at Parts 3 and 5 of Title 16, Article 13, CRS; or from federal sources pursuant to federal laws, rules, and regulations, the receipt, use, and disposition of which are authorized by Section 16-13-601, CRS. 
(Ord. 13-97 § 1(part), 1997). 
3.34.030 - Special provisions. 
A.  The seizure/forfeiture fund is designated as the lawfully created fund to receive proceeds from property seized by and/or forfeited to the federal or state government and allocated to the Florence Police Department pursuant to federal or state laws and regulations. 
B.  For accounting purposes, the seizure/forfeiture fund shall be treated as a special reserve account which will have two (2) divisions. One (1) such division shall receive proceeds from property seized by and/or forfeited to the federal government and allocated by an agency or officer of the Unites States Government; and the other division shall receive proceeds from property seized by and/or forfeited to the State of Colorado pursuant to state law. The assets of each division shall not be commingled. 
C.  All seized and/or forfeited property and all proceeds from seized and/or forfeited property received by or on behalf of the Florence Police Department shall be subject to the reporting and audit requirements set forth at Section 16-31-701, CRS. 
D.  All such seized and/or forfeited property and all proceeds from seized and/or forfeited property received by or on behalf of the Florence Police Department shall be used and expended only as approved and authorized by the committee on disposition required under Section 16-13-702, CRS, and established by the further provisions of this chapter. No expenditure shall be authorized except by a majority vote of all of the members of the committee. A written memorandum regarding each expenditure authorized by the committee shall be made and shall reflect the vote of each committee member. 
E.  Pursuant to Section 16-13-702(3), CRS, the committee on disposition for the Florence Police Department shall, at a minimum, be required to be comprised of the District Attorney of the Eleventh Judicial District or his designee, the Chief of Police of the City of Florence or his designee, and the Mayor of the City of Florence. Additional members may be selected to serve on the committee by the unanimous agreement of the required members, pursuant to Section 16-13-702(3), CRS. The committee is specifically authorized to establish and maintain one (1) or more bank accounts to be used for law enforcement purposes designated by the committee and to deposit into such account or accounts assets of the seizure/forfeiture fund. 
F.  In accordance with applicable federal and state laws, moneys in the seizure/forfeiture fund shall not be subject to appropriation by the City Council of the City of Florence, nor shall such moneys be used or expended for any purpose that is prohibited by applicable federal or state laws or for any permitted purpose that is not specifically authorized by the committee. 
G.  Any interest or other revenue generated on account of investment of moneys in the seizure/forfeiture fund shall remain in the fund. 
(Ord. 13-97 § 1(part), 1997). 
Chapter 3.36 - CAPITAL ACQUISITION AND IMPROVEMENT FUND 
Sections: 

3.36.010 - Capital acquisition and improvement fund created. 
    There is created a capital acquisition and improvement fund for the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 8-87 § 1, 1987). 
3.36.020 - Contributions. 
    All revenues received by the City of Florence by virtue of the mining lease between the City of Florence and Energy Fuels Associated, Limited, dated February 1, 1986, all revenues derived from earnings from investment of funds within the capital acquisition and improvement fund, together with any other funds appropriated by the City to such fund shall be placed in a capital acquisition and improvement fund. Any portion of said fund remaining unexpended at the end of a budget year shall not be converted into the general fund but shall remain in this fund described herein. 
(Ord. 8-87 § 2, 1987). 
3.36.030 - Administration. 
    The City Clerk as the ex officio City Treasurer shall manage and administer the capital improvement and acquisition fund. Records of account pertaining to the capital improvement and acquisition fund shall be kept separate and distinct from other municipal finances. The City Clerk shall in his discretion invest the assets of the capital improvement and acquisition fund in the manner allowed by the Colorado Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 8-87 § 3, 1987). 
3.36.040 - Expenditures. 
    Moneys in the capital improvement and acquisition fund shall be used for the sole purpose of providing funding for the purpose of acquiring, constructing or improving any land, building, structure or other capital asset of the City, or for retiring any bonded indebtedness created for these purposes, or to use as matching funds when so required by any grant awarded to the City for the purposes set forth herein, upon the affirmative vote of a majority of City Council. Any authorization for expenditure from said fund shall be accompanied by a proposed method for repayment within a reasonable time of moneys expended from said fund, it being the intent of the city council that such fund not be depleted. 
(Ord. 8-87 § 4, 1987). 
Chapter 3.38 - GENERAL RESERVE FUND 
Sections: 

3.38.010 - Establishment. 
    There is established for the City of Florence, consistent with the provisions of Amendment 1 to the Colorado Constitution as approved by the voters of the State in November, 1992, a general reserve fund, to which moneys may be designated from time to time by legislative action of the City Council. 
(Ord. 32-92 § 1(part), 1992). 
3.38.020 - Allocations generally. 
    Moneys designated to the general reserve fund will generally be from any and all unallocated year-end fund balances, and such designation will constitute a "reserve increase" as that term is employed in Amendment 1, and will therefore this year be a part of the 1992 "fiscal year spending" within the meaning of Article X, Section 20(2)(e) of the Colorado Constitution. 
(Ord. 33-92 § 1(part), 1992). 
3.38.030 - 1992 allocation. 
    Any and all unallocated year-end fund balances for year 1992 are designated for the general reserve fund. 
(Ord. 33-92 § 1(part), 1992). 
3.38.040 - Necessary clause. 
    Pursuant to C.R.S. 31-16-105 (1973 as amended) the City Council declares that it is necessary to the immediate preservation of the public health and safety that the ordinance codified in this chapter take effect before thirty (30) days from publication after second reading, and shall take effect immediately upon said publication, in order to preserve maximum budgetary flexibility to serve the citizens of Florence after year 1992, while at the same time abiding by the spirit and letter of Amendment 1. 
(Ord. 33-92 § 1(part), 1992). 
Chapter 3.40 - EMERGENCY RESERVE FUND 
Sections: 

3.40.010 - Emergency reserve fund established. 
    An emergency reserve fund for the City of Florence is established in accordance with Article X, Section 20 of the Colorado Constitution to be used only for declared emergencies consistent with the Colorado Constitution. 
(Ord. 30-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
3.40.020 - Allocations generally. 
    Moneys designated for the emergency reserve fund generally will be based upon a certain percentage of fiscal year spending by the City of Florence for any given fiscal year in accordance with Article X, Section 20 of the Colorado Constitution. 
(Ord. 30-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
3.40.030 - 1993 allocation. 
    The allocation to the emergency reserve fund for fiscal year 1993 shall be one percent (1%) of fiscal year 1993 spending by the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 30-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
3.40.040 - Future allocations. 
    Future fiscal year allocations to the emergency reserve fund may be made by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. 30-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
3.40.050 - Necessary clause. 
    Pursuant to C.R.S. 31-16-105 (as amended), the City Council of the City of Florence declares that it is necessary to the immediate preservation of the public health and safety that the ordinance codified in this chapter take effect immediately upon publication after second reading in order to preserve budgetary flexibility and integrity and to abide by the law and spirit of the Colorado Constitution. 
(Ord. 30-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
Chapter 3.42 - PERPETUAL CARE RESERVE FUND 
Sections: 

3.42.010 - Perpetual care reserve fund created. 
    There is created the perpetual care reserve fund for the City of Florence. The purpose of this reserve fund is to set aside certain moneys to be used for the operations and maintenance of the cemetery at such time as there is no longer revenue derived from the sale of grave spaces. 
(Ord. 5-2000 § 1(part), 2000). 
3.42.020 - Contributions. 
    Contributions to the perpetual care reserve fund are derived from a percentage of all revenue collected from the sale of grave spaces and all other fees and charges connected to the operation of the cemetery. The percentage of revenue shall be as established by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. 5-2000 § 1(part), 2000). 
3.42.030 - Administration. 
    The City Clerk as the ex-officio City Treasurer shall manage and administer the perpetual care reserve fund. Records of the account pertaining to the perpetual care reserve fund shall be kept separate and distinct from other municipal finances. The City Clerk shall, in his or her discretion, invest the assets of the perpetual care reserve fund in a manner allowed by Colorado Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 5-2000 § 1(part), 2000). 
3.42.040 - Expenditures. 
    The perpetual care reserve fund shall be a restricted account and shall require an affirmative vote of the majority of the City Council to be expended for any purpose that solely benefits the cemetery. 
(Ord. 5-2000 § 1(part), 2000). 
Chapter 3.44 - CEMETERY EQUIPMENT AND PROJECT FUND 
Sections: 

3.44.010 - Cemetery equipment and project fund. 
    There is created the cemetery equipment and project fund for the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 5-2000 § 2(part), 2000). 
3.44.020 - Contributions. 
    Contributions to the cemetery equipment and project fund are derived from a percentage of all the revenues collected from the sale of grave spaces and all other fees and charges connected to the operation of the cemetery beginning January 1, 2000. The percentage of revenues shall be as established by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. 5-2000 § 2(part), 2000). 
3.44.030 - Administration. 
    The City Clerk as the ex-officio City Treasurer shall manage and administer the cemetery equipment and project fund. Records of the account pertaining to the cemetery equipment and project fund shall be kept separate and distinct from other municipal finances. The City Clerk shall, in his or her discretion, invest the assets of the cemetery equipment and project fund in a manner allowed by Colorado Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 5-2000 § 2(part), 2000). 
3.44.040 - Expenditures. 
    Revenues of the cemetery equipment and project fund shall be used solely for purchasing machinery and equipment for the cemetery and for funding capital construction projects within the cemetery. Expenditure of these funds shall require an affirmative vote of the majority of the City Council. 
(Ord. 5-2000 § 2(part), 2000). 
Chapter 3.48 - REBATE OF BUILDING PERMIT FEES 
Sections: 

3.48.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to simulate local economic growth through increased sales tax revenue and/or increased employment by attracting new private enterprise as well as encouraging the expansion of existing private enterprise through a percentage rebate of building permit fees as assessed under Section 15.04.050 of the Florence Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 18-2005 § 1(part), 2005). 
3.48.020 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows: 
    "Business owner" means a natural person, firm, association, partnership, trust, corporation, limited liability company, or other legal entity that carries on a commercial enterprise for profit, or a particular for-profit occupation or employment habitually engaged in for livelihood or gain. "Business owner" hereunder shall not include the owner of a home-based business. 
    "Capital investment costs" mean land acquisition costs as well as the gross cost of all structures, buildings, fixtures, fences, parking lots, and the like erected upon or affixed to the land, as determined by the City Manager. "Capital investment costs" by a business owner, shall not include land acquisition and other development costs of a project that is primarily for residential purposes as determined by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 18-2005 § 1(part), 2005). 
3.48.030 - Rebate. 
A.  A business owner shall be entitled to a rebate of forty-five (45) percent of the building permit fee actually paid pursuant to Section 15.04.050 of this code so long as the capital investment costs of the project, as defined at Section 3.48.020 of this chapter, exceed one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00), as determined by the City Manager. 
B.  Such rebate shall be paid to the business owner coincident with the issuance of a final certificate of occupancy as authorized by the City Manager. 
C.  The effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be January 1, 2006. 
(Ord. 18-2005 § 1(part), 2005). 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS[1] 
Chapters: 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
 For statutory provisions authorizing cities to tax, license and regulate businesses, see CRS § 31-15-501; for provisions regarding licenses for tree trimmers, see Ch. 12.28 of this code; for provisions on trailer park licenses, see Ch. 15.36 of this code. 

Chapter 5.02 - LICENSING OF BUSINESSES 

5.02.010 - Definitions. 
A.  "Business" means and includes each kind of vocation, occupation, profession, enterprise and establishment, or any and all other kind of activity and matter, any of which are conducted for private profit or benefit, either directly or indirectly, on any premises within the City or anywhere else within its jurisdiction, and shall also mean and include all devices, machines, vehicles, and appurtenances used therein. A business which does not make any sales, transactions, exchanges, trades, deliveries, or shipments of goods or services within the City is not subject to this definition and does not need a business license. 
B.  "Casual transaction" is an isolated, single, or incidental transaction, which in itself does not constitute the carrying on of business. Examples include but are not limited to: fund raisers; garage sales; bake sales; or, private sale of a vehicle. 
C.  "City" means the City of Florence, Colorado. 
D.  "Fixed business" is any business operating from a set operating location. Fixed business does not include a home occupation. 
E.  "License" means a business license. 
F.  "Licensee" is any person required to obtain a license. 
G.  "Home occupation" is any business operated from a residence. No home occupation shall be allowed on property zoned as Commercial, as the same is defined in the City Zoning Code. Examples of home occupations include, but are not limited to: licensed day care facilities; accountants; hairdressers; attorneys; and, seamstresses. 
H.  "Non-fixed business" is any established business not having a set operating location within the City, but which otherwise does business within the City. Examples of non-fixed businesses include, but are not limited to: wholesale and retail distributors; carpenters; construction trades; trash hauling; route sales; door-to-door sales; and paper delivery. 
I.  "Person" means and includes individual natural persons, partnerships, joint ventures, societies, associations, clubs, trustees, trusts, companies, or corporations, or any officers, agents, employees, factors, or any kind of personal representatives of any other person, under either personal appointment or pursuant to law. 
J.  "Premises" means and includes all lands, structures, and places, and the equipment and appurtenances connected or used therewith in any business, and also any personal property which is either affixed to, or is otherwise used in connection with any such business conducted on such premises. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.020 - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this article are: 
A.  To promote the economic growth and development of the City; 
B.  To provide for the general health, safety, and welfare of the City; 
C.  To require the annual licensing and appropriate regulation of all businesses conducted on premises within the City; and 
D.  To provide a uniform procedure for the issuance, administration, enforcement, and revocation of licenses issued by the City. To those ends, the provisions contained in this article shall be liberally construed in order that the true meaning and intent of this article may be carried out. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.030 - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commence or carry on any business within the City without having first obtained a license from the City. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or carry on a business under the license of another and no licensee shall allow or permit any other person to operate under the licensee's permit. 
A.  The City shall not issue this license unless the applicant (its constituents or members) are current with the City and all City enterprises for all fees, assessments, charges, taxes, or amount due of any type. 
B.  A City business license shall not be required by a person, company, or otherwise, who already possesses a valid City license, such as a contractor's license pursuant to Chapter 5.12, or those persons, companies, or others exempt from local licensing requirements by state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.040 - Separate premise or separate business requires license. 
    A separate license shall be obtained for each separate business in the City regardless of whether the business conducted is a separate business at the same locale or is a branch, division or agency of a licensee situated at another premise in the City. Each realtor licensed by the state and engaging in business in the City shall be required to obtain a business license. At the time of license application, the City Clerk shall determine how many business licenses are required of the licensee. A licensee may appeal the determination of the City Clerk to the City Council and their determination shall be final. A finding by the City Clerk of any one (1) of the following conditions shall be prima facie evidence that the licensee has more than one (1) business: 
A.  Separate physical locales; 
B.  Separate business activities in segregated portions of the same building; 
C.  Issuance of multiple sales tax licenses; 
D.  Issuance of multiple sign permits advertising businesses at the same locale; or 
E.  Separate business ownerships. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.050 - Zero cost business licenses. 
    The following "persons" require a business license, but the cost of said business license is zero dollars ($0.00): 
A.  Churches or established religious organizations. 
B.  Tax exempt organizations. 
C.  Schools. 
D.  Persons exempt under federal or state law. 
E.  Persons engaged in a casual transaction. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.060 - Obligations of license. 
    Every licensee shall: 
A.  Ascertain and at all times comply with all laws and regulations applicable to a licensed business. 
B.  Avoid any illegal, unreasonably dangerous or harmful practices or conditions which are detrimental to the public property, health, welfare, peace or safety. 
C.  Not be in default under the provisions of this article nor be in default financially to the City in any manner. 
D.  Refrain from engaging in business in the City whenever the license for that business is revoked or suspended. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.070 - Miscellaneous license provisions. 
A.  Unlawful to Use Public Streets and Rights-of-Way. It shall be unlawful to conduct business on any public street or right-of-way except in accordance with the ordinances of the City or specific written permission from the City. 
B.  License to be Posted. Business licenses must be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises, or other place as appropriate, at all times. 
C.  License is Non-transferable. The business license is issued solely to the licensee and no license issued pursuant to this article shall be transferable to any person. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.080 - Administration. 
    The administration of this article is hereby vested with the City Clerk, or his or her designee who is hereby authorized to: 
A.  Collect license fees and issue receipts therefore. 
B.  Adopt all forms and prescribe the information to be given therein. 
C.  Investigate and determine the eligibility of each applicant for a license. 
D.  Promulgate and enforce all reasonable rules and regulations necessary to the operation and enforcement of this article. 
E.  Investigate, report and recommend to the City Council the suspension of license for violation by the licensee of a provision of this article. 
F.  Require an applicant to produce documentation supporting information given on the business license application if the initial documentation is missing, incomplete, or the Clerk has reason to believe the nature of the business has substantially changed since the time of application. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.090 - License application. 
    Every person required to procure a license shall submit an application in the manner and form required by the City Clerk along with the required license fee for each license. The full payment is required at the time of application. 
    Said application shall at a minimum contain: 
A.  The name and address of the person, firm or corporation desiring the license and the name of the business for which the license is being sought. If the application is other than a natural person, the application shall also provide the names and addresses of the individuals, officers, or directors comprising the applicant. 
B.  The nature of the business to be performed, practiced or carried out. 
C.  The street address, if any, where such business is to be carried on. 
D.  The applicant's state and local sales tax number, if applicable. 
E.  Any other information deemed by the City Clerk to be reasonably necessary to carry out the provisions and the fair administration of this article. 
F.  An affidavit signed by the applicant stating that the information contained on the application is true and correct to the applicant's knowledge and further stating that knowing submission of false information shall be cause for the license to be immediately revoked without notice or hearing. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.100 - License renewal and fees. 
    Every business shall pay an annual license fee and shall obtain a license prior to the commencement of business. The license shall be valid from January 1 of the year of issuance through December 31 of the year of issuance. The business license fee is due each December 1 and payable to the City on or before December 31 annually. First time businesses applying for a business license between July 1 and December 31 of any year shall pay one-half (0.5) of the license fee otherwise due, but shall be liable for a full license fee payment in the succeeding January. For the inaugural year, the year of 2017, businesses shall pay twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for their business license by July 1, 2017. Said license shall be valid until December 31, 2017. 
    The annual business license fee is hereby levied upon every person doing business within the City according to the following schedule, which may be amended by resolution by the City Council: 
A. Each fixed business: Fifty dollars ($50.00) B. Each non-fixed businesses: Fifty dollars ($50.00) C. Each home occupation: Fifty dollars ($50.00) D. Each business not otherwise classified: Fifty dollars ($50.00) E. Each City retail liquor licensee except three and two-tenths percent (3.2%) beer: Fifty dollars ($50.00)  
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.110 - Revocation and suspension. 
A.  Revocation. A license may be immediately revoked should the City Clerk ascertain: that the licensee deliberately and knowingly provided false information on the license application; the licensee has not paid the annual fee; or, the licensee is engaged in an unlawful business or is not qualified or licensed to engage in such a business within the state. 
B.  Suspension. A license may be suspended by the City Council if the Council should find the licensee has violated any of the terms of this article or any regulation or order lawfully made relating thereto; or if should find any fact or condition which, if it had existed or been known at the time of license issuance, would have warranted the refusal of said issuance. Such a finding and determination shall not be made by the Council until: 
1.  The licensee is provided with not less than seven (7) days written notice stating the contemplated action and in general, the grounds therefore, and 
2.  The licensee is given a reasonable opportunity to be heard by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
5.02.120 - Unpaid license fees a lien. 
    Pursuant to state statute, including but not limited to C.R.S. 31-20-101, the City may cause any delinquent charges or fees made or levied hereunder to be certified to the Fremont County Treasurer, to be collected and paid over by said Treasurer in the same manner as real or personal property taxes, including provisions for the creation of a lien upon the subject property. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017F, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
Chapter 5.04 - ADVERTISING SIGNS AND MATERIAL 
Sections: 

5.04.010 - License required. 
    No person, firm or entity shall erect or maintain any billboard or sign within the City of Florence or within one (1) mile of the limits thereof for the purpose of advertising any business to the public without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Ord. 1-79 § 2, 1979) 
5.04.020 - Billboard licenses. 
    Every person, firm or entity wishing to erect or maintain a billboard within the City or within one (1) mile of the boundaries thereof, shall make written application to the City Clerk for an annual license therefor. The application shall state the name and address of the person, firm or entity wishing to erect or maintain the billboard; the location where the billboard shall be erected or maintained and the message the billboard shall bear. The applicant shall also submit to the City Clerk with the application the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Upon receipt of the application and fee, and providing the City Clerk finds that everything is in proper order, the City Clerk shall issue an annual license to the applicant for the billboard for which application is made. 
(Ord. 1-79 § 3, 1979). 
5.04.030 - Business sign licenses. 
    Every person, firm or entity wishing to erect or maintain a commercial business sign within the City or within one (1) mile of the boundaries thereof, after the date of enactment of the ordinance codified in this chapter, shall make written application to the City Clerk for a license therefor. The application shall state the name and address of the person, firm or entity wishing to erect or maintain the sign; the location where the sign shall be erected or maintained; and the message the sign shall bear. The applicant shall also submit to the City Clerk with the application the sum of ten dollars ($10.00). Upon receipt of the application and fee, and providing the City Clerk finds that everything is in proper order, the City Clerk shall issue a license to the applicant for the sign for which application is made. 
(Ord. 1-79 § 4, 1979). 
5.04.040 - Construction standards. 
    Every billboard or sign erected or maintained within the City or within one (1) mile of the boundaries thereof shall be constructed in a safe and sufficient manner so as not to endanger any property or person. Every such billboard or sign shall be subject to inspection by the City Manager or his designated representative. Should any billboard or sign be found to be in an unsafe condition, the person maintaining same shall, upon written notice, immediately remove same or render it in a safe condition subject to the approval of the inspector. 
(Ord. 1-79 § 5, 1979). 
5.04.050 - Unsafe signs-Removal. 
    Should any person responsible for any billboard or sign as above set forth fail to render any billboard or sign safe within two (2) days after written notice has been given of its unsafe condition as set forth in Section 5.04.040, the City Manager shall cause same to be removed and the party responsible for the billboard or sign shall bear the costs thereof. 
(Ord. 1-79 § 6, 1979). 
5.04.060 - View-obscuring signs. 
    No billboard, sign or poster as described in Section 5.04.010 shall be erected, mounted or placed in such a manner so as to obscure or limit the vision of any driver of any vehicle on any public way or obscure the vision of any pedestrian upon any public way in such a manner as may be hazardous to the operation of any vehicle or hazardous to any pedestrian. 
(Ord. 1-79 § 7, 1979). 
5.04.070 - Removal of temporary signs. 
    Any person, firm or entity erecting, mounting or placing any sign or poster of a temporary nature, for whatever purpose, within this City or within one (1) mile of the limits thereof shall be responsible for removing the same within one (1) week after the purposes of the sign or poster is accomplished or the sign or poster is no longer necessary to serve said purpose. 
(Ord. 1-79 § 8, 1979). 
5.04.080 - Political signs. 
    All signs or posters erected within the City or one (1) mile thereof, pursuant to Section 1540 of Article 10 of Title 31 of the Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended, for political office shall be removed within one (1) week after election day. If such signs or posters are not removed within the time specified, the City Manager may cause same to be removed and the candidate or candidates whose names the said signs or posters bear shall bear the cost for such removal. 
(Ord. 1-79 § 9, 1979). 
5.04.090 - Circulars. 
    No person, firm or entity shall distribute or cause to be distributed within this City or one (1) mile thereof any circulars, bills or similar advertising devices in such a manner that same may or could end up in a condition as to be considered litter as defined in Section 5.04.095. It shall be prima facie evidence indicating violation of this section that more than five (5) of any bills, circulars or similar advertising devices are found upon any street, walkway or other public area of this City. 
(Ord. 12-79 (part), 1979: Ord. 1-79 § 10, 1979). 
5.04.095 - Litter defined. 
    The word "litter" is defined to include any rubbish, waste matter, refuse, garbage, trash or other form of abandoned article or personal property, whether solid or liquid and of whatever form, size, kind and description. 
(Ord. 12-79 (part), 1979: Ord. 1-79 § 13, 1979). 
5.04.100 - Signs on State highways. 
    Signs along State highways as defined in Section 43-2-101(1) CRS, and signs along the Interstate system of highways as defined in Section 43-2-101(2), CRS, are prohibited unless such signs conform with all of the requirements of the Outdoor Advertising Act, Part 4 of Article I of Title 43, CRS, as amended, and any rules and regulations promulgated by the State of Colorado Department of Highways pursuant thereto and any applicable federal law and rules and regulations. 
(Ord. 16-84 § 1, 1984). 
Chapter 5.08 - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT GAMES[2] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
 Prior ordinance history: Ord. 368, 370 and 464. 

5.08.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows: 
A.  "Coin-operated amusement game" means any machine which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, or disc, may be operated by anyone for use as a game, entertainment, or amusement, whether or not registering a score. It includes such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, skill ball, pool tables, mechanical grab machines, and all games, operations, or transaction similar thereto under whatever name they may be indicated. 
B.  "Coin-operated music machine" means any music vending machine, contrivance, or device which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, disc, or key into any slot, crevice, or other opening, or by the payment of any price, operates or may be operated for the emission of songs, music, or similar amusement. 
C.  "Owner" means any person owning one or more coin-operated amusement games or one or more coin music machines. 
D.  "Person" means any natural person, firm, corporation or association. 
(Ord. 9-79 § 1, 1979). 
5.08.020 - Gambling prohibited. 
    No person shall use any coin-operated machine for gambling or permit such a machine to be used for a gambling device. 
(Ord. 9-79 § 2, 1979). 
5.08.030 - License-Required. 
    Any owner displaying or keeping for operation any coin-operated amusement game or any coin-operated music machine, in any public place or private club within the City, shall be required to obtain a license from the City Clerk. Before any such license shall issue, the applicant therefor shall file with the City Clerk, as part of the application, a statement under the oath of the applicant or an officer of the applicant, setting forth the number of coin-operated amusement games and the number of coin-operated music machines on display or being kept for operation within the City. 
(Ord. 9-79 § 3, 1979). 
5.08.040 - License-Fee. 
    Licenses shall be issued under this chapter by the City Clerk for each calendar year of operation or any remainder thereof upon payment, in advance, of a fee of: 
A.  Seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for the initial coin operated amusement game and seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) for each additional game; and 
B.  Seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for the initial coin music machine and seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) for each additional machine. 
(Ord. 1-83 § 2, 1983). 
5.08.050 - License-Term. 
    All such licenses shall be issued for a period commencing at noon of the first day of January of each year or upon the date of its issuance if subsequent to said date of January 1st, and shall terminate at noon of the first day of January following the date of issuance of said license. The City Clerk shall make no refunds, rebates, or reduction in the total fee required by Section 5.08.040 to any applicant or licensee for a license period less than twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. 9-79 § 5, 1979). 
5.08.060 - License-Nontransferable. 
    No such license shall be transferable from one person to another. 
(Ord. 9-79 § 6, 1979). 
5.08.070 - License-Display required. 
    Every owner or operator licensed under this chapter shall display at all times upon each coin-operated amusement game and upon each coin-operated music machine a copy of the license issued under the terms of this chapter or, in lieu thereof, a conspicuous card stating the name and address of the owner or operator and the date of the expiration of his license. 
(Ord. 9-79 § 7, 1979). 
5.08.080 - Violation-Misdemeanor-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor, and each twenty-four (24) hours during which said violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. The license of any owner convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be forthwith revoked and any game operated in violation of the terms of this chapter may be confiscated by the order of the Municipal Judge and disposed of as he may direct. Any owner convicted of failing to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be punished pursuant to the general penalty provision of this Code, § 1.12.010. 
(Ord. 9-79 § 8, 1979). 
(Ord. No. 9-2013, § 2, 8-5-2013) 
Chapter 5.12 - CONTRACTORS 
Sections: 

5.12.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
A.  "Contractor" means any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation, who for a fixed or determinable sum of money or other compensation, other than wages, undertakes or agrees to undertake, for another, the construction, alteration or repair of any building or structure affixed to real property, or any part thereof; provided, that such term shall not include, and this chapter shall not apply to, persons installing, repairing or altering plumbing, electrical wiring, natural gas lines, fixtures or appliances, tree trimming or any other business for which a license is otherwise required. 
B.  "General contractor" means any contractor who undertakes or agrees to undertake any such construction, alteration or repair which requires the services of a person or persons engaged in two (2) or more different trades. 
C.  "Limited contractor" means any contractor who undertakes or agrees to undertake any such construction, alteration or repair which requires the services of a person or persons engaged in one trade only. 
D.  "Person" means any individual, whether acting on his own behalf or while in the employ of a firm, partnership or association, which is a contractor, as defined in this section. 
E.  "Trade" means an occupation requiring special mechanical and technical knowledge and skill, including masonry, carpentry, plastering, painting and papering, glazing, roofing, and all other occupations carried on in the construction, alteration or repair of buildings or structures requiring special knowledge and skill for the performance thereof. 
F.  "Wages" means compensation paid for services measured solely by the time spent in performance of such service multiplied by the rate of compensation per unit of time. 
(Ord. 474 § 4, 1960). 
5.12.020 - License required. 
    No person, firm, partnership, association or corporation shall engage in the business of contractor, either general or limited, within the City of Florence, Colorado, as defined in this chapter, unless a contractor's license shall be applied for and there shall be issued to such person, partnership, firm, association or corporation, a contractor's license for the current year, as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 474 § 1, 1960). 
5.12.030 - License fees-Expiration date. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation acting as a contractor to engage in any type of activity within the City without first obtaining a license. The applicant shall provide to the City Clerk proof of general liability and automobile liability insurance by means of a certificate of insurance. The minimum insurance limits shall be as follows: 
General contractor General liability $1,000,000.00 per occurrence Automobile liability $1,000,000.00 each accident Limited contractor General liability $300,000.00 per occurrence Automobile liability $100,000.00 each accident  
    The City shall charge an annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a general contractor license and fifty dollars ($50.00) for a limited contractor license. Licenses shall expire on December 31st, next following the date of issue. Each license shall contain a statement of whether it is a general or limited license, and, if limited, the trade to which its exercise is limited. 
(Ord. 7-2003, 2003). 
5.12.040 - Revocation or suspension of license. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked, suspended or refused. Any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation who intentionally and openly violates the federal, state and municipal laws, rules and ordinances pertaining to the building trades; provided, that no license shall be revoked or suspended for the reason contained in this section except by action of the City Council upon a verified complaint filed with the Council by a party directly affected by such violation, setting forth the violations, and unless such complaint or a part thereof shall, in the opinion of a majority of the Council present at a meeting thereof, be sustained by evidence presented at a hearing before the Council. The applicant shall be given notice of such hearing and a copy of such complaint at least ten (10) days prior to such hearing, and he shall be permitted to be present and be represented by counsel at such hearing and present evidence thereat in his own behalf. 
(Ord. 474 § 3, 1960). 
Chapter 5.16 - JUNK DEALERS 
Sections: 

5.16.010 - Junk defined. 
    "Junk" as used in this chapter, means and includes: All scrap metal, and all other materials, fabrics, rubber, paper, glass, rubbish, discarded items such as furniture, furnishings, clothing, bottles, rope, cable, books, magazines, newspaper, automobiles, machines, apparatuses, and contrivances, and parts thereof, including tires, which, from their worn condition, renders the items practically useless for the purpose for which they were made, whether or not such items are for sale or trade. 
(Ord. 9-78, § 2, 1978). 
(Ord. No. 6-2013, § 1, 5-6-2013)
