B.  It shall be unlawful for any person, applicant, licensee, or manager who operates a sexually oriented business or his or her agent to refuse to permit such lawful inspection of the premises at any time that it is occupied or open for business. 
(Ord. 15-2001 § 2 (part), 2001). 
Chapter 5.38 - MEDICAL MARIJUANA LICENSES AND OPERATIONS PROHIBITED 

5.38.010 - Definitions. 
    The following terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the following meanings: 
A.  "Medical marijuana," "medical marijuana center," "medical marijuana-infused product," "medical marijuana-infused products manufacturer," "optional premises cultivation operation," and "person" shall have the same meanings as set forth at CRS § 12-43.3-104 as amended. 
B.  "Patient" and "primary caregiver" shall have the same meanings as set forth in Article XVIII, Section 14(1) of the Colorado Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 7-2010, § 1, 12-20-2010) 
5.38.020 - Findings. 
    The City Council hereby finds and declares that the Colorado Medical Marijuana Code, CRS § 12-43.3-101 et seq., as amended, clarifies Colorado law regarding the scope and extent of Article XVIII, Section 14 of the Colorado Constitution; that this chapter is necessary based on City zoning, health, safety, and public welfare considerations; and further, that this chapter is intended to apply to all property and business enterprises operating within the City whether stationary, mobile or virtual. 
(Ord. No. 7-2010, § 1, 12-20-2010) 
5.38.030 - Medical marijuana licenses and operations prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate, cause to be operated or permit to be operated a medical marijuana center, optional premises cultivation operation, or medical marijuana-infused products manufacturer's facility in the City, and the City shall not issue licenses to permit any such activities. 
(Ord. No. 7-2010, § 1, 12-20-2010) 
5.38.040 - Severability. 
    If any provision of this chapter shall be held invalid, its invalidity shall not affect any other provisions of this chapter that can be given effect without the invalid provision, and for this purpose the provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 7-2010, § 1, 12-20-2010) 
5.38.050 - Penalty, nuisance declared. 
A.  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished pursuant to Section 1.12.010 of this code. Each day a violation of a provision of this chapter continues to exist shall be deemed a separate violation. 
B.  No person, being the owner, agent, lessee or occupant of, or having under his/her control, any building, lot or premises, shall maintain, allow or permit any activities proscribed in Section 5.38.030, which activities are hereby declared a nuisance per se, that may be abated pursuant to Chapter 8.08, Title 8 of this code. 
C.  The provisions of this section are cumulative. 
(Ord. No. 7-2010, § 1, 12-20-2010) 
Chapter 5.40 - RETAIL MARIJUANA ESTABLISHMENTS PROHIBITED EXCEPT TESTING FACILITIES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6-2016, adopted Mar. 7, 2016, repealed and reenacted Ch. 5.40 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 5.40 pertained to a similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 13-2014, adopted July 7, 2014. 

5.40.010 - Permanent moratorium on marijuana establishments except testing facilities. 
    The City of Florence hereby imposes a permanent moratorium on the acceptance, processing, and approval of all applications for any permit or license, or any other application pertaining to marijuana establishments, including retail marijuana shops, marijuana product manufacturing facilities, and marijuana cultivation facilities as those terms are defined at C.R.S. 12-43.4-103 and Section 16, Article XVIII of the state constitution. Marijuana testing facilities, as that term is defined at C.R.S. 12-43.4-103(21) and Section 16(2)(1) of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution, are exempt from the permanent moratorium. 
(Ord. No. 6-2016, § 1, 3-7-2106) 
5.40.020 - Marijuana testing facilities shall be licensed. 
    The City of Florence requires any marijuana testing facility operating within the City to be licensed pursuant to C.R.S. 12-43.4-405, as amended, and to comply with the requirements of that section and the rules and regulations promulgated by the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. No. 6-2016, § 1, 3-7-2016) 
Title 6 - ANIMALS[1] 
Chapters: 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
 For statutory provisions authorizing cities to regulate and control animals and fowl, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-401 (1) (m) (1975 Supp.) 

Chapter 6.04 - DOGS 
Sections: 

6.04.010 - Definitions. 
    For all purposes of this chapter, the following words shall be defined as follows: 
A.  "Animal Control Officer" means any person employed by the City or County of Fremont to enforce the provisions of this chapter, and all police officers of the City of Florence. 
B.  "City" means the City of Florence, Colorado. 
C.  "Destructive dog" means any dog which has at any time prior injured any type of property belonging to any person or entity other than the owner of the dog, or any dog which the owner thereof knows or should know has destructive tendencies. 
D.  "Dog" means any dog whether male or female excepting puppies which have not yet been weaned. 
E.  "Dog kennel" means any collection of four (4) or more dogs owned by one (1) person at one (1) time and kept at the same location. 
F.  "Noisy dog" means any dog that barks, yelps or howls loudly and at frequent intervals, or continuously or for long periods of time. 
G.  "Owner" means any person who owns, keeps, harbors or possesses a dog in the City, and shall also mean and include any and all persons who own, keep, harbor or possess a dog which at any time runs at large within the City, whether such person is a resident or nonresident of the City; except that "owner" shall not mean nor include any person or persons owning, keeping, harboring or possessing a dog when such person or persons are merely traveling through the City or visiting or sojourning in the City for a period of less than one (1) month. 
H.  "Pound" means the enclosure provided by the City for keeping dogs or a humane shelter not operated by the City but used by the City for impounding animals. 
I.  "Run at large" or "running at large" means any dog when off or away from the premises of the owner, possessor or keeper and not under the control thereof by means of a leash no more than ten (10) feet in length or under voice command. 
J.  "Nefarious dog" means any vicious or destructive dog that bites or bites at any person or other living animal, or otherwise attacks any person or other living animal in a dangerous, threatening or terrorizing manner. 
(Ord. 11-2000 § 1, 2000; Ord. 26-78 § 1, 1979). 
(Ord. No. 9-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
6.04.020 - License required. 
    All dogs in the City shall be licensed and registered by their owners. Applications for licenses shall be made to the City Clerk who shall issue licenses and tags. Dog licenses issued by the City Clerk shall continue valid for a period of two years from the date of issuance. Applications for dog licenses must be submitted to the City Clerk during the last month prior to the expiration of any prior valid license except as provided in this section. An owner who acquires a dog not previously licensed and registered must, within thirty (30) days, license and register such dog. Further, the owner of a newborn dog must license and register the same within thirty (30) days after the dog reaches the age of four months. 
(Ord. 4-82 § 2, 1982). 
6.04.030 - License application fee. 
    Applications to license and register dogs shall be submitted to the City Clerk. Applicants shall submit a certificate from a licensed veterinarian which indicates that the dog to be licensed has been inoculated with an antirabies vaccine within the previous two (2) years. Applicants shall further submit the name and address of the dog owner together with the name, breed, color, and sex of the dog. Applicants shall pay to the City Clerk a license fee in the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for neutered male or spayed female dogs and fifty dollars ($50.00) for dogs which have not been spayed or neutered. 
(Ord. 4-82 § 3, 1982). 
(Ord. No. 9-2016, § 2, 4-18-2016) 
6.04.040 - Change in ownership. 
    Whenever the ownership of a dog changes, the new owner shall, within thirty (30) days of the change, register the dog and pay the fees as provided by Section 6.04.030. 
(Ord. 26-78 § 4, 1978). 
6.04.050 - Tag issuance. 
    Upon submission of a proper application to license and register a dog, the City Clerk shall issue to the applicant a metal tag for the dog licensed. The tag shall be numbered and shall bear the date of anti-rabies inoculation, which date shall be deemed to be the date of issuance of license for the purposes of this chapter. The City Clerk shall keep registration records indicating the tag number and date of issuance of license for all dogs. All licensed dogs shall wear a tag at all times on a collar around the dog's neck of sufficient strength to restrain the dog. If lost, a duplicate tag shall be purchased from the City Clerk at a cost of one dollar ($1.00). 
(Ord. 4-82 § 4, 1982). 
6.04.060 - Registration exemptions. 
    No dog shall be required to be registered if it belongs to a nonresident of the City who has been within the City for fewer than thirty (30) days, nor for any dog brought into the City for purposes of participating in a dog show nor for any dog less than four (4) months of age. Seeing Eye dogs used to assist blind persons shall be registered as required in this chapter, but no fee shall be charged therefor. 
(Ord. 26-78 § 6, 1978). 
6.04.070 - Kennels. 
    Any person or entity keeping four (4) or more dogs at one time in one (1) place shall be deemed to be operating a kennel. No person or entity shall maintain a kennel within the City without first having received a license therefor. Application for such a license shall be made to the City Clerk and shall state the name of the applicant, location of the kennel, number of dogs to be kept therein and shall have the names of all persons residing within one thousand (1,000) feet of the proposed location stating that they consent thereto. Upon the payment of fifty-five dollars ($55.00) by the applicant, the City Clerk, if he finds the application to be in order, shall issue a license to the applicant, good for one (1) year from the date of issuance. No person shall maintain within the City a kennel having more than twenty-five (25) dogs. 
(Ord. 26-78 § 7, 1978). 
6.04.080 - Dogs at large prohibited. 
    No person shall permit any dog under his care to run at large within the City. 
(Ord. 26-78 S8, 1978). 
6.04.090 - Biting dogs-Dogs suspected of rabies. 
    Any dog which is known to have or is suspected of having bitten or injured any person so as to cause an abrasion of the skin, or any dog which in the opinion of the health officer or any licensed veterinarian of the State of Colorado appears to be infected with rabies, shall be impounded at the expense of the owner thereof, closely confined, as directed by the health officer, for a period of fourteen (14) days; and if during such period such dog displays symptoms of illness, its disposition shall be determined by the Health Officer. A dog which is known to have been exposed to an animal infected with rabies shall be impounded at the expense of the owner thereof, and the disposition of such dog shall be made as directed by the Health Officer, or, when permitted by the Health Officer, shall be closely confined by its owner in accordance with the directions of the Health Officer for a period of not less than six (6) months from the date of exposure. If the owner of any such dog cannot be determined or located, then such dog shall be confined under the direction of the Health Officer, and if such dog is not claimed from the Health Officer, the officer may order such dog destroyed. In case such dog is claimed by the owner thereof, the cost of such confinement shall be paid by the owner before such dog is released. 
(Ord. 26-78 § 9, 1978). 
6.04.100 - Noisy dogs. 
    No person or entity shall keep a noisy dog upon any premises within the City. Any dog which continually disturbs any person by means of continuous noise shall be deemed to be a nuisance. Upon complaint made to the Animal Control Officer, the Animal Control Officer shall investigate the matter and if he finds the complaint to be sustained he shall file a complaint against the person keeping such animal in Municipal Court. If any person is convicted of keeping a noisy dog twice in any one (1) year period, he shall be fined a minimum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Ord. 26-78 § 10, 1978). 
6.04.110 - Nefarious dogs prohibited. 
    No person or entity shall keep a nefarious or destructive dog within the City. Upon complaint made to the Animal Control Officer, the Animal Control Officer shall investigate the matter and if he or she finds the complaint to be sustained, shall file a complaint against the person keeping such an animal in Municipal Court. If any person is convicted of keeping a nefarious or destructive dog twice in any one-year period, he or she shall be fined a minimum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Ord. 26-78 § 11, 1978). 
(Ord. No. 9-2016, § 3, 4-18-2016) 
6.04.120 - Nefarious dogs-Impoundment. 
    The Animal Control Officer shall impound any dog running at large, or which is proven, in the manner provided in Section 6.04.110, to be a nefarious or destructive dog, even though such dog is under the direct supervision and control of a person while it is off the premises occupied by its owner. The Animal Control Officer shall also impound any dog proven to be a noisy dog in the manner provided in Section 6.04.100 upon any complaint made to the Animal Control Officer as to any such dog subsequent to an initial complaint made pursuant to Section 6.04.100. The City shall have the authority to contract with the Fremont County Humane Society or other third party contractor to provide facilities for impoundment provided for in this section. 
(Ord. 26-78 § 12, 1978). 
(Ord. No. 9-2016, § 4, 4-18-2016) 
6.04.130 - Nefarious dogs-Destruction. 
    The Animal Control Officer or other police officer may kill any nefarious dog running at large, at any time or place, when there is a grave and imminent danger of its doing harm or injury to any person; and if a dog which proves to be nefarious or destructive is impounded, the Animal Control Officer or Fremont County Humane Society may authorize the euthanasia of the subject dog after ten (10) days from the date of notice to the owner or keeper that the dog is impounded pursuant to Section 6.04.140, unless the owner shall dispose of such dog within ten (10) days after the impounding in such manner that the inhabitants of the City shall be assured that any such dog shall no longer molest the inhabitants of the City. 
(Ord. 26-78, § 13, 1978). 
(Ord. No. 9-2016, § 5, 4-18-2016) 
6.04.140 - Impounded dogs-Notification of owner. 
    The Animal Control Officer shall list with the City Clerk all dogs impounded giving the names of the owner, if known, and if not known, the tag number of the dog, and a description thereof. The City Clerk shall then make no less than two (2) attempts on separate days but within five (5) days of receiving such list to notify the owner of the dog that the dog is impounded. 
(Ord. 26-78 § 14, 1978). 
6.04.150 - Impounded dogs-Redemption. 
    Any dog impounded other than a noisy, vicious or destructive dog, may be redeemed by the owner thereof upon payment to the City of those fees set forth in Chapter 6.12 of this code. Any dog not redeemed within ten (10) days may be disposed of as directed by the City Manager or by such other person as the Council may designate. 
(Ord. 26-78 § 15, 1978). 
6.04.160 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates any section of this chapter shall be considered to have committed a civil infraction and not a crime, and shall be subject to a fine not exceeding four hundred ninety-nine dollars ($499.00) for each such infraction. Each day upon which such infraction continues shall constitute a separate infraction. 
(Ord. 21-94 § 1, 1994). 
Chapter 6.08 - ANIMAL LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9-2012, adopted September 17, 2012, repealed and reenacted Ch. 6.08 to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 6.08 pertained to animal permits and derived from Ord. 570, 1974. 

6.08.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this Chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section: 
A.  "Animal" or "animals" shall include any cattle, horses, mules, sheep, goats or other hard-hoofed animals. 
B.  "Backyard poultry" shall include only female chickens and ducks. Not roosters or drakes. 
C.  "Fowl" means chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guineas, pigeons and like fowl. 
D.  "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or association. 
(Ord. No. 9-2012, § 1, 9-17-2012). 
6.08.020 - License-Required when. 
    No person shall keep or maintain animals, backyard poultry, rabbits or fowl within the corporate limits of the City of Florence unless such person has a valid license to do so, and no animals, backyard poultry, rabbits, or fowl shall be allowed to run or fly at will. 
    Application for a license to keep animals, backyard poultry, rabbits or fowl shall be made in writing to the City Clerk. At the time of application, a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be paid by the applicant. When issued, the license shall be valid for the applicant only, and for the listed premises, until cancelled by the applicant, or until revoked as herein provided. 
    Any premises upon which animals, backyard chickens, rabbits, or fowl are kept or maintained on the effective date of this Ordinance No. 9-2012, shall be deemed in violation. 
(Ord. No. 9-2012, § 1, 9-17-2012). 
6.08.030 - License-Conditions. 
    The City Manager shall issue licenses to persons desiring the same for the keeping of animals, backyard chickens, rabbits or fowl within the City of Florence only in compliance with the provisions of Title 17 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 9-2012, § 1, 9-17-2012). 
6.08.040 - License-Revocation or denial. 
    The City Manager may revoke any license upon satisfactory evidence that the licensee is violating, or have violated, any of the conditions set forth in the Florence Municipal Code. Within seven (7) calendar days after written notice of revocation is mailed by first class mail to the address listed for correspondence on the license application, the licensee shall rid the premises of the animals, backyard poultry, rabbits or fowl, along with any offensive or prohibited materials. 
    License shall be denied if keeping or maintaining animals, backyard poultry, rabbits and fowl is not a permitted use in the zone district containing the premises upon which the license is requested. 
(Ord. No. 9-2012, § 1, 9-17-2012). 
Chapter 6.12 - IMPOUNDMENT 
Sections: 

6.12.010 - Animal Control Officer. 
    The City Manager may appoint a qualified person to act as Animal Control Officer who shall be vested with authority as a police officer. Such Animal Control Officer shall act under the direction and supervision of the Chief of Police and City Manager and shall be responsible to them for carrying out his duties. 
(Ord. 570 Art. IV § 1, 1974). 
6.12.020 - Impoundment fees. 
    Not later than twenty-four (24) hours after the impounding of any dog or other animal, the owner shall be notified, if the owner is ascertainable and within the City. If the owner is unknown, written notice shall be filed with the Police Department describing the dog or other animal and the time and place of the taking. The owner of any dog or other animal so impounded may reclaim such dog or other animal upon suitable proof of ownership and upon the payment of the license fee, if a license is required and is unpaid, and of all cost incurred by the City for impounding and maintenance of such dog or other animal. The following amounts shall be charged: 
A.  For impounding any animal, twenty dollars ($20.00) to reclaim the animal; 
B.  The second time an owner reclaims an animal, the charge shall be forty dollars ($40.00); the third time eighty dollars ($80.00) and so on, with the charge doubling on each subsequent occasion; 
C.  In addition thereto, for keeping and caring for an animal during a period of impoundment, the owner shall be required to pay a daily charge of five dollars ($5.00). 
(Ord. 12-78 § 2, 1978: Ord. 570 Art. IV § 3, 1974). 
6.12.030 - Disposition of unclaimed animals. 
    Any dog or other animal impounded pursuant to this chapter which has not been reclaimed within five (5) days of such impoundment shall be conclusively deemed to have been abandoned by its owner, and may be destroyed or otherwise disposed of by the City of Florence or the Humane Society of Fremont County, Inc. Neither the City of Florence nor the Humane Society of Fremont County, Inc., nor their officers, agents, servants or employees, shall incur any civil or criminal liability whatsoever for the disposition of or destruction of any abandoned dog or other animal. 
(Ord. 570 Art. IV § 4, 1974). 
6.12.040 - Cats. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be construed to include cats. 
(Ord. 570 Art. IV § 5(part), 1974). 
Chapter 6.16 - OFFENSES AGAINST ANIMALS[3] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
 For statutory authority of cities to prohibit and punish for cruelty to animals, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-401(1) (i) (1975 Supp.); for provisions on cruelty to animals, see CRS 1973 § l8-9-201 et seq. 

6.16.010. - Poisoning. 
    It is unlawful for any person to poison any dog or other animal, or to distribute poison in any manner whatsoever with the intent or for the purpose of poisoning any dog or other animal. 
(Ord. 570 Art. V § 1, 1974). 
6.16.020 - Abandoning. 
    It is unlawful for anyone to abandon or turn loose any dog or other animal within the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 570 Art. V § 2, 1974). 
6.16.030 - Striking with vehicle. 
    It is unlawful for anyone to fall to stop and attend any dog or other animal if anyone strikes it with a vehicle. It is unlawful to in any way maim or harm such animal. 
(Ord. 570 Art. V § 3, 1974). 
6.16.040 - Cruelty and fighting. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the City of Florence to treat any animal or fowl in a cruel or inhumane manner, or to suffer any animal or fowl to fight upon exhibition, in violation of the laws of the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. 570 Art. V § 4, 1974). 
6.16.050 - Cats. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be construed to include cats. 
(Ord. 570 Art. IV § 5 (part), 1974). 
Chapter 6.20 - VENOMOUS REPTILES AND AMPHIBIANS 
Sections: 

6.20.010 - Sale or transfer prohibited. 
    No person, firm or entity residing within or doing business within the City of Florence, Colorado, shall sell or otherwise transfer to any other person, firm or entity, any living reptile or amphibian which is capable of inflicting any type of poisoned wound on any living thing. 
(Ord. 3-79 § 1, 1979). 
6.20.020 - Poisonous animals at large. 
    No person, firm or entity residing within or doing business within the City shall cause to be loosed within this City any poisonous reptile or amphibian as described in Section 6.20.010, nor shall he or it be in any way responsible therefor. 
(Ord. 379 § 2, 1979). 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY* 
Chapters: 
Chapter 8.08 - NUISANCES AND ABATEMENT 
Sections: 

8.08.010 - Statutory authorization. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is authorized pursuant to the provisions of Section 31-15-401, CRS 1973, as amended. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 1, 1981). 
8.08.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the ordinance codified in this chapter is to declare what is a nuisance within the City limits and to provide remedies for the abatement of the same. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 2, 1981). 
8.08.030 - Nuisance defined. 
    "Nuisance" means any act or condition which either (A) injuriously affects the safety, health, or morals of the public; or (B) obstructs the free use of property so as to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property; or (C) works some substantial annoyance, inconvenience or injury to the public. 
(Ord 1-81 § 10 (part), 1981). 
8.08.040 - Nuisances prohibited. 
    No person, being the owner, agent or occupant of, or having under his control, any building, lot or premises, shall maintain or allow any nuisance to be or remain thereon, nor shall any person permit or cause any nuisance to exist within the City limits. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 4, 1981). 
8.08.050 - Nuisances designated. 
    A nuisance may include, but is not limited to, the acts or conditions specifically declared to be nuisances in this chapter; provided, that the same act or condition either (A) injuriously affects the safety, health, or morals of the public; or (B) obstructs the free use of property so as to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property; or (C) works some substantial annoyance, inconvenience or injury to the public. 
(Ord. l-8l § l0 (part), 1981). 
8.08.060 - Stagnant ponds. 
    Any cellar, vault, drain, sewer, pond of water or other place, upon or within any private premises or grounds in this City, that is nauseous or offensive to others, or injurious to public health, through an accumulation or deposition of nauseous, offensive or foul water, or other substances, is a nuisance and may be abated as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(A), 1981). 
8.08.070 - Open wells, cisterns or excavations. 
    Excavations exceeding five (5) feet in depth, cisterns and wells or an excavation used for storage of water are public nuisances unless the same are adequately covered with a locked lid, or other covering weighing at least sixty (60) pounds, or are securely fenced with a solid fence to a height of at least five (5) feet, and may be abated as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(B), 1981). 
8.08.080 - Unauthorized handbills, posters and placards. 
    Any handbill, poster, placard, or painted or printed matter which is stuck, posted or pasted upon any public or private house, store or other buildings, or upon any fence, power pole, telephone pole or other structure, without the permission of the owner, agent, or occupant of the house, is a nuisance. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(C), 1981). 
8.08.090 - Fly-producing conditions. 
    The following are nuisances: 
A.  Any accumulation of manure on premises where animals are kept, unless the premises are kept clean and the manure is kept in a box or vault which is screened from flies and emptied at least once each week; 
B.  Privies, vaults, cesspools, pits or like places which are not securely screened to protect them from flies; 
C.  Trash, litter, rags or anything whatsoever in which flies may breed or multiply; or 
D.  Garbage in any quantity which is not covered or screened to protect it from flies. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(D), 1981). 
8.08.100 - Junkyards and dumping grounds. 
    All places used or maintained as junkyards or dumping grounds, or for the wrecking or disassembling of automobiles, trucks, tractors or machinery of any kind, or for the storing or leaving of worn out, wrecked or abandoned automobiles, trucks, tractors, trailers, boats and housetrailers, or machinery of any kind, or of any of the parts thereof, or for the storing or leaving of any machinery or equipment used by contractors or builders or by other persons, which places are kept in such manner as to essentially interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property by others, are a nuisance and may be abated as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(E), 1981). 
8.08.110 - Contaminated or impure wells. 
    Any well or cistern on any property within the city, whenever a chemical analysis or other proper test shows that the water of the well or cistern is contaminated, impure or unwholesome, is a nuisance. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(F), 1981). 
8.08.120 - Defective drains, ditches, tanks or garbage cans. 
    Any unclean, leaking, foul, unsafe, or dangerous, defective or filthy drain, ditch, tank or gutter or garbage can, whenever and wherever found in the City, is a nuisance. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(G), 1981). 
8.08.140 - Discharge of nauseous substances. 
    It is unlawful to discharge out of or from, or permit to flow from any house or place, foul or nauseous liquid or substance of any kind whatsoever, into or upon any adjacent ground or lot, or into any street, alley or public place in the City. Such discharge is a nuisance. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(I), 1981). 
8.08.150 - Stale, putrid or stinking fat, grease or other matter. 
    It is unlawful to keep, collect or use, or cause to be kept, collected, or used in this City, any stale, putrid or stinking fat or grease or other matter. Such conditions are a nuisance and may be abated as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(J), 1981). 
8.08.160 - Throwing rubbish into sewer. 
    It is unlawful to throw or deposit, or cause or permit to be thrown and deposited in any vessel or receptacle connected with a public sewer, any garbage, hair, ashes, fruit, vegetables, peelings, refuse, rags, cotton, cinders, toilet paper and liquid house slops. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(K), 1981). 
8.08.170 - Dead animals. 
    When any animal dies in this City, it shall be the duty of the owner or keeper thereof to remove the body of such animal forthwith beyond the limits of the City. If such body is not forthwith removed, the same is a nuisance, and such owner or keeper shall be deemed to have caused a nuisance to exist, and such nuisance may be abated as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 10(C), 1981). 
8.08.180 - Right of entry. 
    It shall be the duty of the City Manager of the City of Florence or his or her designee to enforce the provisions of this chapter within the City. The City Manager or his or her designee may enter upon or into any lot, house or other building or premises, with proper respect for the occupant's constitutional rights, to examine the property and to ascertain whether any nuisance, as defined by Section 8.08.030, Florence Municipal Code, exists; and any person acting in reliance upon the authority of this section shall be free from any action or liability on account thereof. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 3, 1998). 
8.08.190 - Abatement notice. 
    Upon determining or becoming otherwise aware of the existence of a nuisance, in violation of any provision of the Florence Municipal Code, the City Manager or his or her designee shall issue a written abatement notice to the owner, occupant or agent in charge of any lot, building or premises in or upon which such nuisance may be found, or who may be the cause of such nuisance; which abatement notice shall advise such person of the existence of the nuisance, shall require the person to abate the nuisance within five (5) days after receipt of such notice, and shall advise the person of the possible penalties for noncompliance with this chapter. Such notice shall be served by mailing a copy to the address of the occupant, and to the address of the owner or agent of the property as set forth in the records of the County Treasurer of Fremont County, Colorado. Proper notice shall be deemed to have been given when properly addressed and deposited in the United States Mail with the proper amount of postage attached. Such notice shall be deemed to have been received three (3) days after proper mailing. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 4, 1998). 
8.08.200 - Failure to abate-Remedies cumulative. 
    Any person failing or refusing to comply with the abatement notice issued in accordance of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and may be prosecuted therefor in the Municipal Court. The provisions of this chapter are cumulative to any other provisions within this code which provide for the abatement or penalization of nuisances. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 7, 1981). 
8.08.210 - Summary abatement-Other abatement by the City. 
    A public nuisance may be summarily abated by the City without prior court order if it is a nuisance per se. For the purpose of this section, a nuisance per se is expressly defined as a nuisance which is a nuisance at all times and under all circumstances regardless of location or surroundings. A nuisance which is not a nuisance per se shall be abated following a judicial determination by the Municipal Court that a nuisance exists. However, in all cases the City may summarily abate any nuisance in or upon any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk, highway, or other public property within the City. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 8, 1981). 
8.08.220 - Abatement expense assessment and lien. 
    Any expense incurred by the City in the abatement of a nuisance in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be chargeable against any person, owner, occupant, or agent responsible for such nuisance, and such charges shall be a lien upon the property upon which the nuisance was located until paid in full. The City shall notify such person, owner or occupant of such assessments, which must be paid within thirty (30) days after receipt of notice thereof. If such assessments are not timely paid, the City may certify such delinquent assessment to the Treasurer of Fremont County to be collected by the County Treasurer upon real property in accordance with the provisions of Section 31-20-105, CRS 1973, as amended. 
(Ord. 1-81 § 9, 1981). 
Chapter 8.10 - SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES PROHIBITED 
Sections: 

8.10.010 - State law. 
    Prohibitions and restrictions with respect to smoking within the City of Florence shall be as provided in applicable statutes of the State of Colorado, including but not necessarily limited to the Colorado Clean Indoor Air Act, Part 2 of Article 14 of Title 25, Colorado Revised Statutes, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. 15-2006 § 1 (part), 2006). 
8.10.020 - Exercise of local discretion. 
    The term "entryway" as defined and used in the Colorado Clean Indoor Air Act and applied within the boundaries of the City of Florence shall not include any outdoor area or defined radius that is proximate to any door or doorway leading into any building or facility. Smoking is not prohibited in such outdoor areas. 
(Ord. 15-2006 § 1 (part), 2006). 
8.10.030 - Unlawful acts-Penalty-Disposition of fines. 
A.  It is unlawful for a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls the use of a premises subject to this chapter to violate any provision of this chapter. 
B.  It is unlawful for a person to smoke in an area where smoking is prohibited pursuant to this chapter. 
C.  A person who violates this chapter, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a first violation within a calendar year, a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) for a second violation within a calendar year, and a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each additional violation within a calendar year. Each day of a continuing violation shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(Ord. 15-2006 § 1 (part), 2006). 
Chapter 8.12 - CESSPOOLS, SEWERS AND GREASETRAPS 
Sections: 

8.12.010 - Cesspools prohibited where public sewers are available. 
    No person, firm, or corporation shall use or maintain any privy vault, cesspool, or septic tank for the storage or disposal of human excrement on any premises within the boundaries of any established sanitary sewer district in any case where a public sewer is available and accessible to the property. 
(Ord. 10-89 § l(part), 1989; Ord. 509 § 8, 1965). 
8.12.020 - Inspections. 
    The County of Fremont, through their duly authorized representative shall have the right to issue permits, conduct inspections and collect fees for such permits and inspections of individual sewage systems as provided by agreement between the City of Florence and the County of Fremont. 
(Ord. 10-89 § 2, 1989). 
8.12.030 - Nuisances enumerated. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall use or maintain or permit to remain on premises owned or controlled by such person, firm or corporation, any privy vault, cesspool or septic tank for the disposal of human excrement, or any greasetrap, within the City of Florence, which shall be in a foul, leaking or otherwise defective condition and a menace to public health, or which shall be filled to such extent that it has become a menace to public health or no longer efficient in serving the purpose for which it was installed or in use. Greasetraps, cesspools, septic tanks, and privy vaults found to be in any such condition shall be deemed to be nuisances. 
(Ord. 509 § 10, 1965). 
8.12.040 - Inspector-Authorized vault cleaners. 
    All inspections required in this chapter shall be made by an Inspector appointed by the Council whose compensation shall be fixed by the Council. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall clean, empty, drain, or otherwise remove, carry away or dispose of the contents of any greasetrap, privy vault, cesspool or septic tank except a person, firm or corporation holding a vault cleaner's or scavenger's permit from the City authorizing such person, firm or corporation so to do. 
(Ord. 509 § 11, 1965). 
8.12.050 - Inspection deemed compulsory. 
    No person, firm or corporation owning or controlling any property shall prevent, in any manner, or impose conditions upon, the inspection of any greasetrap, privy vault or cesspool. 
(Ord. 509 § 12, 1965). 
8.12.070 - Abatement of nuisances-Costs to become lien when. 
    The City shall have authority to abate any nuisance defined in this chapter by any appropriate means. If such abatement shall consist of cleaning, emptying or repair of any such greasetrap, cesspool, septic tank or privy vault, or when such cleaning, emptying or repair is ordered by the owner or person controlling the property, and such owner or persons fails to pay the charges direct to the vault cleaner, the cost thereof or charges therefor shall become due and payable with the next installment of water rent for the premises, and the City shall have the same lien and remedies for enforcing payment thereof as is provided by City ordinance for the collection of water rents. 
(Ord. 509 § 14, 1965). 
8.12.080 - Charges of vault cleaners. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall make any charge for cleaning or emptying any greasetrap, privy vault, cesspool or septic tank in excess of the maximum or less than the minimum rates set forth as follows in this section: 
A.  Greasetraps. 
1.  Greasetraps of a size not in excess of three and one-half (3 1/2) feet in depth and two (2) feet in diameter and not lying beneath a paved walk or driveway or beneath a building, a maximum charge of: 
a.  Six dollars and fifty cents ($6.50) for greasetraps lying not more than eight (8) inches beneath the surface; 
b.  Seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) for greasetraps lying more than eight (8) inches but less than two (2) feet beneath the surface. 
2.  Greasetraps in excess of the size described in subsection Al of this section, greasetraps lying two (2) feet or more beneath surface, and greasetraps lying beneath a paved walk or driveway or beneath a building, a charge not to exceed a sum equal to five dollars ($5.00) for each one-half (1/2) hour or fraction thereof, of time employed in such work. 
B.  Privy Vaults, Cesspools, and Septic Tanks. 
1.  A charge not to exceed a sum equal to five dollars ($5.00) per ton for water removed and ten dollars ($10.00) per ton of sludge removed; provided, however, a minimum charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be made in any event. 
(Ord. 509 § 15, 1965). 
8.12.090 - Inspection fee-Payment. 
    The owner of any premises on which is maintained a greasetrap, privy vault or cesspool, shall pay to the city an inspection fee of fifty cents ($.50) for each greasetrap having a covering of less than eight (8) inches, and one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) for each inspection of any other greasetrap, privy vault or cesspool shall be ordered emptied and cleaned by the owner or person in control of the property at or about the time such inspection is made, no inspection charge shall be made. 
    The Inspector or vault cleaner, as the case may be, shall restore the apparatus and all soil and sod thereon, to its former condition after each inspection or cleaning. 
(Ord. 509 § 16, 1965). 
8.12.100 - Kitchen wastes. 
    Waste pipes from kitchen sinks in any restaurant or cooking establishment shall run separate to a grease trap as provided in the State Plumbing Code; provided, that the Superintendent of the Water and Sewer Department may require any commercial, manufacturing or processing establishment which, in his opinion, is discharging into the sewers any substance likely to obstruct the sewer lines, to install a greasetrap as provided in the aforesaid State Plumbing Code; provided further, that no greasetrap shall be required for private residences of any type, or apartment houses, where no cooking is done in excess of the ordinary family requirements, but where such exempt premises now employ or continue using greasetraps in connection therewith, they shall be subject to all existing or future ordinances pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. 509 § 17, 1965). 
8.12.110 - Burying waste prohibited. 
    No night soil or greasetrap or cesspool matter shall be deposited or buried in or on any premises within the City limits. 
(Ord. 504 § 18, 1965). 
8.12.120 - Filling discontinued greasetrap. 
    Whenever any greasetrap, privy vault or cesspool is discontinued, such greasetrap, privy vault or cesspool shall be cleaned to the bottom and filled up with earth or other suitable material; and such work shall be under the supervision of the Superintendent of the Water and Sewer Department. 
(Ord. 509 § 19, 1965). 
Chapter 8.16 - VAULT CLEANING 
Sections: 

8.16.010 - License required-Fee. 
    No person, company or corporation shall engage in or conduct the occupation or business known as vault cleaning without first having obtained from the City a license therefor. A license shall issue to applicants upon the payment of the sum of twelve dollars ($12.00) to the City Clerk, and shall be issued for a calendar year and shall expire on the thirty-first (31st) day of December of each year. Before any such license shall issue, the party applying for same shall furnish evidence satisfactory to the plumbing inspector that the equipment of such applicant is adequate for the purpose of vault cleaning. 
(Ord. 509 § 28, 1965). 
8.16.020 - Removal of contents. 
    The contents of privy vaults, greasetraps and cesspools within the limits of the City shall not be removed therefrom, nor shall the same be transported through, any street, alley or public place within the City, except in the most approved sanitary manner, through or by means of airtight suction tanks, if soft and mixed with water, and if solid or dry, in sheet-steel-covered tanks, in such manner as shall prevent the escape of any noxious or offensive odors, and preserve such contents from sight or exposure during transportation. All tools, appliances, and vehicles used in such cleaning and removal shall be kept and maintained in perfect sanitary condition, subject to the inspection of the Health Officer of this City. 
(Ord. 509 § 29, 1965). 
8.16.030 - Bond. 
    Before issuing the license mentioned in Section 8.16.010, the applicant therefor shall execute and file with the City Clerk a bond to the City of Florence in the penal sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) with sufficient sureties to be approved by the City Clerk, conditioned that the applicant will faithfully observe all ordinances and rules of the Health Board or Health Officer adopted and to be adopted concerning the conduct and regulation of such licensed person, and that he will pay all fines, penalties and damages which may be assessed against him for the violation of such ordinance, rules, and regulations. 
(Ord. 509 § 30, 1965). 
Chapter 8.24 - FIRE PREVENTION[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
 For statutory provisions on the powers of cities in relation to fire regulations, see CRSA § 31-15-601. 

8.24.010 - Fire chief-Authority. 
    The Chief of the Fire Department and employees acting under his authority shall have full and complete police power and authority within the fire station, at fires and proceeding to and from them, in all matters pertaining to the Fire Department, and shall also have authority to make arrests for violations of all City ordinances, the enforcing of which is under his jurisdiction. 
    It is declared that this chapter and all the provisions thereof, and the provisions of all similar ordinances, are under the jurisdiction of the Chief of the Fire Department, whose duty it shall be to see that the same are enforced. 
(Ord. 365 § 1, 1938). 
8.24.020 - Unlawful acts. 
    From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, it is unlawful for: 
A.  Any person or persons to burn trash, lumber, leaves, straw or other like combustible material in any street, alley or vacant lot except by special permission of the Chief of the Fire Department when such burning shall be done in screened, metal receptacles approved by him and under such proper safeguards as he may direct as to time and weather; provided, that the Chief of the Fire Department may issue a general permit by publication during certain seasons of the year for the burning of leaves or other like material where conducted during daylight and with an adult in constant attendance; 
B.  Any person or persons to dispose of, place or dump empty boxes, barrels, leaves, trash, wastepaper, excelsior or other like combustible materials in any alley or on any sidewalk or vacant lot or premises within thirty (30) feet of any building, except by special permission of the Chief of the Fire Department; 
C.  Any person or persons to place ashes within any building in any box, barrel or other wooden vessel or upon any wooden vessel or floor; 
D.  Any person or persons to keep on any premises any oily waste or oily rags unless at all times when not actually in use such oily waste and oily rags are kept in a ventilated metal can with self-closing cover and riveted joints, standing on metal legs which raise the bottom of the container at least five (5) inches above the floor; 
E.  Any person or persons to keep or deposit any ashes or combustible refuse unless same is kept or deposited in a safe, secure, incombustible container with adequate openings at top and bottom; and every owner or occupant of property where ashes are kept or deposited shall erect and maintain upon the premises a permanently affixed incombustible ash pit for that purpose so located as not to endanger walls, fences or other combustible material. When located in a yard, such ash pits shall be so placed as to create no nuisance to adjoining property, and in no case shall they be located within a shed or at such location as to create a fire hazard. The primary duty of erecting such ash pits shall be upon the owner of such premises, but in the event that such owner fails, neglects or refuses to erect such ash pits, such failure, neglect or refusal shall in no way excuse the occupant of such premises from the erection of the same. Ash pits shall be cleaned at least once each week, and at such shorter intervals as may be necessary; 
F.  Any person or persons to pile or store hay, straw, lumber or other combustible material unless the same are completely enclosed within buildings; provided, that the Chief of the Fire Department may, by special permission, authorize such storage when, in his opinion the same does not constitute a fire hazard; 
G.  Any person or persons to store or keep any dynamite, nitroglycerin, giant powder, bulk can powder or other explosives in any building, storeroom, or warehouse within the City limits, except as hereafter provided. 
    Any person or persons desiring to store or keep any such dynamite, nitroglycerin, giant powder, gun powder or other explosives shall make written application to the Chief of the Fire Department for permission to do so, which application shall describe the amount of such explosives desired to be kept or stored by such applicant and the facilities and place such applicant proposes for the storage of the same. If, in the opinion of the Chief of the Fire Department, the facilities for storage are safe, considering the type and quantity of explosives desired to be stored, then the Chief of the Fire Department may issue a permit for such storage; provided, that such explosives shall, at all times, be kept in magazines made of fireproof material and kept securely locked, except when necessarily opened for use by authorized persons, and further provided that such magazines shall be conspicuously labelled in red letters at least four (4) inches high, "EXPLOSIVES" and located within the building on the ground floor within ten (10) feet of a street entrance. 
(Ord. 365 § 2, 1938). 
8.24.030 - Sale, use and possession of fireworks. 
A.  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply to this section: 
    "Fireworks" shall mean any composition or device designed to produce a visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration, or detonation, and that meets the definitions of "articles pyrotechnic", "permissible fireworks", or "display fireworks" as defined in C.R.S. 12-28-101. "Fireworks" shall not mean: 
(1)  Toy caps, party poppers, and items similar to toy caps and party poppers that do not contain more than sixteen (16) milligrams of pyrotechnic composition per item and snappers that do not contain more than one (1) milligram of explosive composition per item; 
(2)  Highway flares, railroad fusees, ship distress signals, smoke candles, and other emergency signal devices; or 
(3)  Educational rockets and toy propellant devices type engines used in such rockets when such rockets are nonmetallic construction and utilize replaceable engines or model cartridges containing less than two (2) ounces of propellant and when such engines or model cartridges are designed to be ignited by electrical means; or 
(4)  Fireworks which are used in testing or research by a licensed explosives laboratory. 
    "Permissible fireworks" shall mean the following small fireworks devices designed to produce audible or visual effects by combustion, complying with the requirements of the United States consumer product safety commission as set forth in 16 C.F.R. 1500.1 to 1500.272 and 1507.1 to 1507.12, and classified as consumer fireworks UN0446 and UN0337 pursuant to 49 C.F.R. 172.101: 
(1)  cylindrical fountains, total pyrotechnic composition not to exceed seventy-five (75) grams each for a single tube or, when more than one (1) tube is mounted on a common base, a total pyrotechnic composition of no more than two hundred (200) grams; 
(2)  Cone fountains, total pyrotechnic composition not to exceed fifty (50) grams each for a single cone or, when more than one (1) cone is mounted on a common base, a total pyrotechnic composition of no more than two hundred (200) grams; 
(3)  Wheels, total pyrotechnic composition not to exceed sixty (60) grams for each driver unit or two hundred (200) grams for each complete wheel; 
(4)  Ground spinner, a small device containing not more than twenty (20) grams of pyrotechnic composition venting out of an orifice usually in the side of the tube, similar in operation to a wheel, but intended to be placed flat on the ground; 
(5)  Illuminating torches and colored fire in any form, total pyrotechnic composition not to exceed two hundred (200) grams each; 
(6)  Dipped sticks and sparklers, the total pyrotechnic composition of which does not exceed one hundred (100) grams, of which the composition of any chlorate or perchlorate shall not exceed five (5) grams; 
(7)  Any of the following that do not contain more than fifty (50) milligrams of explosive composition: 
(a)  Explosive auto alarms; 
(b)  Toy propellant devices; 
(c)  Cigarette loads; 
(d)  Strike-on-box matches; or 
(e)  Other trick noise makers. 
(8)  Snake or glow worm pressed pellets of not more than two (2) grams of pyrotechnic composition and packaged in retail packages of not more than twenty-five (25) units; 
(9)  Fireworks that are used exclusively for testing or research by a licensed explosives laboratory; 
(10)  Multiple tube devices with: 
(a)  Each tube individually attached to a wood or plastic base; 
(b)  The tubes separated from each other on the base by a distance of at least one-half (0.5) of one (1) inch; 
(c)  The effect limited to a shower of sparks to a height of no more than fifteen (15) feet above the ground; 
(d)  Only one (1) external fuse that causes all of the tubes to function in sequence; and 
(e)  A total pyrotechnic composition of no more than five hundred (500) grams. 
    "Permissible fireworks" do not include aerial devices or audible ground devices, including, but not limited to, firecrackers. 
    "Person" shall mean an individual, partnership, firm, company, association, or corporation. 
B.  Sale of Fireworks. 
1.  Any person wishing to engage in the sale of "permissible fireworks", as defined C.R.S. 12-28-10,1 must first obtain the applicable licenses to do so, including, but not limited to a state retailer of fireworks license, a sales tax license, and a city business license. 
2.  The sale of "permissible fireworks" shall only be permitted from June 21st to July 4th. During all other times, the sale of "fireworks" shall not be allowed. 
3.  The sale of "fireworks" other than "permissible fireworks" is prohibited. 
C.  Use of Fireworks. 
1.  The use of "permissible fireworks" shall be permitted on July 4th between the hours of 12:00 p.m. and 12:00 a.m., on December 31st between the hours of 11:30 p.m. and 12:00 a.m., and January 1st between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 12:30 a.m. During all other times, the use of "permitted fireworks" is prohibited. 
2.  The use of "fireworks" is prohibited other than the use of "permissible fireworks" as provided above. 
D.  Possession of Fireworks. 
1.  No person shall sell, purchase, possess, or use "fireworks" other than "permitted fireworks" and in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
2.  No person under the age of sixteen (16) may purchase, possess, or use "permissible fireworks", unless under direct adult supervision. 
E.  Penalty. 
1.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this code, any person who violates Section 8.23.030C1 or 8.23.030D2 shall upon conviction be fined a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. 
2.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this code, any person who violates Section 8.23.030B, 8.23.030C2, or 8.23.030D1 shall upon conviction be fined a mandatory minimum fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. 
3.  Notwithstanding any other provision, any sale, use, or possession must be done in compliance with the provisions of C.R.S. 12-28-101 et seq. as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 08-21-2017B, § 1, 9-5-2017). 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-21-2017B, § 1, adopted Sept. 5, 2017, repealed the former § 8.24.030 and enacted a new § 8.24.030 as set out herein. The former § 8.24.030 pertained to fireworks and derived from Ord. 365, § 3, adopted 1938. 
8.24.040 - Inspections. 
A.  It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to inspect or cause to be inspected by the Fire Department officers or members, as often as may be necessary but not less than twice a year in outlying districts, and four (4) times a year in the closely built portions of the City, all buildings, premises and public thoroughfares, except the interiors of private dwellings, for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire, or any violations of the provisions or intent of any ordinances of the City affecting fire hazard. 
B.  Whenever any officer or member shall find in any building, or upon any premises or other place, combustible or explosive matter or dangerous accumulations of rubbish or unnecessary accumulations of wastepaper, boxes, shavings or any other highly flammable materials especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger property; or shall find obstructions to or on fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors or windows liable to interfere with the operations of the Fire Department, or egress of occupants, in case of fire; or shall find any condition dangerous to lives or property by reason of the fire hazard, he shall order the same to be removed or remedied, and such order shall forthwith be complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or buildings, subject to appeal within twenty-four (24) hours to the Mayor, who shall within ten (10) days review such order and file his decision thereon, and unless the order is revoked or modified it shall remain in full force and be obeyed by such owner or occupant. 
C.  Any owner or occupant failing to comply with such order within ten (10) days after said appeal shall have been determined, or if no appeal is taken then within ten (10) days after the service of the order, shall be liable to a penalty as hereinafter stated. 
D.  The Chief of the Fire Department shall have authority to order the immediate discontinuance of the use of any stove, stovepipe, flue, furnace, electric wiring or other hazardous device, pending the result of the appeal. 
(Ord. 365 § 4, 1938). 
Chapter 8.28 - GARBAGE AND REFUSE 
Sections: 

8.28.010 - Trash defined. 
A.  For the purposes of this chapter, the word "trash" means and includes any grass clippings, leaves, hay, straw, manure, shavings, excelsior, paper, ashes, garbage, rubbish, containers, boxes, glass, cans, bottles, waste and discarded building and construction materials (including but not limited to, plaster, broken concrete, bricks, cinder blocks, stones, wood, roofing material, wire and metal binding, sacks or loose discarded or unused material), kitchen and table refuse and offal, swill and every accumulation of animal, vegetable and other matter than attends the preparation, consumption, decay or dealing in or storage of meats, fish, fowls, birds, fruits or vegetables; the word "trash" also means and includes all garbage, refuse and rubbish of any kind or nature whatsoever, and any materials commonly known as garbage, refuse or rubbish of any kind of character or by any means known. 
B.  Notwithstanding what is set forth in subsection A of this section, "trash" shall not be construed to mean any hazardous substances or any material mixed with hazardous substances as defined at any United States Act including the Federal Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (as amended) and the Federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (as amended), or as defined at Articles 15 and 16, Title 25, C.R.S. (as amended), and collection and disposal of such hazardous substances and material mixed with hazardous substances shall be in accordance with any and all Federal and State regulations and shall not be the responsibility of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 29-92 § 1, 1992). 
8.28.020 - Accumulation of trash prohibited. 
    Any accumulation of trash on any premises, improved or unimproved, in the City of Florence is prohibited and is declared to be a nuisance. 
(Ord. 561 Art. II § 1, 1973). 
8.28.030 - Order to remove trash-Abatement and issuance of summons. 
    Whenever there is an accumulation of trash, the City Manager or his or her designee shall notify any owner of property, his agent or person having charge of such property, in writing, requiring the removal of any accumulated trash from such property or premises within five (5) days after service of notice. If such property owner, agent or person having charge of such property shall not remove such trash in accordance with the requirement of such order, the City Manager or his or her designee shall order that such trash be removed and assess the cost thereof against the property or premises and a summons and complaint charging a violation of this section shall be issued to such owner, agent or person having charge of such property. The amount so assessed shall be a lien upon the property upon which the accumulation was located, until paid in full. If such assessment is not timely paid, the city may certify such delinquent assessment to the County Treasurer to be collected by the County Treasurer upon real property in accordance with the provisions of CRS §§ 31-20-105 and 31-20-106. 
    If a summons is issued for a violation of this chapter, the fact that the violation is currently remedied shall not be a defense. If a summons is issued for a violation of this chapter, there shall be a mandatory one hundred dollar ($100.00) minimum fine plus applicable surcharges and court costs, assessed to cover a portion of the resources used by the city to bring the property into compliance. The mandatory minimum fine is in addition to all other remedies provide for in this chapter, but the fine assessed by the Florence Municipal Court shall not exceed the jurisdictional limitations of the Florence Municipal Court. Nothing herein shall limit the ability of the city to use any and all other remedies available to the city in this code or other applicable laws. Nothing herein shall limit in any way the recovery by the city for costs incurred by the city's abatement of any violation. 
(Ord. No. 02-15-2018a, § 3, 3-5-2018). 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-15-2018a, § 3, adopted Mar. 5, 2018, amended § 8.28.030 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 8.28.030 pertained to order to remove trash-abatement and derived from Ord. 29-92 § 2, adopted 1992. 
8.28.040 - Unlawful placement of trash. 
    No person shall deposit or place any trash in such a manner that the same is or tends to become a nuisance or in such a manner endangers or tends to endanger the public health. No person having the occupancy control or management of any premises shall cause or permit any trash to be accumulated thereon in such a manner that the same is or tends to become a nuisance or in such a manner endangers or tends to endanger the public health. No person shall in any manner throw, place, scatter, deposit, or bury any trash in or upon any public street, alley or other public place or upon his own premises or the premises of another. 
(Ord. 561 Art. II § 3, 1973). 
8.28.050 - Duties of residents. 
    It shall be the duty of every person, whether owner, lessee or renter of any vacant lot, building or premises, including any place of business, hotel, restaurant, dwelling house, apartment, tenement or any other establishment, at all times to maintain the premises in a clean and orderly condition, permitting no deposit or accumulation of trash or materials other than those ordinarily attendant upon the use for which such premises are legally intended. Any such accumulation shall constitute a nuisance and shall be nonconforming in the use of such premises. 
(Ord. 561 Art. III § 1, 1973). 
8.28.060 - Building materials to be removed from construction sites. 
    All plaster, broken concrete, bricks, cinder blocks, stones, wood, roofing material, wire or metal binding, sacks or loose discarded or unused material of any kind resulting from the wrecking, construction or reconstructing of any room, basement, wall, fence or sidewalk or building or the manufacture of any product shall be promptly removed or discarded in such a manner as not to be scattered about by the wind or otherwise, and as soon as possible be removed by the person responsible for such work. Such person shall be held liable for any scattering of such refuse upon adjacent property. 
(Ord. 561 Art. III § 2, 1973). 
8.28.070 - Removal of refuse from certain businesses required. 
    Discarded automobile parts stoves, furniture, wool, hides, junkyard refuse and packinghouse or slaughterhouse trash shall be removed periodically from such respective establishments by the proprietor so that the premises are clean and orderly at all times. Silt and similar deposits from automobile wash racks shall be removed by the establishment creating such deposit. Any accumulation of trash or material that is highly explosive or flammable which might endanger life or property shall be removed to such place as approved by the Chief of Police or the Chief of the Fire Department; such removal to be handled by the establishments responsible therefor. 
(Ord. 561 Art. III § 3, 1973). 
8.28.080 - Accumulation and use of manure. 
    Other than a light spread of manure which may be applied on lawns or gardens for fertilizing purposes, manure shall not be kept on any property for any purposes, or kept in any place for later use, but shall be either plowed under or removed by the owner, occupant or agent. 
(Ord. 561 Art. III § 4, 1973). 
8.28.090 - City to provide collection service. 
    The City of Florence or its agents, contractors or city-licensed operators shall furnish collection service as provided in this chapter to all persons residing within the City. 
(Ord. 561 Art. IV § 1, 1973). 
8.28.100 - Collection contract. 
    The City Council may enter into contracts or agreements with any persons or firms for the collection and disposal of trash, or any portion thereof, throughout the City, or it may at its discretion make provision for the collection or disposal of trash. 
(Ord. 561 Art. IV § 2, 1973). 
8.28.110 - Collection of trash-Licensing of individuals. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or association other than the City of Florence, or its duly authorized agents, which engages in the business of collection and disposal of trash within the City of Florence shall be required to obtain a license from the City Clerk. The license applicant shall provide proof of his vehicle liability insurance of an amount no less than three thousand dollars ($3,000.00). The City shall charge a license fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00). The license shall be issued for a period commencing on the first day of January of every year and valid until the first day of January of the following year. The City shall make no reduction in license fee because an applicant requires a license for a period of less than twelve (12) months. Nothing in the section shall prevent an individual from hauling his own trash; provided, that any trash hauled by such individual shall be in a covered container or in a vehicle covered or enclosed in such a manner as to prevent the scattering of any trash from the container or vehicle; and, provided further, that it is properly disposed of in conformity with all applicable City, County, State or Federal regulations, and that such individual is subject to all other provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 29-92 § 3, 1992). 
8.28.120 - Charges for city collection services-Costs to become lien when. 
A.  Establishing Charges. The City Council shall, by resolution, establish charges for collection service under this chapter, prescribe the time and manner of payment of such charges, and adopt measures designed to enforce the payment thereof such as in their discretion are necessary or desirable. In addition to any other charge, there shall be a ten dollar ($10.00) charge assessed to the subject account for payment by a check which is not honored by the drawer's bank. 
B.  Charges are a Lien. The amount of charges for trash collection service shall be the responsibility of the property owner and shall be a lien upon the subject property, and when three (3) months in arrears may be certified to the Fremont County Treasurer for collection in like manner as are general property taxes with any collection charge added that is allowed by law. 
C.  Notices Provided. Notice of the certification to the Fremont County Treasurer shall be mailed to the property owner at his last known address. 
    All billings shall be sent to the record owner unless the record property owner requests that such billings be sent to some other person. A written request form for this purpose shall be provided by the City and shall contain such information as may be deemed appropriate or necessary by the City Manager and shall be signed by the record owner. Such form shall contain a written warning providing as follows: 
"Warning. In the event of nonpayment of the trash collection bill and any other charges, including specifically a $10.00 charge for payment by a check not honored by the drawer's bank, the amount of such bill and charges together with any collection penalty provided by law may constitute a lien against the property and may be certified to the Fremont County Treasurer, who may add further charges for collection in like manner as are general property taxes. 
    If you choose to have billings sent to someone else, you will not receive notice of the status of your account unless you inquire at the City Clerk's office. 
As the property owner, you are responsible for payment of trash collection charges." 
(Ord. 7-88 § 3, 1988). 
8.21.121 - Residential collection. 
    "Residential" shall be defined as a single-family dwelling wherein one family resides; multi-family dwelling consisting of two or more family units; and mobile home parks. Collection shall be made from residences once per week in accordance with the rules and regulations as promulgated by the City Council. The monthly rates for residential trash collection shall be as set by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. 29-92 § 4, 1992). 
8.28.122 - Commercial collection. 
    "Commercial" shall be defined as all locations not designated as "residential' as defined in Section 8.28.121 of this chapter. 
    Collection shall be made from commercial locations in accordance with the rules and regulations as promulgated by the City Council. The monthly rates for commercial trash collection shall be as set by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. 29-92 § 5, 1992). 
8.28.150 - Unauthorized molesting, removal of trash or containers prohibited. 
    No person shall molest, remove, handle or otherwise disturb any trash containers or contents for servicing by the collectors; provided, that this section does not apply to the owner, occupant, lessee or tenant of the residence or dwelling so placing the containers and contents. 
(Ord. 561 Art. IV § 7, 1973). 
8.28.160 - Promulgation of rates, rules and regulations by City Council. 
    The City Council shall by resolution, establish rates, promulgate rules and regulations relating to the manner of preparing and accumulating trash for collection; the type and kind of containers to be used for such accumulation; the manner of use and care for such containers, and such other rules and regulations as, in its discretion, are necessary or desirable in the interest of maintaining efficiency and sanitary conditions in the trash collection system and service within the City; and such resolutions, when adopted, shall be of the same force and effect as if fully set forth in this section. All such resolutions shall contain the rules and regulations to be adopted, and shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation within the City of Florence at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of such resolution. 
(Ord. 29-92 § 7, 1992). 
8.28.170 - Enforcement. 
    The City Manager shall have charge and supervision of the trash collection system. He is empowered to employ and direct all assistants, laborers, agents, contractors, employees and City-licensed operators in the operation of the service. He shall enforce the terms of this chapter and the various rules and regulations promulgated under this chapter from time to time. 
(Ord. 561 Art. V § 1, 1973). 
Chapter 8.32 - LITTER 
Sections: 

8.32.010 - Scattering refuse prohibited-Refuse defined. 
    It is unlawful for any person to spill, leak, deposit, throw, dump, leave, distribute or scatter any rubbish, waste matter, refuse, garbage, trash or other form of abandoned article or item of personal property, whether solid or liquid and of whatever form, size, kind and description (hereinafter for purposes of this chapter referred to as "refuse"), or caused to be spilled, leaked, dropped, deposited, thrown, dumped, left, distributed or scattered any such refuse from any vehicle whether standing, parked or moving upon any public right-of-way, in any public park, in any public parking facility or upon any private parking facility to which the general public is invited. 
(Ord. 3-78 § 1, 1978). 
8.32.020 - Vehicle-Improperly confined refuse prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drive, operate or park any vehicle upon any public way, in any public park, in any public parking facility or in any private parking facility to which the general public is invited, and any vehicle in which any such refuse (as defined in Section 8.32.020) is not properly confined, loaded, contained, held, stored or carried. 
(Ord. 3-78 § 2, 1978). 
8.32.030 - Vehicle-Defined. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the term "vehicle" means any device capable of being moved by itself or of being propelled or drawn by other means, and shall include agricultural vehicles, tractors, locomotives and railcars, motor vehicles, bicycles and trailers. 
(Ord. 3-78 § 3, l978). 
8.32.050 - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to street cleaning or sanding by the public authorities of the City of Florence, Colorado, or any political subdivision or agency of the State of Colorado, or to the private use of sand or water facilitating the operation of a motor vehicle on snow, ice, contaminated surfaces, or to the cleansing of the area of the public way of unsafe or unclean substance. 
(Ord. 3-78 § 5, 1978). 
8.32.060 - Evidence of guilt. 
    It shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of any moving vehicle, or the person who parked the vehicle, from which the refuse (as defined in Section 8.32.010) drops, spills, leaks, is thrown, dumped, deposited, distributed, scattered or left from, committed the offense declared unlawful in Sections 8.32.010 and 8.32.020. 
(Ord. 3-78 § 6, 1978). 
Chapter 8.36 - UNDESIRABLE GROWTH 

8.36.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "City Manager" means the City Manager of the City of Florence or his or her designee. 
    "Person" means an individual, firm or corporation. 
    "Undesirable growth" means any growth or collection of undesirable plant life over ten (10) inches in height; and shall include brush, weeds, noxious and unhealthful growths and substances, or any one or more of the same. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 6(part), 1998). 
8.36.020 - Accumulation of undesirable growth prohibited-Declared a nuisance. 
    No person shall allow to accumulate upon any property owned, operated or occupied by the person within the City any undesirable growth over ten (10) inches in height, nor shall such person allow the same to accumulate on any street, sidewalk or alleyway adjacent to such property. The accumulation of undesirable growth pursuant to this chapter is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 6(part), 1998). 
(Ord. No. 10-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
8.36.030 - Notice and issuance of summons. 
A.  Upon determining or becoming otherwise aware of the existence of undesirable growth in violation of this chapter, the City Manager or his or her designee shall issue a written notice to the owner, or if the owner does not reside upon the premises, to the occupant who is not an owner, or agent in charge of any lot, building or premises in or upon which such undesirable growth may be found, or which is adjacent to any street sidewalk or alleyway in which the undesirable growth is found, which abatement notice shall advise such person of the existence of the undesirable growth. The notice shall be in writing, shall state that undesirable growth exists and constitutes a hazard or nuisance, shall inform the addressee that he or she must, within five (5) days after service or receipt of such notice, cause the undesirable growth to be removed and the property cleaned or the accumulation otherwise remedied; and shall advise the addressee of the possible penalties for noncompliance with this chapter. Such notice shall be served by mailing a copy of the notice to the address of the occupant, and to the address of the owner or agent of the property as set forth in the records of the County Assessor of Fremont County, Colorado. Proper notice shall be deemed to have been given when properly addressed and deposited in the United States Mail with the proper amount of postage attached. Such notice shall be deemed to have been received three (3) days after proper mailing. If there is more than one (1) owner of the premises, or more than one (1) occupant of the premises who is not an owner, notice as provided for herein to one (1) of the owners, or one (1) of the occupants who is not an owner, shall be deemed notice to each of the owners and each of the occupants who is not an owner. 
B.  A person upon whom notice has been served to cut, trim or remove weeds or other undesirable growth from the property, and who for a period of five (5) days after receipt of such notice shall neglect or fail to comply with the provisions of the notice shall be deemed to have violated the provisions of this chapter. Subsequent to the initial five-day period, each and every period of five (5) succeeding days of noncompliance thereafter shall constitute a separate and additional violation of this chapter. 
C.  Nothing herein shall prevent the issuance of a summons for each and every violation of this chapter. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-15-2018a, § 1, adopted Mar. 5, 2018, amended § 8.36.030 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 8.36.030 pertained to notice and derived from Ord. 6-98 § 6(part), adopted 1998; and Ord. No. 10-2016, § 2, adopted April 18, 2016. 
(Ord. No. 02-15-2018a, § 1, 3-5-2018). 
8.36.040 - Failure to comply-Work performed by City. 
    Should any person receiving notice pursuant to this chapter fail to comply within the time provided in the notice, the City Manager may order that such undesirable growth be removed and shall assess the cost of such removal against the property or premises upon which the undesirable growth was found, or which is adjacent to the street, side walk or alleyway in which the undesirable growth was found. In addition to the actual cost of removal of undesirable growth, the City Manager shall assess an additional fifteen (15) percent for overhead expenses and eight (8) percent per annum interest on the total amount due until paid. Such costs, penalty and interest may be recovered in an action against such owner or occupant, or both, and such sums shall constitute a lien against the land affected and the City Clerk shall certify such sums to the Fremont County Treasurer to be perfected and collected by the Fremont County Treasurer in accordance with Sections 31-20-105 and 106, C.R.S., this section, and Section 8.36.050 hereinafter. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 6(part), 1998).
