(Ord. No. 10-2016, § 3, 4-18-2016) 
8.36.050 - Notice of assessment and lien. 
    Subsequent to the assessment by the City Manager, as provided for in Section 8.36.040, notice of such assessment shall be sent to the owner, and the person in possession if the person in possession is different than the owner of the affected property, certified mail and return receipt requested. Such notice shall contain a statement of the costs to be assessed, together with notice that if payment is not received within thirty (30) days of receipt of the notice, the City shall place a lien on the property in the amount assessed against the land, which lien shall have priority over all other liens except general tax liens and prior special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 10-2016, § 4, 4-18-2016). 
8.36.060 - Assessed costs-Recovery at law. 
A.  In case of failure to pay the assessment or any portion thereof or any penalty or interest thereon when due, the City may recover at law from the owner of the land, from which such weeds or other undesirable growth were cut or destroyed, the amount of such assessment, with penalties and interest, in any court in Fremont County with jurisdiction. 
B.  The statement of costs made by the City Manager as provided in this chapter shall be prima facie proof of the amount due. 
C.  Writs of attachment may be issued to any sheriff, and in any such proceeding no bond shall be required of the City, nor shall any sheriff require of the City an indemnifying bond for executing any writ of attachment or writ of execution upon any judgment entered in such proceedings; and the City may prosecute appeals of writs of error in such cases without the necessity of providing bond therefore. 
D.  The City may commence an action for the recovery of costs due under this chapter, and this remedy shall be in addition to all other remedies provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10-2016, § 5, 4-18-2016). 
8.36.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of Section 8.36.020 is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount not to exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.12.010. 
    If a summons is issued for a violation of this chapter, the fact that the violation is currently remedied shall not be a defense. If a summons is issued for a violation of this chapter, there shall be a mandatory one hundred dollar ($100.00) minimum fine plus applicable surcharges and court costs assessed to cover a portion of the resources used by the city to bring the property into compliance. The mandatory minimum fine is in addition to all other remedies provide for in this chapter, but the fine assessed by the Municipal Court shall not exceed the jurisdictional limitations of the Municipal Court. Nothing herein shall limit the ability of the city to use any and all other remedies available to the city in this code or other applicable laws. Nothing herein shall limit in any way the recovery by the city for costs incurred by the city's abatement of any violation. 
(Ord. No. 02-15-2018a, § 2, 3-5-2018; Ord. No. 10-2016, § 7, 4-18-2016). 
Chapter 8.37 - UNDESIRABLE PLANTS 
Sections: 

8.37.010 - Undesirable plants. 
    Russian, Spotted and Diffuse Knapweed and Leafy Spurge are declared to be undesirable plants. 
(Ord. 20-91 § 1(part), 1991). 
8.37.020 - Declaration of nuisance. 
    Leafy Spurge, Russian Knapweed, Spotted Knapweed, and Diffuse Knapweed, and all other plants designated "undesirable plants" by the City are declared to be a public nuisance. Such action may be taken as is available for nuisance abatement under the laws of this state and the City of Florence, and as the Council, n their sole discretion, deem necessary. 
(Ord. 20-91 § 1(part), 1991). 
8.37.030 - Removal of undesirable plants by property owner required. 
    Property owners within the City of Florence shall be responsible for the elimination of undesirable plants from their property within thirty (30) days of the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. Such removal shall be accomplished in an ecologically feasible and environmentally safe manner in accordance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. 20-91 § 1 (part), 1991). 
8.37.040 - Enforcement. 
    The City shall have the right to enter upon any premises, lands, or places, whether public or private, during reasonable business hours or upon proper notice for the purpose of inspecting for the existence of undesirable plants, and shall have the right to propose, implement or enforce the management of undesirable plants upon such lands in accordance with the provisions of C.R.S. 35-5-109, which rights shall include the right of the City to remove the undesirable plants and assess the costs thereof to the landowner. 
(Ord. 20-91 § 1(part), 1991). 
8.37.050 - Penalty. 
    In addition to any costs that may be assessed against a landowner, a violation of this chapter shall be subject to the general penalty provision of this Code, § 1.12.010, in addition to any other remedies provided herein or allowed by ordinance, law, rule, or regulation. Each day a violation continues to exist shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(Ord. 20-91 § 1(part), 1991). 
(Ord. No. 9-2013, § 4, 8-5-2013) 
Chapter 8.40 - HAZARDOUS TREES[2] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
 For additional provisions concerning trees, see Ch. 12.28 of this code. 

8.40.010 - Inspection and survey of trees. 
    The City Manager or his duly appointed representative shall have the power to inspect any trees, logs or branches within the City of Florence, Colorado, whether on private or public property. The City Manager or his duly appointed representative shall, from time to time, but at least once each year, conduct a survey to determine whether there are any trees within the City in a diseased or otherwise dangerous condition detrimental to other trees or property within the City. 
(Ord. 16-78 § 1, 1978). 
8.40.020 - Notice of dangerous condition-Required. 
    Should any tree, log or branch upon any private property within the City of Florence, Colorado, be found to be in a diseased or otherwise dangerous condition such that it is deemed to be detrimental to other trees or property, the City Manager or his representative shall at once notify in writing the owner or agent of the property of the existing condition and shall direct such owner, occupant or agent to remove, eradicate, remedy or otherwise alleviate the condition. 
(Ord. 16-78 § 2, 1978). 
8.40.030 - Notice of dangerous condition-Contents. 
    The notice referred to in Section 8.40.020 shall be in writing; shall advise the addressee of the addresses and locations of those trees, logs or branches deemed to be in a dangerous condition; shall inform the addressee that he or she must remove, eradicate, remedy or otherwise alleviate the described condition within fifteen (15) days of the receipt of the notice and advise the addressee of the possible penalties for noncompliance with this chapter. Such notice shall be served by mailing a copy of the notice to the address of the occupant and to the owner or agent of the property set forth in the records of the County Treasurer of Fremont County, Colorado. Proper notice shall be deemed to have been given when properly addressed and deposited in the United States Mail with the proper amount of postage attached. Such notice shall be deemed to have been received three (3) days after proper mailing. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 7, 1998). 
8.40.040 - Failure of property owner to abate conditions-City authority. 
    In the event that the owner or agent as hereinabove described fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter after proper notice, the City Manager shall take all necessary steps to remove, eradicate, remedy, or otherwise alleviate the condition or conditions described in the notice. The owner of the subject property shall be responsible for and pay the costs incurred by the City in remedying the conditions stated in the notice. The property owner shall pay any such costs within thirty (30) days after a written bill for charges has been submitted to the property owner. The bill shall be sent certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the owner or agent of the property as maintained in the office of the County Treasurer of Fremont County, Colorado. Proper notice shall be deemed to have been given when properly addressed and deposited in the United States Mail with the proper amount of postage attached. Such notice shall be deemed to have been received three (3) days after proper mailing. Any charges not timely paid shall be assessed and collectible as a lien against the property pursuant to Chapter 3.28 of this Code. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 8, 1998). 
8.40.050 - City Manager authority. 
    The City Manager shall have the authority to care for and maintain all trees located on public property within the City of Florence, Colorado, and shall take whatever action he deems necessary to prevent the trees from becoming in any way hazardous to other trees or property within the City. 
(Ord. 16-78 § 6, 1978). 
8.40.060 - Removal of trees-Replanting. 
    Whenever any tree located on public property is removed for any reason, another tree shall be planted by the City in the same general location if practicable, but if not practicable then at another location to be decided by the City Council. 
(Ord. 16-78 § 7, 1978). 
8.40.070 - Removal of trees-Removal of stump. 
    Whenever any tree is removed for any reason, from public property within the City of Florence, the person or entity responsible for removing same shall, at the time when the tree is removed, cause the stump to be removed to a depth of six (6) inches below the level of the ground. 
(Ord. 5-79, 1979: Ord. 16-78 § 8, 1978). 
8.40.080 - Removal of diseased trees. 
    Whenever any tree, limb or branch is removed because of disease, infestation or other condition that could be transferred to and cause the ailment of surrounding healthy trees, whether on private or public property, the person or entity causing the removal of same shall immediately cause to be transported all wood, logs and branches thereof to a place designated by the City for such purposes. 
(Ord. 16-78 § 9, 1978). 
8.40.090 - Elm trees. 
    So long as there exists Dutch elm disease in the United States of America, no person shall plant an elm tree within the City of Florence, Colorado. 
(Ord. 16-78 § 10, 1978). 
Chapter 8.44 - UNSIGHTLY VEHICLES 
Sections: 

8.44.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  1.  "Unsightly vehicle" means any motor vehicle originally manufactured for operation on public streets and highways which: 
a.  Has two (2) or more cracked, broken, shattered or missing windows; or 
b.  Has one (1) or more major portions of the body missing or noticeably or strikingly damaged, such as hood, fender, trunk lid, door, roof or panel or cannot move under its own power; or 
c.  Is used for storage purposes; or 
d.  The motor vehicle has an expired registration of greater than thirty (30) days. 
2.  No vehicle shall be considered an "unsightly vehicle" if it is: 
a.  Within a fully enclosed building or solid fence at least five (5) feet in height and for which a building permit has been issued; notwithstanding any exemptions for such structures contained in the building codes currently in force in the City; 
b.  Completely encased or covered by a tarpaulin, canvas, cloth or plastic (not transparent) cover and made secure by attaching same to the vehicle or part or to the ground; or 
c.  Exempt from registration under the provisions of C.R.S. § 42-3-103, as amended. 
B.  "Unsightly vehicle part" means a major body or mechanical part originally manufactured as part of a motor vehicle or for replacement or repair of any motor vehicle including but not limited to engine, battery, wheel, differential, transmission, transfer case, drivetrain, hood, fender, trunk door, door, roof or panel. "Unsightly vehicle part" shall not include any motor vehicle part which is within a fully enclosed building or solid fence which is over five (5) feet in height, and for which a building permit has been issued; notwithstanding any exemptions for such structures contained in the building codes currently in force in the City. 
C.  "City Manager" means the City Manager of the City of Florence or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017A, § 1, 4-17-2017; Ord. 7-2007 (part), 2007). 
8.44.020 - Keeping or permitting unsightly vehicles or parts. 
    It is unlawful for any owner or occupant of any real property located within the City to keep or permit an unsightly vehicle or an unsightly vehicle part on such property, unless such property is properly zoned for the keeping of such items. It is also unlawful for any owner of an unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part to permit such unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part to remain upon public property within the City. This chapter shall not apply to persons having a valid business license from the City to engage in the business of either selling or performing repairs upon new or used motor vehicles. This chapter shall allow for one (1) unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part to be kept on private property so long as active steps are being taken to repair or restore said unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017A, § 1, 4-17-2017; Ord. 7-2007 (part), 2007). 
8.44.030 - Enforcement. 
A.  The City Manager shall enforce the provisions of this chapter in the following manner: upon finding that an unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part exists, the City Manager shall issue or cause to be issued a written notice to the owner or occupant of the property upon which the unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part is found that such unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part must be corrected or disposed of within thirty (30) days from the date of the service of such notice, and shall advise such owner or occupant of the possible penalties for noncompliance with this chapter. Such notice shall be served by handing a copy of the notice to the owner or occupant, and by mailing by certified mail return receipt requested to the address of the owner as maintained in the office of the County Treasurer of Fremont County, Colorado. Proper notice shall be deemed to have been given when properly addressed and deposited in the United States mail with the proper amount of postage attached. Such notice shall be deemed to have been received three (3) days after proper mailing. 
B.  Should such owner or occupant fail to comply with such notice, then the City Manager shall take all necessary steps to remove the unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part described after conviction in Municipal Court and the person convicted shall be responsible for and pay the costs incurred by the City in removing the unsightly vehicle or unsightly vehicle part. Such person shall pay any such costs within thirty (30) days after a written bill for charges has been mailed to the address of the owner of the property affected. Such bill shall be sent certified mail, return receipt requested. Any charges not timely paid shall be assessed and collectible as a lien against the property pursuant to Chapter 3.28 of this Code. 
(Ord. 7-2007 (part), 2007). 
Chapter 8.46 - ABANDONED VEHICLES 
Sections: 

8.46.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions apply: 
    "Abandoned motor vehicle" means a motor vehicle, as defined in this section, left unattended on public property, including any portion of a highway right-of-way, within the limits of the city, for a period longer than twenty-four (24) hours. 
    "Motor vehicle" means any self-propelled vehicle which is designed for travel on the public highways and which is generally and commonly used to transport persons and property over the public highways. 
    "Public property" means any real property having its title, ownership, use or possession held by the city. 
    "Trailer" means a camper coach, camper trailer, semitrailer, trailer coach, mobile home, motor home or utility trailer, all as defined at CRS § 42-1-102 or any other device which is designed to transport persons, animals, personal effects, or trash, or used for the occupancy of persons. 
    "Unattended" means not substantially driven by an operator. 
(Ord. No. 03-19-2018A, § 1, 4-2-2018; Ord. 8-94 § 1(part), 1994). 
8.46.020 - Abandonment of motor vehicles. 
A.  No person shall abandon a motor vehicle, or any of its constituent parts, upon public property. A motor vehicle shall be presumed abandoned if such vehicle is left unattended on public property for more than twenty-four (24) hours unless prior arrangements have been made with the Police Department to leave the motor vehicle unattended for a longer specified period of time and the Chief of the Police Department has agreed to the extension of time. 
B.  It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section that: 
1.  The motor vehicle has been left for more than twenty-four (24) hours unattended or unmoved; or 
2.  License plates or other identifying marks have been removed from the motor vehicle; or 
3.  The motor vehicle has an expired registration of greater than thirty (30) days; or 
4.  The motor vehicle has been damaged or is deteriorated so extensively that it has value only for junk or salvage; or 
5.  The motor vehicle is apparently inoperable; or 
6.  The motor vehicle is illegally parked; or 
7.  The owner has been notified by the Police Department, or other agency, to remove the motor vehicle, and it has not been moved within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 03-19-2018A, § 1, 4-2-2018; Ord. 8-94 § 1(part), 1994). 
8.46.030 - Abandonment of trailers. 
A.  No person shall abandon a trailer, or any of its constituent parts, upon public property. A trailer, as defined in Section 8.46.010 shall be presumed abandoned if such trailer is left on public property for more than twenty-four (24) hours. 
B.  It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section that: 
1.  The trailer has been left for more than twenty-four (24) hours unattended or unmoved; or 
2.  License plates or other identifying marks have been removed from the trailer; or 
3.  The trailer has an expired registration of greater than thirty (30) days; or 
4.  The trailer has been damaged or is deteriorated so extensively that it has value only for junk or salvage; or 
5.  The trailer is apparently inoperable; or 
6.  The trailer is illegally parked; or 
7.  The owner has been notified by the Police Department, or other agency, to remove the trailer, and it has not been moved within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 03-19-2018A, § 1, 4-2-2018; Ord. 8-94 § 1(part), 1994). 
8.46.040 - Emergency towing. 
    Whenever any officer of the Florence police department finds a motor vehicle or trailer, attended or unattended, standing upon any portion of a highway right-of-way in such a manner as to constitute an obstruction to traffic or proper highway maintenance, such officer is authorized to cause the motor vehicle to be moved to eliminate any such obstruction. 
(Ord. 8-94 § 1(part), 1994). 
8.46.050 - Procedure upon abandonment. 
    Upon any violation of this chapter, an officer of the Florence police department shall invoke those procedures of the model traffic code governing illegally parked vehicles including those provisions granting a police officer authority to ticket and impound the vehicle and dispose of the same if it remain unclaimed pursuant thereto. For purposes of this chapter, any reference to "motor vehicle" in the model traffic code shall include motor vehicles as well as trailers as defined herein. 
(Ord. 8-94 § 1(part), 1994). 
8.46.060 - Civil infraction. 
    An infraction of this chapter shall be civil in nature and not a criminal offense, and be subject to a mandatory minimum fine of two hundred seventy-five dollars ($275.00) per infraction in addition to applicable surcharges and court costs. The penalty provisions at CRS § 42-4-1612 are hereby expressly declared not applicable to violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-19-2018A, § 1, 4-2-2018; Ord. 8-94 § 1(part), 1994). 
Chapter 8.48 - FREEZERS, CHESTS AND REFRIGERATORS 
Sections: 

8.48.010 - Abandonment prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to abandon or discard in any public or private place any chest, closet, piece of furniture, refrigerator, freezer, icebox or other article or device having a compartment of one and one-half (1 1/2) cubic feet or more capacity, having a mechanical or magnetic lock or feature designed to keep the door in a closed position, or any article or device which is substantially airtight with the door closed. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 10(part), 1998). 
8.48.020 - Enforcement. 
    The City Manager or his or her designee shall enforce the provisions of this chapter in the following manner: Upon finding an item as described in Section 8.48.010, the City Manager or his or her designee shall issue or cause to be issued a written notice to the owner or occupant of the property upon which the item is found that such item should be corrected or disposed of within forty-eight (48) hours from the date of the service of such notice, and shall advise such owner or occupant of the possible penalties for noncompliance with this chapter. Such notice shall be served by handing a copy of the notice to the owner or occupant or by mailing by certified mail to the address of the owner or agent as maintained by the office of the County Treasurer of Fremont County, Colorado. Proper notice shall be deemed to have been given when properly addressed and deposited in the United States Mail with the proper amount of postage attached. Such notice shall be deemed to have been received three (3) days after proper mailing. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 10(part), 1998). 
8.48.030 - Penalty. 
    Should such owner or occupant fail to comply with the notice referred to in Section 8.48.020, the City Manager shall order that the item described in the notice should be immediately disposed of or corrected and shall assess the cost thereof against the property or premises on which the item is found. Such person shall pay any costs incurred by the City in the removal or correction of the violation within thirty (30) days after a written bill for charges has been mailed to the address of the property affected. Such bill shall be sent certified mail, return receipt requested. Any charges not timely paid shall be assessed and collectible as a lien against the property pursuant to Chapter 3.28 of this Code. 
(Ord. 6-98 § 10(part), 1998). 
Chapter 8.52 - HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES INCIDENTS 
Sections: 

8.52.010 - Emergency response authority designated. 
    The Florence Fire Protection District is designated the emergency response authority for hazardous substances incidents within the limits of the City of Florence, Colorado. 
(Ord. 5-84 § 1, 1984). 
8.52.020 - Statutory authorization. 
    The provisions of this chapter are authorized pursuant to the provisions of CRS, 29-22-102. The City of Florence and the Colorado State Patrol shall, as necessary, exercise continuing supervisory authority for the clean-up and removal of hazardous substances involved in incidents within the City of Florence, as the same may be defined by the Colorado Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 5-84 § 2, 1984). 
Chapter 8.56 - NOISE PROHIBITED 
Sections: 

8.56.010 - Legislative declaration. 
    The City Council of the City of Florence finds and declares that noise is a major source of environmental pollution which represents a threat to the serenity and quality of life in the City of Florence. Excess noise often has an adverse physiological and psychological effect on human beings, thus contributing to an economic loss to the community. Accordingly, it is the policy of the City to establish standards for noise level limits for various time periods and areas within the City limits of the City of Florence as well as within all areas over which the City of Florence has jurisdiction. Noise in excess of the limits provided in this chapter constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. 24-2006 (part), 2006). 
8.56.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    "Commercial zone" means a general commercial district, central historic district, or business professional district as those districts are represented on the most recent Zoning District Map of the City of Florence. 
    "db(A)" means sound levels in decibels measured on the "A" scale of a standard sound level meter having characteristics defined by the American National Standards Institute, Publication S1.4-1971. 
    "Decibel" means a unit used to express the magnitude of a change in sound level. The difference in decibels between two (2) sound pressure levels is twenty (20) times the common logarithm of their ratio. In sound pressure measurements sound levels are defined as twenty (20) times the common logarithm of the ratio of that sound pressure level to a reference level of 2 × 10-5 N/m 2 (Newton's/meter squared). As an example of the effect of the formula, a three (3) decibel change is a one hundred (100) percent increase or decrease in the sound level, and a ten (10) decibel change is a one thousand (1,000) percent increase or decrease in the sound level. 
    "Industrial zone" means a light industrial district (I-1) or heavy industrial district (I-2) as those districts are represented on the most recent Zoning District Map of the City of Florence. 
    "Motor vehicle," "motor-driven cycle," "off-highway vehicle," and "vehicle" mean the same as those definitions found at CRS 42-1-102 (1973 as amended) or any future codification. 
    "Person" means any natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation or company. 
    "Residential zone" means a residential estates district, R-1 low density residential district, R-2 low medium density residential district, R-3 high density residential district, manufactured home district, manufactured home park district, recreational vehicle park district, or planned unit development (PUD) as those districts and PUD's are represented on the most recent Zoning District Map of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 24-2006 (part), 2006). 
8.56.030 - Noise prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to make, or cause to be made, any continuous, impulsive, or periodic noise which: 
A.  Is of such unusual or exceptional character, intensity or duration that it disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of any person or causes damage to any property; or 
B.  Exceeds the levels set forth in Section 8.56.040 or Section 8.56.060. 
(Ord. 24-2006 (part), 2006). 
8.56.040 - Maximum permissible noise levels. 
A.  Every activity to which this section is applicable shall be conducted in a manner so that any noise produced is not objectionable due to intermittence, beat frequency, or shrillness. Sound levels of noise radiating from a property line at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet or more therefrom in excess of the db(A) established for the following time periods and zones shall constitute prima facie evidence that such noise is a public nuisance and an infraction hereunder: 
Zone 7:00 a.m. to 
next 7:00 p.m. 7:00 p.m. to 
next 7:00 a.m. Residential 55 db(A) 50 db(A) Commercial 60 db(A) 55 db(A) Light Industrial 70 db(A) 65 db(A) Heavy Industrial 80 db(A) 75 db(A)  
B.  In the hours between seven (7:00) a.m. and the next seven (7:00) p.m., the noise levels permitted in subsection A of this section for light industrial and heavy industrial zones may be increased by ten (10) db(A) for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes in any one (1) hour period. 
C.  Periodic, impulsive, or shrill noises shall be considered a public nuisance and an infraction hereunder when such noises are at a sound level of five (5) db(A) less than those listed in subsection A of this section. 
D.  In all sound measurements, consideration shall be given to the effect of the ambient noise level created by the encompassing noise of the environment from all sources at the time and place of such sound level measurement. 
(Ord. 24-2006 (part), 2006). 
8.56.050 - Exceptions. 
    The maximum db(A) specified in Section 8.56.040 shall not apply to sound from: 
A.  Any bell or chime from any building clock, school or church; 
B.  Any siren, whistle, or bell lawfully used by emergency vehicles or any other alarm system used in case of fire, collision, civil defense, police activity or other emergency; 
C.  Any domestic power equipment operated upon any residential, commercial, industrial or public place between seven (7:00) a.m. and nine (9:00) p.m. provided that such equipment does not exceed eighty (80) db(A); 
D.  Activities directly connected with the abatement of an emergency; 
E.  Construction projects shall be subject to the maximum permissible noise levels specified for heavy industrial zones for the period within which construction is to be completed pursuant to any applicable construction permit issued by proper authority or, if no time limitation is imposed, for a reasonable period of time for completion of the project; 
F.  All railroad rights-of-way shall be considered as light industrial zones for the purposes of this section, and the operation of trains shall be subject to the maximum permissible noise levels specified for such zone; 
G.  This section is not applicable to the use of property for purposes of conducting special events which may or may not involve motor or other vehicles, but such exception is effective only during the specific period of time within which such use of the property is authorized by the City of Florence; 
H.  This section is not applicable to the use of property by the City of Florence or any other entity not organized for profit, including, but not limited to, nonprofit corporations, or any of their lessees, licensees, or permittees, for the purpose of promoting, producing, or holding cultural, entertainment, athletic, or patriotic events, including, but not limited to, concerts, music festivals, and fireworks displays. 
(Ord. 24-2006 (part), 2006). 
8.56.060 - Maximum permissible noise levels for operation of motor vehicles, motor-driven cycles, off-highway vehicles, and other vehicles. 
A.  The City of Florence hereby prohibits the operation of motor vehicles which produce noise in excess of the sound levels in decibels, measured on the "A" scale on a standard sound level meter having characteristics established by the American National Standards Institute, Publication S1.4-1971, and measured at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the center of the lane of travel, or fifty (50) feet or more from a vehicle designed for off-highway use and within the speed limits specified in this section: 
Speed limit of 25 mph or less Speed limit of more than 25 mph  (1) Any motor vehicle with a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of six thousand pounds or more, any combination of vehicles towed by such motor vehicle, and any motor-driven cycle. 86 db(A) 90 db(A) ; (2) Any other motor vehicle, or self-propelled recreational vehicle primarily designed for off-highway use and for which registration as a motor vehicle is not required, and any combination of vehicles towed by such motor vehicle or self-propelled vehicle. 82 db(A) 86 db(A)  
B.  The City Council for the City of Florence may adopt resolutions establishing any test procedures deemed necessary. 
C.  This section applies to the total noise from a vehicle or combination of vehicles. 
D.  For the purpose of this section, a truck, truck tractor, or bus that is not equipped with an identification plate or marking bearing the manufacturer's name and manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating shall be considered as having a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of six thousand (6,000) pounds or more if the unladen weight is more than five thousand (5,000) pounds. 
E.  The maximum db(A) specified in this section shall not apply to sound from activities directly connected with the abatement of an emergency, including any siren, whistle, or bell lawfully used by emergency vehicles or any other alarm system used in case of fire, collision, civil defense, police activity or other emergency. 
F.  Sound levels of noise in excess of the above-described limits shall constitute prima facie evidence that such noise is a public nuisance and an infraction hereunder. 
(Ord. 24-2006 (part), 2006). 
8.56.070 - Exhaust systems and mufflers. 
    No person shall discharge the exhaust of any steam engine, internal combustion engine, air compressor equipment, motor boat, motor vehicle, motor-driven cycle, or other power device which is not equipped with a properly maintained exhaust system with a muffler or a spark arrestor. It is unlawful for any person to operate any engine designed to have an exhaust system using a cut-out, bypass or other similar device. 
(Ord. 24-2006 (part), 2006). 
8.56.080 - Penalty. 
    Any violation of any provision of this chapter by any person shall be considered a civil infraction and not a criminal offense, and upon a finding by a court of competent jurisdiction that a violation has occurred said person shall be subject to a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00) per infraction. 
(Ord. 24-2006 (part), 2006). 
Chapter 8.60 - USE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS BY MINORS PROHIBITED 

8.60.010 - State law-Authorization. 
    C.R.S. 25-14-301, known as the Teen Tobacco Use Prevention Act, authorizes statutory cities to enact ordinances that prohibit the possession of cigarettes or other tobacco or nicotine related products by persons under eighteen (18) years of age and to impose stricter requirements than those set forth under the Act. 
(Ord. No. 11-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
8.60.020 - Definitions. 
A.  "Minor" means any person under eighteen (18) years of age. 
B.  "Person" means an individual or business entity. 
C.  "Possession" means that a person has or holds any amount of a tobacco product anywhere on his or her person or that he or she owns or has custody of a tobacco product or has a tobacco product within his or her immediate presence and control. 
D.  "Tobacco product," means: 
1.  Product that contains nicotine or tobacco or is derived from tobacco and is intended to be ingested or inhaled by or applied to the skin of an individual; or 
2.  Device that can be used to deliver tobacco or nicotine to the person inhaling from the device, including electronic cigarettes, cigars, cigarillos, or pipes. 
3.  Notwithstanding any provision of paragraphs 1. and 2. above, "tobacco product" does not mean a product that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved as a tobacco use cessation product. 
(Ord. No. 11-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
8.60.030 - Furnishing tobacco product to minor prohibited. 
A.  A person shall not give, sell, distribute, dispense, or offer for sale a tobacco product to any person who is under eighteen (18) years of age within the City. 
B.  Before giving, selling, distributing, dispensing, or offering to sell to an individual any tobacco product, a person shall request from the individual and examine a government-issued photographic identification that establishes that the individual is eighteen (18) years of age or older; except that, in face-to-face transactions, this requirement is waived if the individual appears older than thirty (30) years of age. 
C.  A person who violates paragraph A. of this section commits a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
D.  It is an affirmative defense to a prosecution under paragraph A. of this section that the person furnishing the tobacco product, was presented with and reasonably relied upon a document that identified the individual receiving the tobacco product as being eighteen (18) years of age or older. 
(Ord. No. 11-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
8.60.040 - Purchasing tobacco product by minor prohibited. 
A.  A minor who purchases or attempts to purchase a tobacco product within the City commits a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished in accordance with the fine schedule set forth at Section 8.60.070. 
(Ord. No. 11-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
8.60.050 - Possession, use or consumption of tobacco product by minor prohibited. 
A.  A minor who has a tobacco product within his or her possession, or uses or consumes a tobacco product within the City commits a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished in accordance with the fine schedule at Section 8.60.070. 
(Ord. No. 11-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
8.60.060 - Affirmative defenses. 
    It is an affirmative defense to the offense described in Section 8.60.050 that the tobacco product was possessed or consumed under the following circumstances: 
A.  While the minor was legally upon private property with the knowledge and consent of the owner or legal possessor of such private property and the tobacco product was possessed or consumed with the consent of his or her parent or legal guardian who was present during such possession or consumption. 
B.  The possession or consumption of a tobacco product shall not constitute a violation of this section if such possession or consumption takes place for religious purposes protected by the first amendment to the United States Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 11-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
8.60.070 - Fines and penalties. 
    A minor who violates Sections 8.60.040 or 8.60.050 commits a misdemeanor and shall be fined according to the following schedule: 
A.  First offense: Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) plus fifteen dollars ($15.00) surcharge and court costs. 
B.  Second offense: Fifty dollars ($50.00) plus fifteen dollars ($15.00) surcharge and court costs. 
C.  Third offense: One hundred dollars ($100.00) plus fifteen dollars ($15.00) surcharge and court costs. 
D.  Fourth offense or more: General penalty Section 1.12.010, plus fifteen dollars ($15.00) surcharge and court costs. 
(Ord. No. 11-2016, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
Title 9 - HOUSING AND WELFARE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 9.10 - FAIR HOUSING 
Sections: 

9.10.010 - Title. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be known as the "Fair Housing Ordinance of the City of Florence, Colorado," and is authorized by the provisions of Section 24-34-501, et seq., CRS 1973, as amended. 
(Ord. 21-80 § l, 1980). 
9.10.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
A.  "Discriminate" means both segregate and separate. 
B.  "Housing" means any building, structure, vacant land or part thereof during the period it is advertised, listed or publicly advertised for sale, lease, rent or transfer of ownership; except, that "housing" shall not include any room offered for rent or lease in a single- family dwelling maintained and accepted in part by the owner or lessee of the dwelling as his household. 
C.  "Person" means one or more individuals, partnerships, associates, corporations, legal representatives, trustees, receivers, owners, lessees, proprietors, managers, employees or any agent of such person, but shall not include any nonprofit, fraternal, educational or social organization or club, unless such nonprofit, fraternal, educational or social organization or club has the purpose of promoting discrimination in the matter of housing against any person because of handicap, race, creed, color, marital status, national origin or ancestry. 
D.  "Restrictive covenant" means any specification limiting transfer, rental or lease of any housing because of handicap, race, creed, color, sex, marital status, national origin or ancestry. 
(Ord. 21-80 § 2, 1980). 
9.10.030 - Unfair housing practices. 
    It is an unfair housing practice and unlawful and prohibited: 
A.  For any person having the right of ownership or possession, or the right of transfer, sale, rental or lease of any housing, as defined in Section 9.10.020, or any agent of such person, to refuse to show, sell, transfer, rent or lease, or to refuse to receive and transmit any bona fide offer to buy, sell, rent or lease, or otherwise to deny to or withhold from any person such housing because of handicap, race, creed, color, sex, marital status, religion, national origin or ancestry; 
B.  For any person or agent to discriminate against any person because of handicap, race, creed, color, sex, marital status, religion, national origin or ancestry in the terms, conditions or privileges pertaining to any housing or the transfer, sale, rental or lease thereof, or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith, or to cause to be made any written or oral inquiry or record concerning the handicap, creed, color, sex, marital status, religion, national origin or ancestry of a person seeking to purchase, rent or lease any housing; 
C.  For any person or agent to whom application is made for financial assistance for the acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of any housing to make or cause to be made any written or oral inquiry concerning the handicap, race, creed, color, sex, marital status, religion, national origin or ancestry of any person seeking such financial assistance or concerning the handicap, race, creed, color, sex, marital status, religion, national origin or ancestry of prospective occupants or tenants of such housing, or to discriminate against any person because of handicap, race, creed, color, sex, marital status, religion, national origin or ancestry in the terms, conditions or privileges relating to the obtaining or use of any such financial assistance; 
D.  For any person or agent to include in any transfer, sale, rental or lease of housing any restrictive covenants, or for any person to honor or exercise, or attempt to honor or exercise, any restrictive covenant pertaining to housing; 
E.  For any person or agent to print or publish, or cause to be printed or published, any notice or advertisement relating to the sale, transfer, rental or lease of any housing which indicates any preference, limitation, specification or discrimination based on handicap, race, creed, color, sex, marital status, national origin or ancestry; 
F.  For any person or agent to aid, abet, incite, compel or coerce the doing of any act defined in this section as an unfair housing practice, or to obstruct or prevent any person from complying with the provisions of this chapter, or to attempt, either directly or indirectly, to commit any act defined in this section to be an unfair housing practice; 
G.  For any person or agent to discharge, demote or discriminate in matters of compensation against any employee or agent because of the employee's or agent's obedience to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 21-80 § 3, 1980). 
9.10.040 - Exemptions-Religious or denominational organizations. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to bar any religious or denominational institution or organization which is operated or supervised or controlled by, or is operated in connection with, a religious or denominational organization, from limiting admission to or giving preference to persons of the sane religion or denomination or from making such selections of buyers, lessees or tenants as are calculated by such organization or denomination to promote the religious or denominational principles for which it is established or maintained. 
(Ord. 21-80 § 4(A), 1980). 
9.10.050 - Exemptions-Gender. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to bar any person from leasing premises only to members of one sex. 
(Ord. 21-80 § 4(B), 1980). 
9.10.060 - Exemptions-Marital status zoning. 
    This chapter shall not apply to or prohibit compliance with local zoning ordinance provisions concerning residential restrictions on marital status. 
(Ord. 21-80 § 4(C), 1980). 
9.10.070 - Exemptions-Handicapped housing. 
    This chapter shall not be construed to prevent or restrict the sale, lease, rental, transfer or development of housing designed or intended for the use of the handicapped. 
(Ord. 21-80 § 4(D), 1980). 
9.10.080 - Exemptions-Gift, inheritance or devise transfer. 
    This chapter is not intended to prevent or restrict any transfer of housing by gift, inheritance or devise. 
(Ord. 21-80 § 4(E), 1980). 
9.10.090 - Complaints. 
A.  Any person claiming to be aggrieved by an unfair housing practice may, in person or by attorney, make, sign and file with the City Manager a verified written complaint, in duplicate, which states the name and address of the person alleged to have committed the unfair housing practice complained of and which sets forth the particulars thereof and contains such other information as may be required by the City Manager. 
B.  Upon filing of the complaint, the City Manager shall advise the complainant that redress can only be had by filing a complaint within ninety (90) days from the date of the alleged unfair housing practice with the Colorado Civil Rights Commission. 
(Ord. 21-80 § 5, 1980). 
Chapter 9.16 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS 
Sections: 

9.16.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "Peddler" means any person who travels within the City of Florence conveying or transporting goods, wares or merchandise or offering or exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers. 
B.  "Solicitor" means any person who travels within the City of Florence soliciting or taking or attempting to take orders for sale or purchase of goods, wares or merchandise, including magazines, books, periodicals, real or personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery or for services to be performed or for the donation of money or financial assistance, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such order, or whether or not he is collecting advance payment on such orders. Such definition includes any person who, for himself, or for another person, firm or corporation, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, motor vehicle, trailer, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, hotel or motel room, lodging house, apartment, shop, or any streets, alleys or other place within the City for the primary purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
C.  "Itinerant merchant" or "transient merchant" means any individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture, or any other commercial entity that, on a temporary basis, sells, leases, takes orders or delivers goods, wares, food, merchandise or other tangible personal property in the City by a retail sale; or makes such sale from a temporary location, which includes any location other than a building as defined at Section 17.08.015. 
D.  "Pushcart vendor" means a vendor who would otherwise be considered an itinerant merchant but who vends goods, wares, food or other merchandise on a retail basis from a pushcart that is capable of being moved by hand from one location to another. 
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
(Ord. No. 21-2008, §§ 1, 2, 12-1-2008) 
9.16.020 - License required-Application. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or transient merchant to engage in any such business within the City without first obtaining a license. A license shall be required for each person peddling, soliciting, selling or attempting to sell goods, wares or merchandise within the City. A separate license shall also be required for each temporary location within the City. 
B.  A license application for each individual shall be filed with the City Clerk on forms furnished by the City and said applicant shall provide the following information when applying in person at City Hall: 
1.  Name, social security number and birth date of the applicant; 
2.  Driver's license number, vehicle make, model, and license plate number; 
3.  Complete permanent home address of the applicant and, in the case of the transient merchant, the local address from which proposed sales will be made; 
4.  In the case of the transient merchant, written permission of the property owner upon whose property the temporary business will be conducted; 
5.  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold by each applicant; 
6.  If employed, the name, address, phone number and federal employer's identification number of the employer, together with credentials therefor establishing the exact relationship; 
7.  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
8.  The source of supply of the goods or property proposed to be sold or orders taken for the sale thereof, where such goods or products are located at the time said application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery; 
9.  State of Colorado sales tax license number; 
10.  In the case of food vendors, any and all licenses or certificates required by the State of Colorado or any of its departments, or any other regulatory agency having jurisdiction; 
11.  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, other than traffic violations, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
12.  The last three municipalities where the applicant carried on business immediately preceding the date of application and the addresses from which such business was conducted in each of those municipalities. 
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.16.030 - Exemptions. 
A.  The terms of this chapter do not include the acts of persons selling personal property at wholesale to dealers in such articles, nor to acts of merchants or their employees in delivering goods in the regular course of business; estate auctions; real estate agents and insurance agents licensed by the state; newspaper deliverers; any public utility and its employees franchised to do business within the City; auto salesmen; persons engaged in noncommercial religious activities; persons selling only religious literature; persons, groups, firms or corporations serving under the auspices of charitable, religious, civic, philanthropic, school or any licensed nonprofit organization; persons serving established business routes and persons calling by invitation; sales from time to time by residential premises owners who dispose of personal property. 
B.  Persons, firms or corporations selling goods, wares or merchandise who participate in a special event within the City, sponsored by a local group or organization, or who participate in any City-sanctioned event, shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.16.040 - Terms of license; fees. 
A.  Those peddlers, solicitors, transient merchants, or pushcart vendors desiring to peddle, solicit, sell or attempt to sell within the City shall make application to the City Clerk and, upon approval of said application, shall pay a fee pursuant to the following schedule: 
Peddlers, per day: ..... $25.00 
Solicitors, per day: ..... $25.00 
Transient merchants, per calendar year: ..... $150.00 
Pushcart vendors, per calendar year: ..... $150.00 
    The fee for all days indicated on the application shall be payable in full upon approval of the application and shall be nonrefundable. No licensee shall be entitled to a license under this chapter unless the licensee exhibits to the City Clerk a current Colorado sales tax license and any other licenses required by law. The license, when issued, shall be valid for the number of consecutive days indicated on the application and approved by the City Clerk, commencing with the time of issuance and expiring at that same time on the last licensed day. If, upon expiration of the license, the licensee wishes to continue to conduct the licensed business in the City, the licensee must reapply for a new license, subject to the limitations of Section 9.16.050. 
B.  Those peddlers, solicitors, transient merchants, or pushcart vendors desiring to peddle, solicit, sell or attempt to sell goods, food, wares or merchandise other than door-to-door may do so only in those areas of the City of Florence which are designated "C District - General Commercial," "CB District - Central Business District Commercial," or "CHB District - Central Historic Business District," as defined in Chapters 17.40, 17.44 and 17.45, respectively, of the Florence Municipal Code, and only with the written permission of the property owner upon whose property the temporary business will be conducted. Said peddler, solicitor, transient merchant or pushcart vendor shall make application to the City Clerk and, upon approval of said application, shall pay the prescribed fee per business location. The license, when issued, shall be valid for the number of consecutive days provided in Section 9.16.050, commencing with the time of issuance and expiring at that same time on the last licensed day. If, upon expiration of the license, the licensee wishes to continue to conduct the licensed business in the City of Florence, the licensee must reapply for a new license, subject to Section 9.16.050. 
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
(Ord. No. 23-2008, § 3, 12-1-2008; Ord. No. 10-2015, § 1, 12-24-2015) 
9.16.050 - Transfer of license prohibited; consecutive days designated; wait periods designated. 
    No license issued under this chapter shall be transferred or assigned, nor shall its holder conduct business in any location other than the location specified in the license, nor shall it be used by the holder for a purpose other than that for which the license was issued. A license issued under this chapter shall be issued according to the following schedule: 
Type of License Consecutive Days Allowed Wait Period for Renewal Peddler 30 days 15 days Solicitor 30 days 15 days Transient merchant 180 days 0 days Pushcart vendor 180 days 0 days  
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
(Ord. No. 23-2008, § 4, 12-1-2008) 
9.16.060 - Display of license. 
    Every person who is issued a license under the provisions of this chapter shall display the license in a conspicuous place on the premises in which the licensed activity is being conducted, or if there are no premises, shall carry the license while engaged in the activity for which he has been licensed, and moreover shall produce the license upon request of any customer, law enforcement officer or any other agent or employee of the City. 
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.16.070 - Denial or revocation of license. 
A.  The City Clerk may deny any application for a license pursuant to this chapter, and any license issued under this chapter may be revoked by order of the City Manager, or his designee, if there is a finding that the licensee has: 
1.  Misstated information contained in the application; 
2.  Violated any section of this chapter of the municipal code; 
3.  Violated any other City ordinances or regulations, or any state laws applicable to the business activity of the applicant; 
4.  Conducted the licensed business activity in such a manner as to constitute a threat to public health, safety or general welfare; 
5.  Failed to produce a State Health Department inspection report or failed a State Health Department inspection; 
6.  Been convicted of a felony. 
B.  Any applicant who has had an application for license pursuant to this chapter denied, or whose license, once issued, has been revoked, shall not be entitled to apply for any further licenses pursuant to this chapter for a period of one (1) year from the date of denial of the application or the revocation of the license. 
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.16.075 - Compliance with Title 17. 
    The use of real property by a transient merchant or pushcart vendor, other than by the owner of such real property, shall not trigger the requirements of Title 17 of this Code, except the use of such real property shall conform to the use requirements of the relevant zone district. In addition, the City Manager shall approve the location of any trailer, pushcart, tent or other temporary device employed by a transient merchant or pushcart vendor to ensure public safety. 
(Ord. No. 23-2008, § 5, 12-1-2008) 
9.16.080 - Enforcement. 
    The Florence Police Department shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.16.090 - Penalty. 
    Any person, group, corporation, partnership, or other legal entity who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished pursuant to the general penalty provisions of Section 1.12.010 of this code and be assessed costs pursuant to Section 2.16.080 of this code, as amended. 
(Ord. 6-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
Chapter 9.20 - CURFEW FOR MINORS 
Sections: 

9.20.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "Loitering" means remaining idle in essentially one location and shall include the concept of spending time idly, being dilatory, lingering, staying, sauntering, delaying, and standing around and shall also include the colloquial expressions "hanging around" and "hanging out." The term shall also include such activity by the driver or a passenger in a motor vehicle which is parked, standing or being driven on any public street, alley or parking lot. 
B.  "Public place" means any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, park, playground, or place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment, or other lawful purpose. A public place shall include but not be limited to any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, bowling alley, cafe, theater, drug store, pool room, shopping center, and any other place devoted to the amusement or entertainment of the general public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of the above. 
C.  "Going to or returning from" means travel directly to or from any activity excepted from the coverage of this chapter, which travel shall not exceed a period of thirty (30) minutes prior to the commencement of such activity or subsequent to the termination of such activity. 
(Ord. 5-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.20.020 - Juvenile loitering during nighttime hours prohibited. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to loiter or to aimlessly drive or ride about on or about any street, avenue, highway, road, sidewalk, curb, gutter, parking lot, alley, vacant lot, park, cemetery, playground, yard, building, place of amusement, or eating place, whether public or private, or any other public place, during the hours beginning at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday mornings and ending at six (6:00) a.m.; and beginning at ten (10:00) p.m. on Sunday night through Thursday night, and ending at six (6:00) a.m. the following mornings. No violation of this section will have occurred if the person under the age of eighteen (18) years is accompanied by a parent, guardian, or other adult over the age of twenty-one (21) years who is authorized, in writing, by a parent or guardian of such juvenile to take said parent's place in accompanying said juvenile for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area. 
B.  This section shall not apply, and no person shall be charged with a violation of this section or arrested therefor, if such person was: 
1.  Not loitering; or 
2.  In a parked, standing or moving motor vehicle while accompanied by a parent, guardian, or other adult person over the age of twenty-one (21) years who is authorized, in writing, by a parent or guardian of a person under the age of eighteen (18) years to take the parent's or guardian's place in accompanying the juvenile for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area; or 
3.  In a motor vehicle in interstate travel; or 
4.  Engaged in any lawful employment, or participating in any school, religious or athletic activity or going to or returning from any such activity or going to or from any other activities of any kind which are supervised or directed by adult persons over the age of twenty-one (21) years; provided that such adult persons have the authority of the parents of the persons under the age of eighteen (18) years who are participating in or attending such event or activity to conduct and to supervise the event or activity; and further provided that the group or organization has given the police department not less than seventy-two (72) hours advance, written notice of the event or activity; or 
5.  Married or an otherwise emancipated minor. 
(Ord. 5-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.20.030 - Parental responsibility. 
    It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other adult having the care and custody of a juvenile under the age of eighteen (18) years to knowingly permit or allow such juvenile to loiter or to aimlessly drive or ride about at the places and within the times prohibited by Section 9.20.020 of this chapter. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent, guardian, or other adult person having responsibility for a juvenile should be reasonably expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a juvenile in that parent's, guardian's, or other adult person's custody. It shall be no defense that a parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of the juvenile was indifferent to the activities, conduct or whereabouts of such juvenile. 
(Ord. 5-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.20.040 - Business owner or operator responsibility. 
    It shall be a violation of this Chapter 9.20 for any proprietor, owner, or operator of any public place, or any agent or employee of such proprietor, owner, or operator to permit a juvenile to remain in his establishment during the hours prohibited by this chapter unless the minor is accompanied by a parent, guardian, or other adult person over the age of twenty-one (21) years, which adult has the written authority of a parent or guardian of the juvenile to have control of the juvenile, or unless necessary for medical purposes or for an activity which is excepted from the applicability of the curfew by the terms of this chapter. Whenever a juvenile continues to remain at such an establishment after the proprietor, owner, operator or other person in charge orders him to leave, the proprietor, owner, operator or other person in charge shall immediately notify the police department of the violation. 
(Ord. 5-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.20.050 - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this Chapter 9.20 may be found guilty of a civil infraction and shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). The minimum fine provided under this section shall not be suspended by the municipal court. 
(Ord. 5-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
9.20.060 - Severability. 
    If any provision of this chapter or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this chapter which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this chapter are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. 5-96 § 1(part), 1996). 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapter 10.04 - MODEL TRAFFIC CODE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8-2013, adopted August 5, 2013, amended Chapter 10.04 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Chapter 10.04 pertained to the same subject matter, consisted of §§ 10.04.010-10.04.100, and derived from Ord. 13-2001, 2001; Ord. 11-2002, 2002; Ord. 1-2005, 2005; Ord. No. 20-2008, adopted November 17, 2008; and Ord. No. 3-2009, adopted March 2, 2009. 

10.04.010 - Code adopted by reference. 
    Pursuant to parts 1 and 2 of article 16 of title 31, C.R.S., there is hereby adopted by reference Articles I and II, inclusive, of the 2003 edition of the "Model Traffic Code for Colorado" (hereinafter "Model Traffic Code") promulgated and published by the Colorado Department of Transportation, Safety and Traffic Engineering Branch, 4201 East Arkansas Avenue, EP 700., Denver, CO 80222. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.020 - Purpose of code. 
    The subject matter of the Model Traffic Code relates primarily to comprehensive traffic control regulations for the City. The purpose of this ordinance and the Code adopted herein is to provide a system of traffic regulations consistent with state law and generally conforming to similar regulations throughout the state and nation. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.030 - Copies on file; certification. 
    At least one (1) copy of the Model Traffic Code adopted herein, certified to be true and accurate as provided by law, is now filed in the office of the Clerk of the City of Florence, Colorado, and may be inspected during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.040 - Interpretation. 
    This ordinance shall be so interpreted and construed as to effectuate its general purpose to conform with the State's uniform system for the regulation of vehicles and traffic. Article and section headings of this ordinance and adopted Model Traffic Code shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or extent of the provisions of any article or section thereof. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.050 - Application. 
    This ordinance shall apply to every street, alley, sidewalk area, driveway, park, and to every other public way or public place or public parking area, either within or outside the corporate limits of this municipality, the use of which this municipality has jurisdiction and authority to regulate. The provisions of sections 1401, 1402 and 1413 of the adopted Model Traffic Code, respectively concerning reckless driving, careless driving and eluding a police officer, shall apply to both public places and ways and private places throughout the jurisdiction of the City of Florence. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.060 - Violations and penalties. 
    The following penalties, herewith set forth in full, shall apply to this Chapter 10.04: 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions adopted in this Chapter 10.04. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided in this Chapter 10.04, every person convicted of a violation of any provision adopted in this ordinance shall be punished pursuant to the general penalty provision of this Code, § 1.12.010. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.070 - Section 902 Supplemented - Certain turns into on-street parking spaces prohibited. 
    Section 902 of the Model Traffic Code is supplemented by the addition of a new subsection 902(4) to read as follows: 
902(4). In the CHB (Central Historic Business) Zoning District of the City, the driver of any vehicle shall not cross one or more lanes of traffic for the purpose of entertaining an on-street parking place provided for vehicles traveling in the opposite direction. Left turns into an off-street parking lot, alley, private road or driveway, when not prohibited by official traffic control devices, shall be governed by Sections 702 and 901(b). 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.080 - Section 1101 modified - Speed limits. 
    Model Traffic Code-Amendment as to Speed Limit. 
    Section 1101(2)(c) ("Speed limits") of the Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities, Revised 2003 Edition, is amended to provide as follows: 
"Twenty-five (25) miles per hour in any residence district, as defined in Section 42-1-102(11), C.R.S., unless otherwise posted." 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.090 - Section 1204 modified-Places where parking is prohibited. 
    Subsection 1204(1) of the Model Traffic Code is amended by the addition of a new subsection 1204(1)(l) [following subsection 1204(1)(k)] to read as follows: 
(l)  Between the sidewalk and the curb where there is space between the sidewalk and curb; or between the sidewalk and the parking lane on any street that has no curb when there is a space between the sidewalk and the parking lane. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.100 - Section 1205 supplemented-Angle parking permitted. 
    Model Traffic Code - Amendment as to Angle Parking. 
    Angle parking shall be permitted on Colorado State Highways 115 and 67 unless official signs prohibit angle parking on portions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.110 - Section 1209 modified-Owner liability for certain violations. 
A.  Section 1209 of the Model Traffic Code is hereby re-designated as subsection 1209(1). 
B.  A new subsection 1209(2) is hereby added to read as follows: 
1209(2). In any prosecution for a violation of any ordinance governing the stopping, parking or operating of a vehicle, where the operator of the vehicle is not known, the owner of said vehicle shall be liable upon conviction for the payment of any fine assessed, unless the owner of the vehicle can furnish sufficient evidence that the vehicle was, at the time of the violation, in the care, custody or control of another person. To avoid liability for payment, the owner of the motor vehicle is required within twenty (20) days after notification by the issuance of the appropriate summons and complaint for the type of violation charged, to furnish to the municipal prosecutor the name and address of the person who had the care, custody or control of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.120 - Section 1409(4) modified-Compulsory insurance-Noncompliance-Penalty. 
    Subsection 1409(4) of the Model Traffic Code is hereby amended to read as follows: 
(4)  (a)  Any person who violates the provisions of subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this Section 1409 shall be assessed a minimum mandatory fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus court costs and any surcharges adopted by the City of Florence. The court may suspend up to one half of the fine upon a showing that appropriate insurance as required pursuant to section 10-4-619 or 10-4-624, C.R.S., as amended, has been obtained. Nothing in this paragraph (a) shall be construed to prevent the court from imposing a fine greater than the minimum mandatory fine. 
(b)  Upon a second or subsequent conviction under this section within a period of five years following a prior conviction under this section 1409, the defendant shall be punished by a minimum mandatory fin of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), plus court costs and any surcharges adopted by the City of Florence, and the court shall not suspend such minimum fine except as hereinafter provided. The court may establish a payment schedule for a person convicted of the provisions of subsection (1), (2), or (3) of this section. The court may suspend up to one half of the fine upon a showing that appropriate insurance as required pursuant to section 10-4-619 or 10-4-624, C.R.S., as amended, has been obtained. 
(c)  A violation of subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this Section 1409 shall be considered a civil infraction and not a criminal offense. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.130 - Section 1412 supplemented-Bicycles, rollerblades and skateboards prohibited on certain sidewalks. 
    A new Subsection 1412(12) is added to provide as follows: 
12.  (a)  It is unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle or use rollerblades or a skateboard on sidewalks adjacent to the 100 and 200 blocks of East Main Street and West Main Street; and sidewalks adjacent to the 100 blocks of North Pikes Peak and South Pikes Peak. 
(b)  For purposes of this section the following definitions apply: 
(1)  "Bicycle" means a device propelled by human power upon which any one (1) or more persons may ride and which is composed of one (1) or more wheels. "Bicycle" includes unicycles, tricycles and tandem bicycles. 
(2)  "Rollerblades" means a pair of shoes or boots which have attached wheels and allows the person wearing the boots to propel himself or herself along a surface. "Rollerblades" includes roller skates and in-line skates. 
(3)  "Skateboard" means a device propelled by human or motorized power upon which any person may ride, which is composed of one (1) or more wheels, none of which exceeds four (4) inches in diameter and upon which is mounted a flat board or surface designed to carry one (1) or more persons. 
(c)  The prohibition contained in paragraph (a) of this subsection shall apply without regard to whether signage prohibiting such conduct is erected at or near such locations. 
(d)  Every person convicted of a violation of this subsection 1412(12) shall be punished by a fine of forty-five dollars ($45.00) plus court costs and any surcharges adopted by the City of Florence. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013)

10.04.150 - Leaving Roadway to Avoid Traffic Control Device Prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for the driver of a motor vehicle to leave a roadway and cross public or private property to intentionally avoid an official traffic control device. Conviction of a violation of this section shall result in a fine that is double the fine provided at Section 10.04.140(A)(3) of this chapter plus court costs and any surcharges adopted by the City of Florence. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.160 - Misuse of a wireless telephone-Definition-Penalty. 
(A)  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: 
(1)  "Emergency" means a situation in which a person: 
(a)  Has reason to fear for such person's life or safety or believes that a criminal act may be perpetrated against such person or another person, requiring the use of a wireless telephone while the car is moving; or 
(b)  Reports a fire, a traffic accident in which one (1) or more injuries are apparent, a serious road hazard, a medical or hazardous materials emergency, or a person who is driving in a reckless, careless, or otherwise unsafe manner. 
(2)  "Operating a motor vehicle" means driving a motor vehicle on a public highway, but "operating a motor vehicle" shall not mean maintaining the instruments of control while the motor vehicle is at rest in a shoulder lane or lawfully parked. 
(3)  "Use" means talking on or listening to a wireless telephone or engaging the wireless telephone for text messaging or other similar forms of manual data entry or transmission. 
(4)  "Wireless telephone" means a telephone that operates without a physical, wire line connection to the provider's equipment. The term includes, without limitation, cellular and mobile telephones. 
(B)  A person under eighteen (18) years of age shall not use a wireless telephone while operating a motor vehicle. 
(C)  A person eighteen (18) years of age or older shall not use a wireless telephone for the purpose of engaging in text messaging or other similar forms of manual data entry or transmission while operating a motor vehicle. 
(D)  Subsection (B) or (C) of this section shall not apply to a person who is using the wireless telephone: 
(1)  To contact a public safety entity; or 
(2)  During an emergency. 
(E)  (1)  A person who operates a motor vehicle in violation of subsection (B) or (C) of this section commits a traffic infraction, and the court shall assess a fine of forty-five dollars ($45.00) plus court costs and any surcharges adopted by the City of Florence. 
(2)  A second or subsequent violation of subsection (B) or (C) of this section shall be a traffic infraction, and the court shall assess a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court costs and any surcharges adopted by the City of Florence. 
(F)  (1)  An operator of a motor vehicle shall not be cited for a violation of subsection (B) of this section unless the operator was under eighteen (18) years of age and a law enforcement officer saw the operator use, as defined in paragraph (3) of subsection (A) of this section, a wireless telephone. 
(2)  An operator of a motor vehicle shall not be cited for a violation of subsection (C) of this section unless the operator was eighteen (18) years of age or older and a law enforcement officer saw the operator use a wireless telephone for the purpose of engaging in text messaging or other similar forms of manual data entry or transmission. 
(G)  The provisions of this section shall not be construed to authorize the seizure and forfeiture of a wireless telephone, unless otherwise provided by law. 
(H)  This section does not restrict operation of an amateur radio station by a person who holds a valid amateur radio operator license issued by the federal communications commission. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.170 - Amendment to Model Traffic Code-Restricted use of streets. 
A.  The use of certain streets and roadways by motor-driven cycles, trucks or other commercial vehicles, bicycles, motorized bicycles and horse-drawn vehicles or other non-motorized traffic shall be restricted or prohibited when official signs giving notice thereof are erected. 
B.  For the purpose of road construction and maintenance, any street or portion thereof may, by action of this municipality or by agreement with other concerned road agencies, be temporarily closed to through traffic or to all vehicular traffic during the work project, and the traffic affected shall be guided along appropriate detours or alternative routes by official traffic control devices. 
C.  The City Manager, as traffic control engineer, may designate particular streets as restricted and prohibit truck traffic upon such streets for trucks weighing in excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds. Except as provided in subsection E, such trucks weighing in excess of ten thousand (10,000) [pounds] shall travel only upon streets designated as "truck route" and park only in designated truck parking areas. 
D.  When signs are so erected giving notice of restrictions or prohibitions upon the use of streets, no person shall disobey the directions or instructions stated on such signs. 
E.  The provisions herein shall not be construed to prohibit the drivers of any excluded vehicles from traveling over such restricted or prohibited residential streets, other than controlled-access roadways, for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise, provided such excluded vehicles enter such streets at the intersection nearest the destination of the vehicle and promptly proceed thereon no farther than the nearest negotiable intersection thereafter, and provided that such deliveries shall be between the hours of six (6:00) a.m. and six (6:00) p.m. 
F.  Subsection E of this section shall not be construed to permit an excluded vehicle to remain in a prohibited area in excess of two (2) hours absent visible evidence of loading and/or unloading of such vehicle, or absent an emergency requiring that such vehicle be parked in a prohibited area longer than two (2) hours. Except as provided hereinabove, any excluded vehicle parked in a prohibited area for longer than two (2) hours shall be presumed to be there for an unpermitted purpose. Conviction of a violation of this section shall result in a fine that is double the fine provided at Section 10.04.140(A)(3) plus court costs and any surcharges adopted by the City of Florence. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.180 - Traffic Engineer.
