A.  The office of Traffic Engineer is hereby established. The City Manager is hereby designated as the Traffic Engineer and, as such, shall exercise the powers and duties provided for in this section. 
B.  At such times as the Traffic Engineer may be absent from the city or unable to perform his duties, the said duties shall be vested in the Chief of Police or such other municipal official as may be determined and authorized by the City Manager. 
C.  Subject to (i) the review of City Council; (ii) the requirements of applicable state law; and (iii) the requirements of applicable ordinances of the city, the Traffic Engineer shall have the authority to exercise and implement any and all of the powers granted to "municipal authorities" in Section 42-4-1102, C.R.S. as amended, and as said section may be amended following the adoption of this section. All such powers are hereby incorporated into this section by this reference. 
D.  In addition to the powers and duties delegated elsewhere in this section and subject to the requirements of applicable state law, the Traffic Engineer shall have authority to cause the erection and display of appropriate official signs and other official traffic control devices and to otherwise do those things necessary to cause the implementation of any traffic regulation or designation enacted by or pursuant to any ordinance of City Council, as enumerated in subsection (1) of Section 42-4-111, C.R.S., as amended, and as said section may be amended in the future. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.190 - Validity. 
    If any part or parts of this ordinance are for any reason held to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance. The City Council hereby declares that it would have passed this ordinance and each part or parts thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one (1) part or parts be declared invalid. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.200 - Repeal. 
    Existing or parts of ordinances covering the same matters as embraced in this ordinance are hereby repealed and all ordinances or parts of ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of this ordinance are hereby repealed, except that this repeal shall not affect or prevent the prosecution or punishment of any person for any act done or committed in violation of any ordinance hereby repealed prior to this ordinance taking effect. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013, § 1, 8-5-2013) 
10.04.300 - License plates. 
A.  License plate required. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, stop, park or for the owner or person in charge of any vehicle to cause or knowingly permit to be driven, stopped or parked on any street or highway within the City or any property that is owned by the City, any vehicle that has been assigned a license plate or plates, pursuant to state law or the law of any other state, unless the license plate or plates assigned to the vehicle for the current registration year are properly attached to and displayed on the vehicle, in accordance with the laws of the state or the laws of any other state. 
B.  "License plate" construed: For purposes of this section, the term "license plate" shall include license plates, number plates, personalized license plates, special license plates and other plates, both permanent and temporary, issued pursuant to state law or the law of any other state. 
C.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, any person who violates any provision of this section, upon conviction, or upon entry of a plea of guilty in connection with a penalty assessment, shall be fined a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. Any person who violates any provision of this section for a second time within twelve (12) months shall, upon conviction, or upon entry of a plea of guilty in connection with a penalty assessment, be fined a mandatory minimum fine of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. Any person who violates any provision of this section for a third or subsequent time within twelve (12) months shall, upon conviction, or upon entry of a plea of guilty in connection with a penalty assessment, be fined a mandatory minimum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. An officer, based upon probable cause for the issuance of the citation, and with knowledge from dispatch, personal knowledge, or otherwise, may allege an elevated violation and cite the defendant with a penalty assessment reflecting such allegation of an additional violation within the time period specified above. The defendant may choose to pay the penalty assessment based upon the elevated fees associated with alleged additional violations. A defendant wishing to contest the elevated fees associated with alleged additional violations may do so at any point prior to entry of judgment by the court. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017D, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
10.04.400 - Misuse of license plates. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to display or cause or permit to be displayed on any vehicle driven, stopped, or parked on any street or highway within the City or any property that is owned by the City, any license plate, as that term is construed in Section 10.04.300B of this Code, that is not the license plate that has been assigned to that vehicle pursuant to state law or the laws of any other state. 
B.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, any person who violates any provision of this section, upon conviction, or upon entry of a plea of guilty in connection with a penalty assessment, shall be fined a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. Any person who violates any provision of this section for a second time within twelve (12) months shall, upon conviction, or upon entry of a plea of guilty in connection with a penalty assessment, be fined a mandatory minimum fine of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. Any person who violates any provision of this section for a third or subsequent time within twelve (12) months shall, upon conviction, or upon entry of a plea of guilty in connection with a penalty assessment, be fined a mandatory minimum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. An officer, based upon probable cause for the issuance of the citation, and with knowledge from dispatch, personal knowledge, or otherwise, may allege an elevated violation and cite the defendant with a penalty assessment reflecting such allegation of an additional violation within the time period specified above. The defendant may choose to pay the penalty assessment based upon the elevated fees associated with alleged additional violations. A defendant wishing to contest the elevated fees associated with alleged additional violations may do so at any point prior to entry of judgment by the court. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017D, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
10.04.500 - Licenses for drivers required. 
A.  No person shall drive any motor vehicle upon a highway or street in the City unless such person has been issued a currently valid driver's or minor driver's license or an instruction permit by the Department of Motor Vehicles. 
B.  No person shall drive any motor vehicle upon a highway or street in the City if such person's driver's or minor driver's license has been expired for one (1) year or less and such person has not been issued another such license by the Department of Motor Vehicles or by another state or country subsequent to such expiration. 
C.  No person shall drive any motor vehicle upon a highway or street in the City unless such person has in his or her immediate possession a current driver's or minor driver's license or an instruction permit issued by the Department of Motor Vehicles of the state or any other state. 
D.  No person who has been issued a currently valid driver's or minor driver's license or an instruction permit shall drive a type or general class of motor vehicle upon a highway or street in the City for which such person has not been issued the correct type or general class of license or permit. 
E.  No person who has been issued a currently valid driver's or minor driver's license or an instruction permit shall operate a motor vehicle upon a highway or street in the City without having such license or permit in such person's immediate possession. 
F.  No person shall drive a two-wheel motorcycle on a roadway, highway, or street within the City without a general motorcycle endorsement, but a person who possesses a general motorcycle endorsement may drive any validly registered and currently insured motorcycle on the roadway. 
G.  A charge of a violation of subsection B of this section shall be dismissed by the court if the defendant elects not to pay the penalty assessment and, at or before the defendant's scheduled court appearance, exhibits to the court a currently valid driver's or minor driver's license. 
H.  A charge of a violation of subsection E of this section shall be dismissed by the court if the defendant elects not to pay the penalty assessment and, at or before the defendant's scheduled court appearance, exhibits to the court a currently valid license or permit issued to such person or an officially issued duplicate thereof if the original is lost, stolen, or destroyed. 
I.  The conduct of a driver of a motor vehicle which would otherwise constitute a violation of this section is justifiable and not unlawful when: 
1.  It is necessary as an emergency measure to avoid an imminent public or private injury which is about to occur by reason of a situation occasioned or developed through no conduct of said driver and which is of sufficient gravity that, according to ordinary standards of intelligence and morality, the desirability and urgency of avoiding the injury clearly outweigh the desirability of avoiding the injury sought to be prevented by this section; or 
2.  The applicable conditions for exemption, as set forth in C.R.S. § 42-2-102, exist. 
J.  The issue of justification or exemption is an affirmative defense. As used in this subsection J, "affirmative defense" means that, unless the City's evidence raises the issue involving the particular defense, the defendant, to raise the issue, shall present some credible evidence on that issue. If the issue involved in an affirmative defense is raised, then the liability of the defendant must be established beyond a reasonable doubt as to that issue as well as all other elements of the traffic infraction. 
K.  Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of class B traffic infraction and subject to a mandatory minimum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
L.  Notwithstanding any law to the contrary, a second or subsequent conviction under subsection A or D of this section, when a person receiving such conviction has not subsequently obtained a valid state driver's license or the correct type or general class of license, shall result in the assessment by the department of six (6) points against the driving privilege of the person receiving such second or subsequent conviction and a mandatory minimum fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
M.  The following persons need not obtain a Colorado driver's license: 
1.  Any person who operates a federally owned military motor vehicle while serving in the armed forces of the United States; 
2.  Any person who temporarily drives or operates any road machine, farm tractor, or other implement of husbandry on a highway; 
3.  Any nonresident who is at least sixteen (16) years of age and who has in his or her immediate possession a valid driver's license issued to such nonresident by his or her state or country of residence. A nonresident who is at least sixteen (16) years of age and whose state or country of residence does not require the licensing of drivers may operate a motor vehicle as a driver for not more than ninety (90) days in any calendar year, if said nonresident is the owner of the vehicle driven and if the motor vehicle so operated is duly registered in such nonresident's state or country of residence and such nonresident has in his or her immediate possession a registration card evidencing such ownership and registration in his or her own state or country. 
4.  A nonresident on active duty in the armed forces of the United States if that person has in his or her possession a valid driver's license issued by such nonresident's state of domicile or, if returning from duty outside the United States, has a valid driver's license in his or her possession issued by the armed forces of the United States in foreign countries, but such armed forces license shall be valid only for a period of forty-five (45) days after the licensee has returned to the United States; 
5.  The spouse of a member of the armed forces of the United States who is accompanying such member on military or naval assignment to this state, who has a valid driver's license issued by another state, and whose right to drive has not been suspended or revoked in this state; 
6.  Any nonresident who is temporarily residing in Colorado for the principal purpose of furthering such nonresident's education, is at least sixteen (16) years of age, has a valid driver's license from his or her state of residence, and is considered a nonresident for tuition purposes by the educational institution at which such nonresident is furthering his or her education. 
7.  Any person who has in his or her possession a valid driver's license issued by such person's previous state of residence shall be exempt, for thirty (30) days after becoming a resident of the state of Colorado, from obtaining a license, as provided in C.R.S. § 42-2-101. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017D, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
10.04.600 - Unlawful use or possession of a license. 
A.  1.  No person shall have in such person's possession a lawfully issued driver's, minor driver's, or temporary driver's license or instruction permit, knowing that such license or permit has been falsely altered by means of erasure, obliteration, deletion, insertion of new matter, transposition of matter, or any other means so that such license or permit in its thus altered form falsely appears or purports to be in all respects an authentic and lawfully issued license or permit. 
2.  No person shall fraudulently obtain a driver's, minor driver's, or temporary driver's license or an instruction permit. 
B.  No person shall have in such person's possession a paper, document, or other instrument which falsely appears or purports to be in all respects a lawfully issued and authentic driver's, minor driver's, or temporary driver's license or instruction permit. 
C.  No person shall display or represent as being such person's own any driver's, minor driver's, or temporary driver's license or any instruction permit which was lawfully issued to another person. 
D.  No person shall fail or refuse to surrender or present to a police officer upon lawful demand any driver's, minor driver's, or temporary driver's license or any instruction or temporary permit issued to such person which has been suspended, revoked, or cancelled by the department. 
E.  No person shall permit any unlawful use of a driver's license issued to such person. 
F.  No person shall photograph, photostat, duplicate, or in any way reproduce any driver's license or facsimile thereof for the purpose of distribution, resale, reuse, or manipulation of the data or images contained in such driver's license. 
G.  Any person who violates this section shall, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined a mandatory minimum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017D, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
10.04.700 - Operation of vehicle approached by emergency vehicle-Operation of vehicle approaching stationary emergency vehicle or stationary towing carrier vehicle. 
A.  Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle making use of audible or visual signals meeting the requirements of C.R.S. Section 42-4-213 or 42-4-222, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and where possible shall immediately clear the farthest left-hand lane lawfully available to through traffic and shall drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the right-hand edge or curb of a roadway clear of any intersection and shall stop and remain in that position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed, except when otherwise directed by a police officer. 
B.  1.  A driver in a vehicle that is approaching or passing a stationary authorized emergency vehicle that is giving a visual signal by means of flashing, rotating, or oscillating red, blue, or white lights as permitted by C.R.S. Section 42-4-213 or 42-4-222, or a stationary towing carrier vehicle that is giving a visual signal by means of flashing, rotating, or oscillating yellow lights shall exhibit due care and caution and proceed as described in paragraphs 2 and 3 of this subsection B. 
2.  On a highway with at least two (2) adjacent lanes proceeding in the same direction on the same side of the highway where a stationary authorized emergency vehicle or stationary towing carrier vehicle is located, the driver of an approaching or passing vehicle shall proceed with due care and caution and yield the right-of-way by moving into a lane at least one (1) moving lane apart from the stationary authorized emergency vehicle or stationary towing carrier vehicle, unless directed otherwise by a peace officer or other authorized emergency personnel. If movement to an adjacent moving lane is not possible due to weather, road conditions, or the immediate presence of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, the driver of the approaching vehicle shall proceed in the manner described in paragraph 3 of this subsection B. 
3.  On a highway that does not have at least two (2) adjacent lanes proceeding in the same direction on the same side of the highway where a stationary authorized emergency vehicle or stationary towing carrier vehicle is located, or if movement by the driver of the approaching vehicle into an adjacent moving lane, as described in paragraph 2 of this subsection B, is not possible, the driver of an approaching vehicle shall reduce and maintain a safe speed with regard to the location of the stationary authorized vehicle or stationary towing carrier vehicle, weather conditions, road conditions, and vehicular or pedestrian traffic and proceed with due care and caution, or as directed by a peace officer or other authorized emergency personnel. 
C.  1.  A driver in a vehicle that is approaching or passing a maintenance, repair, or construction vehicle that is moving at less than twenty (20) miles per hour shall exhibit due care and caution and proceed as described in paragraphs 2 and 3 of this subsection C. 
2.  On a highway with at least two (2) adjacent lanes proceeding in the same direction on the same side of the highway where a stationary or slow-moving maintenance, repair, or construction vehicle is located, the driver of an approaching or passing vehicle shall proceed with due care and caution and yield the right-of-way by moving into a lane at least one (1) moving lane apart from the vehicle, unless directed otherwise by a peace officer or other authorized emergency personnel. If movement to an adjacent moving lane is not possible due to weather, road conditions, or the immediate presence of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, the driver of the approaching vehicle shall proceed in the manner described in paragraph 3 of this subsection C. 
3.  On a highway that does not have at least two (2) adjacent lanes proceeding in the same direction on the same side of the highway where a stationary or slow-moving maintenance, repair, or construction vehicle is located, or if movement by the driver of the approaching vehicle into an adjacent moving lane, as described in paragraph 2 of this subsection C, is not possible, the driver of an approaching vehicle shall reduce and maintain a safe speed with regard to the location of the stationary or slow-moving maintenance, repair, or construction vehicle, weather conditions, road conditions, and vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and shall proceed with due care and caution, or as directed by a peace officer or other authorized emergency personnel. 
D.  1.  A driver in a vehicle that is approaching or passing a motor vehicle where the tires are being equipped with chains on the side of the highway shall exhibit due care and caution and proceed as described in paragraphs 2 and 3 of this subsection D. 
2.  On a highway with at least two (2) adjacent lanes proceeding in the same direction on the same side of the highway where chains are being applied to the tires of a motor vehicle, the driver of an approaching or passing vehicle shall proceed with due care and caution and yield the right-of-way by moving into a lane at least one (1) moving lane apart from the vehicle, unless directed otherwise by a peace officer or other authorized emergency personnel. If movement to an adjacent moving lane is not possible due to weather, road conditions, or the immediate presence of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, the driver of the approaching vehicle shall proceed in the manner described in paragraph 3 of this subsection D. 
3.  On a highway that does not have at least two (2) adjacent lanes proceeding in the same direction on the same side of the highway where chains are being applied to the tires of a motor vehicle, or if movement by the driver of the approaching vehicle into an adjacent moving lane, as described in paragraph 2 of this subsection D, is not possible, the driver of an approaching vehicle shall reduce and maintain a safe speed with regard to the location of the motor vehicle where chains are being applied to the tires, weather conditions, road conditions, and vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and shall proceed with due care and caution, or as directed by a peace officer or other authorized emergency personnel. 
E.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this code, any person who violates any provision of this section, upon conviction shall be fined a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs and four (4) points shall be assessed against their driving privileges. Any person who violates any provision of this section for a second time shall, upon conviction, be fined a mandatory minimum fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs and four (4) points shall be assessed against their driving privileges. Any person who violates any provision of this section for a third or subsequent time shall, upon conviction, be fined a mandatory minimum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs and four (4) points shall be assessed against their driving privileges. 
(Ord. No. 02-21-2017J, § 1, 3-6-2017) 
10.04.900 - Accident involving damage-Duty. 
A.  The driver of any vehicle directly involved in an accident resulting only in damage to a vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident or as close thereto as possible but shall immediately return to and in every event shall remain at the scene of such accident until the driver has complied with Section 10.04.1000 and has been instructed or allowed to leave by law enforcement. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. Any person who violates any provision of this subsection A is, upon conviction, subject to a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
B.  When an accident occurs on the traveled portion, median, or ramp of a divided highway and each vehicle involved can be safely driven, each driver shall move such driver's vehicle as soon as practicable off the traveled portion, median, or ramp to a frontage road, the nearest suitable cross street, or other suitable location to fulfill the requirements of Section 10.04.1000. Any person who violates any provision of this subsection B is, upon conviction, subject to a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017E, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
10.04.1000 - Duty to give notice, information, and aid. 
A.  The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to, serious bodily injury to, or death of any person or damage to any vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall give the driver's name, the driver's address, and the registration number of the vehicle he or she is driving and shall upon request exhibit his or her driver's license to the person struck or the driver or occupant of or person attending any vehicle collided with and where practical shall render to any person injured in such accident reasonable assistance, including the carrying, or the making of arrangements for the carrying, of such person to a physician, surgeon, or hospital for medical or surgical treatment if it is apparent that such treatment is necessary or if the carrying is requested by the injured person. 
B.  In the event that none of the persons specified are in condition to receive the information to which they otherwise would be entitled under subsection A of this section and no police officer is present, the driver of any vehicle involved in such accident after fulfilling all other requirements of subsection A of this section, insofar as possible on the driver's part to be performed, shall immediately report such accident to the nearest office of a duly authorized police authority as required in Section 10.04.1000 and submit thereto the information specified in subsection A of this section. 
C.  Any person who violates any provision of this section is, upon conviction, subject to a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017E, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
10.04.1100 - Misuse of a wireless telephone-Definitions-Penalty. 
A.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: 
1.  "Emergency" means a situation in which a person: 
a.  Has reason to fear for such person's life or safety or believes that a criminal act may be perpetrated against such person or another person, requiring the use of a wireless telephone while the car is moving; or 
b.  Reports a fire, a traffic accident in which one (1) or more injuries are apparent, a serious road hazard, a medical or hazardous materials emergency, or a person who is driving in a reckless, careless, or otherwise unsafe manner. 
2.  "Operating a motor vehicle" means driving a motor vehicle on a public highway, but "operating a motor vehicle" shall not mean maintaining the instruments of control while the motor vehicle is at rest in a shoulder lane or lawfully parked. 
3.  "Use" means talking on or listening to a wireless telephone or engaging the wireless telephone for text messaging or other similar forms of manual data entry or transmission. 
4.  "Wireless telephone" means a telephone that operates without a physical, wireline connection to the provider's equipment. The term includes, without limitation, cellular and mobile telephones. 
B.  A person under eighteen (18) years of age shall not use a wireless telephone while operating a motor vehicle. 
C.  A person eighteen (18) years of age or older shall not use a wireless telephone for the purpose of engaging in text messaging or other similar forms of manual data entry or transmission while operating a motor vehicle. 
D.  Subsection B or C of this section shall not apply to a person who is using the wireless telephone: 
1.  To contact a public safety entity; or 
2.  During an emergency. 
E.  1.  A person who operates a motor vehicle in violation of subsection B or C of this section commits a class A traffic infraction and, upon conviction is subject to a mandatory minimum fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
2.  A second or subsequent violation of subsection B or C within a one-year period of this section shall be a class A traffic infraction and, upon conviction is subject to a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
F.  1.  An operator of a motor vehicle shall not be cited for a violation of subsection B of this section unless the operator was under eighteen (18) years of age and a law enforcement officer saw the operator use, as defined in paragraph 3 of subsection A of this section, a wireless telephone. 
2.  An operator of a motor vehicle shall not be cited for a violation of subsection C of this section unless the operator was eighteen (18) years of age or older and a law enforcement officer saw the operator use a wireless telephone for the purpose of engaging in text messaging or other similar forms of manual data entry or transmission. 
G.  The provisions of this section shall not be construed to authorize the seizure and forfeiture of a wireless telephone, unless otherwise provided by law. 
H.  This section does not restrict operation of an amateur radio station by a person who holds a valid amateur radio operator license issued by the federal communications commission. 
(Ord. No. 04-03-2017E, § 1, 4-17-2017). 
Chapter 10.08 - TRAFFIC REGULATIONS ON STATE HIGHWAYS 

10.08.010 - Encroachments prohibited. 
    No commercial activity or encroachment shall be permitted within the right-of-way boundaries of State Highway 115 in the City of Florence and the width from curb to curb of such streets shall be a minimum of fifty-eight (58) feet. 
(Ord. 13-2001 § 2(part), 2001). 
10.08.020 - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation that violates Section 10.08.010 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by the general penalty section of this code. 
(Ord. 13-2001 § 2(part), 2001). 
Chapter 10.12 - RAILROADS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
 For statutory provisions authorizing cities to regulate railroad companies within the city, see C.R.S. 31-15-501(f). 

10.12.010 - Speed limit for locomotives. 
    It is unlawful for any person having charge of any locomotive or train of cars on any railroad through, into or out of the City of Florence, to run said locomotive or train of cars at a greater speed than forty (40) miles per hour. 
(Ord. 13-2001 § 3(part), 2001). 
10.12.020 - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation that violates Section 10.12.010 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by the general penalty section of this code. 
(Ord. 13-2001 § 3(part), 2001). 
Chapter 10.16 - SITTING UPON OR LEANING AGAINST VEHICLES 

10.16.010 - Prohibited acts. 
    It is unlawful for any person to lean against, sit upon, interfere with or otherwise have any contact with any motor vehicle, trailer or other type of means of conveyance upon the public streets, roads, or alleyways within the City of Florence, other than his own, without the permission of the owner thereof. 
(Ord. 13-2001 § 4(part), 2001). 
10.16.020 - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation that violates Section 10.16.010 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by the general penalty section of this code. 
(Ord. 13-2001 § 4(part), 2001). 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
 For statutory provisions authorizing cities to prevent and remove encroachments and obstructions on streets and sidewalks, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-702 (1)(a)(I) and (III) (1975 Supp.) 

12.04.010 - Obstructing sidewalks prohibited-Exceptions. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to obstruct any part of the sidewalk in this city with boxes, barrels, casks, crates, tables, or displays of merchandise, or any other article or thing whatever; provided, that merchants, mechanics, artisans or other residents of the city may occupy a reasonable space upon said sidewalks with boxes, barrels, crates, casks or other shipping receptacles for a time necessary to unpack or remove the same within his shop or place of business and no longer. 
    This section shall not apply to encroachments provided for in Section 12.04.060. 
(Ord. No. 09-05-2017A-1, § 1, 10-2-2017; Ord. 139 § 1, 1898). 
12.04.020 - Obstruction of public ways. 
    No person or persons shall, in this City, erect any fence, house or other obstruction, or dig any pit or hole in or upon any of the streets, sidewalks, alleys or public grounds of the City except for the purpose of uncovering any water or gas pipe, or in excavating to lay the same, or place thereon any stone, timber, trees or any obstruction whatsoever. 
(Ord. 201 § l, 1903). 
12.04.030 - Crossing streets. 
    No person shall occupy any crosswalk, or any public highway or public place in this city, by any animal or vehicle or both attached, a longer time than may be necessary to cross the same. 
(Ord. 201 § 2, 1903). 
12.04.040 - Vehicles on sidewalks. 
    No person shall ride, drive or place any beast of burden or vehicle upon any sidewalk, otherwise than going into or out of any premises owned or occupied by him or her or by his or her employees. 
(Ord. 201 § 3, 1903). 
12.04.050 - Stone, coal and firewood on sidewalks. 
    No person shall leave or permit to be left, any stone, coal, firewood or other material upon any sidewalk in this city. 
(Ord. 201 § 4, 1903). 
12.04.060 - Encroachments. 
A.  No person or property owner may encroach or obstruct upon the city's right-of-way by placing any item upon any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk, highway, public place, or public grounds within the city, except as specifically provided below. The provisions providing for encroachment, below, only allow for such encroachment by approved items in the city's right-of-way on sidewalks and shall not allow for encroachment or obstruction of the city's right-of-way in any street, avenue, alley, highway, public place or public grounds. These provisions providing for encroachment, below, shall also only allow approved encroachment within the Central Historic Business District, as defined in Chapter 17.45, and pursuant to the provisions below. 
B.  Property owners wishing to encroach upon city right-of-way shall provide proposed plans showing details including but not limited to, the size, material, placement, and use, of the items the property owner wishes to place within the city's right-of-way. If necessary, the City Manager may request further information regarding the proposed encroachment. If the City Manager does not approve the request, the property owner may appeal the decision of the City Manager to the City Council. The City Council's decision will be final. 
C.  After approval, property owners may be permitted to place approved items on the sidewalks in front of their property, provided that at all times a minimum of sixty (60) inches of clearance is maintained for pedestrian traffic; however, in areas where a tree is present, the required minimum clearance for pedestrian traffic shall be forty-eight (48) inches. At all times, the applicable above minimum clearances shall be maintained vertically to a height of eighty-four (84) inches. Required minimum clearances shall be measured from the outside, street side, of the curb and include the curb. Minimum clearances shall be maintained throughout the radius of street corners. 
D.  All approved items, including sandwich board signs and merchandise displays, shall be placed against the building in a manner so as to provide as straight and consistent a path as possible and comply with the minimum width requirements in this section. However, trees, trashcans, benches and planters may be placed closer to the street side of the sidewalk so long as the minimum clearances are maintained at all times. 
E.  Merchandise displays may only be placed outside during business hours and must be brought inside the property at closing and remain inside until the beginning of the next business day. Under no circumstances shall any merchandise displays be left outside overnight on the city's right-of-way. 
F.  Restaurants with outdoor seating must fence in the outdoor seating area and maintain the required minimum clearance in this section. Umbrellas may be placed within fenced seating areas so long as the above required minimum clearances are maintained. 
G.  No approved item may, at any time, pose a threat, or be altered to pose a threat, to the health, safety, or welfare of the public. 
H.  Sandwich board signs must be placed against the building and may not reduce the above minimum clearances for pedestrian traffic below the minimum distances required under Section 12.04.060A. Sandwich board signs may under no circumstances be left outside overnight on the city's right-of-way. If there is no building on the property, all sandwich board signs must be anchored and may not be placed in the city's right-of-way. Sandwich board signs must also comply with the city's sign code. 
I.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this code, any person who violates any provision of this section, upon conviction shall be fined a mandatory minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus any applicable surcharges and court costs. Each and every day a violation is committed, exists, or continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
J.  Nothing herein shall prevent the city pursuing any and all remedies available, including but not limited to, removal of any encroachment. 
K.  On days of special events, which have been authorized by the City Council, from the hours of 7:00 a.m.-10:00 p.m. on the day(s) of the event, property owners may encroach upon the city's sidewalks, with merchandise displays, sandwich board signs, benches, plants and or planters, so long as the required minimums in Section 12.04.060C are maintained and items do not pose a threat to the health, safety, or welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 09-05-2017A-1, § 2, 10-2-2017; Ord. 201 § 5, 1903). 
12.04.100 - Definition of pedestrian loitering. 
    When used in this chapter, the term "loitering" means remaining idle in essentially the same location and shall include the concept of spending time idly; to be dilatory; to linger; to stay; to saunter; to delay; to stand around; and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around," or "hanging out." 
(Ord. 10-2002(part), 2002). 
12.04.110 - Pedestrian loitering-Prohibited acts. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to loiter either alone or in consort with others: 
1.  On any portion of any street or highway located between the sidewalks or between the curbs, or on any portion of the vehicular traveled portion of any street, highway, or alley which does not have abutting sidewalks or curbs, in such a manner as to obstruct such vehicular-traveled portion of any street, highway, or alley, or so as to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles; or 
2.  On any sidewalk in such a manner so as to obstruct the sidewalk or in any manner as to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of pedestrians. 
B.  When any person causes or creates any of the conditions enumerated in subsection A of this section, a police officer or any other law enforcement officer shall order that person to stop causing or creating such conditions and to move on or disperse. 
(Ord. 10-2002(part), 2002). 
12.04.120 - Affirmative defense to pedestrian loitering. 
    It shall be an affirmative defense to the alleged offenses enumerated in Section 12.04.110, that the defendant's acts were lawful and that he or she was exercising his or her rights of lawful assembly as a part of a peaceable and orderly petition for the redress of grievances either in the course of labor disputes or otherwise. 
(Ord. 10-2002(part), 2002). 
12.04.130 - Penalty for pedestrian loitering. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished pursuant to Section 1.12.010 of this Code. 
(Ord. 10-2002(part), 2002). 
Chapter 12.06 - EXCAVATIONS AND STREET CONSTRUCTION* 
Sections: 

12.06.010 - Statutory authorization. 
    The ordinance codified at this chapter is authorized pursuant to the provisions of Colorado Revised Statutes, 31-15-702, as amended. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.020 - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to modify or construct any driveway within the public right-of-way, or to extend or construct any street, alley, or sidewalk, or to bore, jack, dig up, open, excavate or cause to be dug up, opened or excavated any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place belonging to the City with having first secured a permit from the City Manager. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.030 - Permit kept on site. 
    Such permit shall be kept at the site of the excavation while the work is in progress and shall be exhibited upon request to any police officer, the City Manager or to any other authorized representative of the City. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.040 - Work prohibited without permit-Double fee for permit required when. 
    Any person extending or constructing any street, driveway (within the public right-of-way), alley, or public sidewalk, or making a cut or excavation in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place belonging to the City without first having obtained a City permit as provided in this chapter shall have all operations suspended by the City Manager and shall obtain a City permit applicable to that particular cut or excavation and shall pay twice the usual fee that would have been charged if a permit had been properly obtained prior to making the cut or excavation. Such penalty fees shall be in addition to any penalties that may be imposed by a court for violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.050 - Emergency work-Permit procedure. 
    Any person may make an emergency cut or excavation in any street, alley, sidewalk or other place belonging to the City. For the purpose of the section, the word "emergency" is expressly defined as an unforeseen event or situation that constitutes an immediate peril to life or property. However, such person must, the first working day after making such cut or excavation, notify the City Manager of such cut or excavation and obtain a permit and pay the ordinary fee required. Failure to make such notification and obtain the required permit shall result in suspension as provided in Section 12.06.040. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.060 - Permit-Application-Contents required. 
    Application for permits to excavate, modify, or construct, including applications to create a driveway entrance from a public thoroughfare, shall be made upon a form provided by the City Manager and shall recite specifically and illustrate by sketch or plan the exact location and approximate depth, length, width, extent, nature and purpose of the construction or excavation to be made, the duration of time required for the work and any other pertinent data requested by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.070 - Permit-Issuance requirements. 
    Every applicant, before being granted a permit under the provisions of this chapter, shall, in addition to the filing fee required in Section 12.06.110, furnish the City with proof of insurance in such form as is approved by the City Manager with an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Colorado with the following provisions for coverage: 
A.  Bodily injury liability including motor vehicle in the amount of: 
1.  One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person, 
2.  Three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for each accident; 
B.  Property damage liability including motor vehicle in the amount of: 
1.  Twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each occurrence, 
2.  Fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) aggregate; 
C.  Such proof of insurance shall be specified for all operations of the permittee and for all of his vehicles to be used in the course of his operations in the City. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.080 - Bond requirements. 
    Every applicant, before being granted a permit under the provisions of this chapter, shall provide to the City a license and permit surety bond from a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Colorado, in the penal sum of three thousand dollars ($3000.00) to secure performance of excavations by permittee in accordance with this chapter. The terms of such license and permit bond shall provide that the bond shall be forfeited if the permittee violates any provision of this chapter. Such bond shall remain in full force and effect for a period of one (1) year commencing upon the date of issuance of excavation permit. This bond requirement shall not apply to property owner(s) performing work on single family residential property owned and occupied by said owner(s) as their primary residence. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.090 - Permit-Issuance-Conditions. 
    All City permits shall be issued according to the provisions of this chapter and subject to such rules, directions and limitations regarding the scope of work and the time required for that work and the manner in which the work is to be performed as the City Manager may prescribe, which requirements are intended to provide for the proper care and protection of the streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public places of the City and persons and property of the general public. The City Manager may require supporting documentation from the permit applicant, such as traffic studies, drainage studies, and engineered plans. Upgrading of supporting and collecting streets and thoroughfares may also be required. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.100 - Permittee qualifications. 
    Permits shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter only to those persons who are licensed as excavators or determined by the City Manager to be duly qualified as excavators or license sewer contractors, structural contractors, sewer layers or plumbers performing work for which they are licensed. This qualification requirement shall not apply to property owner(s) performing work on single family residential property owned and occupied by said owner(s) as their primary residence. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.110 - Permit-Issuance requirements-Resurfacing and repaving. 
    The City of Florence is under no obligation to repave or resurface any excavation within the City. If the City agrees to perform resurfacing or repaving for an excavation then the permit shall so specify. The City Manager shall specify upon the permit the cost of such resurfacing or repaving to be performed by the City. Permittee shall pay such costs in advance together with the permit fee required under this chapter. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.120 - Fee schedule. 
    The fee for an excavation, construction, or driveway access permit shall be as specified in the City's adopted fee schedule, together with any costs assessed in advance for repaving or resurfacing to be performed by the City in such sum as the City Manager specifies. For major developments, as defined by the City Manager, the permittee shall also pay all costs associated with engineering reviews and additional design information required by the City Manager or City Engineer. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.130 - Protection of utilities-Permittee duty. 
    The applicant for any permit under this chapter shall be directed and is required to inquire to the utility companies and to the City as to the location of underground facilities that might be affected by the proposed cut or excavation. Upon request by the City Manager, the applicant shall disclose the location of any such facilities. Permittees shall be solely responsible for any loss or injury to any utility line or facility caused by any cut or excavation by permittee. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.140 - Boring or tunneling required when-City Manager determination. 
    If the City Manager determines it to be in the best interest of the City to require the applicant to bore, jack or tunnel a utility line or other line that is to be placed in the public right-of-way, instead of making a street cut or excavation therefore, he shall have the authority to impose such requirement and issue a permit for such boring, jacking or tunneling pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.150 - Duty to make corrections. 
    Any person who cuts, opens, digs, excavates, or causes to be dug up, opened or excavated any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place within the City shall at the conclusion of excavations restore the entire area affected to its original condition. All excavations shall be completed within three (3) weeks of the date of issuance of permit. All waste construction or excavating materials shall be removed from the site. Any ditches, gutters, culverts, storm sewers or drain pipes shall be left open, unblocked and in operating condition. Such permittee or persons shall be required to repave or resurface said street, alley, sidewalk or other public except as otherwise required by this chapter. In the event of settlement, subsidence, or failure of a repair made by the permittee of a particular excavation or cut or part thereof within a period of one (1) year after the excavation permit is issued, the permittee who had performed the excavation work shall be notified by the City Manager and given two (2) weeks time in which to correct the condition to the satisfaction of the City Manager. If the permittee fails to correct the condition to the satisfaction of the City Manager, then the City may correct the condition and the permittee shall be responsible for repaving and repair costs occasioned thereby. Furthermore, the permittee shall discontinue any and all other excavation work within the public rights-of-way within the City, and shall be issued no additional excavation permits until such time as the required repair has been completed and paid for by permittee. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.160 - Excavation, backfill, and construction standards for alleys, sidewalks, streets, drainage facilities, sewers, water lines, and other public or private facilities within public easements or rights-of-way. 
    The City of Florence has adopted "by reference" the February 26, 2001 Edition of the "STANDARD CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS AND STANDARD DETAILS FOR CITY OF PUEBLO, COLORADO, DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS" as the standard for the items listed in this section. Those standards shall be known as the "Florence Street Standards". The City Manager is given the authority to make interpretations and minor modifications to the Florence Street Standards for any conflicting or unclear items. In the event portions of the Florence Street Standards conflict with the Florence Subdivision Regulations or adopted building codes, the building codes and subdivision regulations shall prevail and supercede any such conflicting provision in the Florence Street Standards. The Fremont Sanitation District will remain responsible for all elements of the sanitary sewer facility design, construction, and maintenance within the City of Florence. In the event portions of the Florence Street Standards conflict with the sanitary sewer design standards currently used by the Fremont Sanitation District the requirements of the Fremont Sanitation District shall prevail and supercede any such conflicting provision in the Florence Street Standards. The Florence "Minimum Street Design Standards" presented in Table 1 of Appendix A, Part II Section 2, of the Florence Subdivision Regulations shall prevail as minimum standard for the design parameters listed in that table. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.170 - Major street extensions and additions to street system. 
    Additional information may be required. The City Manager may require competent design reports, drainage studies, traffic studies, upgrades to adjacent thoroughfares, and upgrades to other thoroughfares that may be significantly impacted by the project for which a permit is requested. The permittee must pay all costs associated with the required studies, engineering review, and the upgrades. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.180 - Barricades required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to dig or cause to be dug an hole, cut, drain, ditch or any other excavation in any street, alley, sidewalk or public place belonging to the City without providing during the nighttime sufficient warning lights to be placed with suitable barricade or temporary fence around such hole, cut, drain, ditch or other excavation. During the daytime, the barricade or temporary fence shall be maintained and kept in place, but warning lights shall not be required. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.190 - Traffic safety devices-Required. 
    Every hole, cut, drain, ditch or other excavation in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place belonging to the City shall be further protected at all times by traffic safety devices as prescribed by the City Manager in order to minimize the disruption of the flow of traffic in the vicinity of the work. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.200 - Traffic safety devices-Damaging or removing unlawful. 
    It is unlawful to damage, displace, remove or interfere with any barricades or temporary fence, warning light or other safety device which is lawfully placed around or about any hole, cut, drain, ditch or any other excavation or construction work in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place belonging to the City. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.210 - Liability of permittees. 
    Any person who undertakes work pursuant to a permit issued under the provisions of this chapter or performs work under contracts with the City shall be answerable for any damage occasioned to persons, animals, or property by reason of carelessness or negligence connected with such work and by obtaining a permit for such work shall thereby be deemed to consent and agree to hold the City harmless from any such damage or injury. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.220 - Recordkeeping requirements. 
    The City Manager shall keep a record of all applications made for excavation or cut permits and of the permits so issued. It shall be the duty of every person to furnish upon request of the City Manager information regarding the location in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place of the City of any pipe or other structure installed, maintained or utilized by such person. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
12.06.230 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished pursuant to the general penalty provision of this Code, § 1.12.010. Each day upon which any such violation continues shall constitute a separate misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 4-2003 § 1, 2003). 
(Ord. No. 9-2013, § 5, 8-5-2013) 
Chapter 12.08 - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION 
Sections: 

12.08.010 - Sidewalk construction. 
    Construction and repair of sidewalks located within public right-of-way shall be governed by the procedures set forth at C.R.S. 31-25-501 et seq., or as said statutory sections may be amended or recodified from time to time. 
(Ord. 8-2007 (part), 2007). 
12.08.020 - Construction specifications. 
    The construction of sidewalks shall be in accordance with construction standards and specifications adopted by the City. 
(Ord. 8-2007 (part), 2007). 
Chapter 12.12 - SIDEWALK CLEANING 
Sections: 

12.12.010 - Adjoining occupants to keep sidewalks clear. 
    All persons shall be required to keep the sidewalks adjacent to any property occupied by them, within this City, or adjacent to any property maintained by them for business purposes, within this City, free and clear of snow, ice, mud, dirt, rubbish, trash or filth. 
(Ord. 33-78 § 2, 1979). 
12.12.020 - Snow removal. 
    All persons described in Section 12.12.010 shall, within twenty-four (24) hours of the end of a snowfall, have the sidewalks adjacent to their property as described in Section 12.12.010 cleared of snow and ice. 
(Ord. 33-78 § 3, 1979). 
(Ord. No. 4-2014, § 1, 3-3-2014) 
12.12.030 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violating this chapter shall be subject to a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. 33-78 § 4, 1979). 
Chapter 12.16 - MOVING HEAVY OBJECTS ON STREETS 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons, without having first had and obtained a permit therefor as provided in this chapter, to move any building, structure or object requiring the use of rollers, capstan or machinery of any kind, upon any of the streets, or to hoist any safes or heavy objects into or out of any buildings over any street or place to which the public have access. 
(Ord. 31-78 § 2, 1979). 
12.16.020 - Permit application. 
    Any person, firm or entity wishing to move or hoist any object as described in Section 12.16.010, must first make application to the City Manager for a permit to do such act. The application shall be in writing and shall state a description of the activity for which the permit is sought, the streets or public areas which will be affected by such activity and the date and hours during which the activity shall take place. 
(Ord. 31-78 § 3, 1979). 
12.16.030 - Permit fees. 
    In addition to the requirements set forth in Section 12.16.020, the applicant shall pay to the City Manager the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for a permit to move any building and ten dollars ($10.00) for the moving or hoisting of any other object for which a permit is required. 
(Ord. 31-78 § 4, 1979). 
12.16.040 - Issuance of permit. 
    Upon receipt of proper written application and the proper fee, the City Manager shall issue a permit to the applicant specifying the type of activity, place of activity and the time and date when the activity shall take place. 
(Ord. 31-78 § 5, 1979). 
12.16.050 - Utility line removal. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the person, firm or entity engaging in any activity described in Section 12.16.010 to notify the proper authorities concerning any utility lines which must be removed to facilitate the activity. 
(Ord. 31-78 § 6, 1979). 
12.16.060 - Damage to public property. 
    The person, firm or entity making application for a permit to engage in any activity described in Section 12.16.010 shall be held responsible for the repair of any damage to public property caused by such activity. 
(Ord. 31-78 § 7, 1979). 
Chapter 12.20 - STREET NAMES AND HOUSE NUMBERS[2] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
 For statutory provisions authorizing cities to regulate the names of streets and the numbering of houses, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-702(1)(a)(VIII)(1975 Supp.) 

12.20.010 - Street prefixes. 
    All continuous streets in this City, running north and south, north of Main Street, shall have the word "north" prefixed to them; all streets south of Main Street running in the same direction shall have the word "south" prefixed to them; all streets running east and west, east of Pikes Peak Avenue, and State Highway 67, shall have the word "east" prefixed to them, and all streets running in the latter direction west of said avenue shall have the word "west" prefixed to them. 
(Ord. 5-2002 (part), 2002; Ord. 198 § 1, 1902). 
12.20.020 - Numbering-Compliance required. 
    It is made the duty of all owners or occupants of all buildings situated in the City of Florence, to number them in the manner provided in this chapter, and as may hereafter be provided by the City Council by ordinance. 
(Ord. 198 § 2, 1902). 
12.20.030 - Decimal numbering system adopted. 
    The decimal system of numbering houses is adopted, but the numbers heretofore assigned to buildings except as provided in this chapter, shall remain the numbers of such buildings respectively until otherwise changed by the City Council by ordinance or resolution. 
(Ord. 198 § 3, 1902). 
12.20.040 - Numbers assigned to blocks. 
    One hundred (100) numbers shall be assigned to each block allowing one (1) number for each space of twenty-five (25) feet in width; and buildings on north and south streets or avenues shall be numbered north and south from Main Street and buildings on east and west streets and avenues shall be numbered east and west from Pikes Peak Avenue and State Highway 67. 
(Ord. 5-2002 (part), 2002; Ord. 198 § 4, 1902). 
12.20.050 - Even and odd numbers. 
    In numbering, only full blocks shall be given one hundred (100) numbers, and across all resubdivided tracts of land intervening between portions laid out into blocks, the lines of streets shall be considered to cross in regular continuance of streets in additions adjoining. Odd/even numbering shall be as shown on Figure 12.20.050. The City Clerk shall assign each house or primary structure its proper number as the same appears upon any plat filed in the office of the City Clerk. 
(Ord. 5-2002 (part), 2002; Ord. 198 § 5, 1902). 

12.20.060 - Size of numbers. 
    Each of the figures of every number shall not be less than two and one-half (2 1/2) inches in length and so marked as to be distinctly and easily read. Said numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous place on or above the front door of the buildings to which the same are attached. 
(Ord. 198 § 6, 1902). 
12.20.070 - Refusal to number house-Placement of number by city. 
    Any person being the owner or occupant of any building, who, after being notified of the proper number for said building shall for thirty (30) days thereafter decline or refuse to number any buildings owned or occupied by him or her in conformity with the provisions of the ordinances of this City shall, on conviction thereof, be fined in a sum not exceeding the sum of five dollars ($5.00) and upon such neglect or refusal as aforesaid the City Police Chief shall proceed at once to place a number upon such house or houses as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 198 § 7, 1902). 
Chapter 12.24 - PARK REGULATIONS[3] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
 For statutory authority of municipalities to regulate the use of parks, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-702(1)(a)(I) (1975 Supp.) 

12.24.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "City Manager" means not only the City Manager of the City of Florence, but his designated employees including any member of the Police Department, Public Works Department or Recreation Director. 
B.  "db(A)" means sound levels in decibels measured on the "A" scale of a standard sound level meter having characteristics defined by the American National Standards Institute, Publication S1.4-1971. 
C.  "Park" means any designated park, parkway or recreation area owned by the City of Florence whether or not the park is located within the corporate limits of the City. 
D.  "Pet" means any animal owned by a person including, but not limited to dogs, cats, horses, goats, sheep, swine or any other type of livestock or reptile. 
E.  "Refuse" means all combustible or noncombustible solid waste, garbage, rubbish, debris and litter. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.020 - Hours. 
    The public parks of the City of Florence shall be open daily to the public from seven (7:00) a.m. until ten (10:00) p.m., except the Florence River Park and Florence Mountain Park, which hours shall be between seven (7:00) a.m. and nine (9:00) p.m. No person other than an employee of the City of Florence, providing he or she is acting in an official capacity, shall remain in any public park at any other time; provided, however, that the City Manager may issue permits extending the time specified in this section; and provided further, that the City Manager, for good cause, may limit the time specified in this section. No person shall camp in any park overnight without a permit issued by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.030 - City police power to control conduct in public parks outside of the municipal limits. 
    The City of Florence may enforce any and all city ordinances and any and all laws of the State of Colorado in all public parks owned by the City of Florence that lie outside the City of Florence municipal limits with the same authority and to the same extent as if said public parks were located within the City of Florence municipal limits, for the prevention of any acts which are or may be declared unlawful by the City of Florence or the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.040 - Unlawful to remain in parks. 
    It is unlawful for any person, other than an employee of the City of Florence, providing he or she is acting in an official capacity, to remain in or enter any public park at a time other than the hours designated at Section 12.24.020 herein, without first having obtained a permit from the City Manager. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.050 - Parks to be closed in emergencies. 
    In case of emergency or inclement weather, or where, in the judgment of the City Manager, the public interest demands it, the driveways, and other portions of any park may be closed to the public. Further, the manager of the Florence Municipal Swimming Pool may close the swimming pool for reasons of public interest. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.060 - Permits. 
    The City Manager, or his designee, shall have the authority to issue written permits reserving areas and structures within the parks. It is unlawful for any person to fail to observe or respect written permits issued pursuant to this section. When no permit has been issued, then the use of such areas shall follow generally the rule of first-come first-served. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.070 - Unlawful disposal of refuse. 
    It is unlawful for any person to deposit or dispose of refuse which is produced or generated off the site or any park, in any containers which are provided in any park for the disposal of refuse. Such containers as are provided in all parks are intended and shall be used solely for the purpose of disposal of refuse produced or generated within the park or by activities lawfully conducted therein. It is unlawful for any person to throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any pond, lake, stream or other body of water in or adjacent to any park, or any tributary, stream, storm sewer or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of such waters. It is unlawful to dump, deposit or leave any bottles, glass containers, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage or other refuse in any area of a park other than a container in the park for the purpose of holding such refuse. Where receptacles are not so provided, all such refuse shall be carried away from the park by the person or party responsible for its presence. If refuse is found in a park with a name and address written on such refuse, it shall be prima facie evidence that the refuse was unlawfully discarded by such individual. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.080 - Abandoning or disturbing animals prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to abandon a pet in a park. It is unlawful for any person, with the exception of authorized City or State officials, to disturb any fish, waterfowl, birds, fowls, reptiles or any animals whatsoever present in the parks owned or controlled by the City. The provisions of this section are not meant to prohibit fishing in the Florence River Park and its access to the Arkansas River. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.090 - Defecation by animals. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or custodian of any pet which has defecated in any City park or recreation area to fail to clean up and remove such excrement or feces. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.100 - Restraint of animals. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or custodian of any pet to allow such pet to run free in any City park or recreation area. All pets brought to any park must be kept on a leash not to exceed six (6) feet in length. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.110 - Erection of tents or buildings. 
    It is unlawful to build or place any tent, building, booth, stand or other structure in or upon any of the parks, parkways, or other recreational facilities without first having obtained a permit to do so from the City Manager, except if such tent, building, booth, stand or other structure is erected for designated purposes at City-sanctioned events. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.120 - Fires prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to light, make or use any unenclosed fire within any park; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to authorized City employees. Fires may only be built in fireplaces or on grills constructed for that purpose in such areas and such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the City Council from time to time. It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon, or leave unattended, a fire he or she has started in a park. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.130 - Prohibited acts. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation using any park to perform any of the following acts: 
A.  To wilfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove, any building, bridge, table, bench, fireplace, railing, paving or paving material, water line or other public utility or their appurtenances, sign, notice or placard, whether temporary or permanent, monument, stake, post or other boundary marker, or other structure or equipment, facility or park property whatsoever, either real or personal; 
B.  To possess, light, throw, use, discharge or cause to be discharged any fireworks, whether or not permissible as defined at C.R.S. 12-28-101 (as amended) in any park; 
C.  To cut, remove, deface, injure or maim any tree or shrub in a park, whether alive or dead, fur any purpose without the express written consent of the City Manager; 
D.  To operate any motorized vehicle in any park except on designated roadways or parking areas; 
E.  To deface, impair, mar, damage or ruin the natural beauty of any park; 
F.  To possess any glass container within any City park, or to transport any glass container in any park. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.140 - Weapons. 
    It is unlawful for any person, except an authorized law enforcement officer, to discharge or otherwise use within a park any firearm as defined at C.R.S. 30-15-301 (as amended), or any explosive or incendiary device as defined at C.R.S. 9-7-103 (as amended). A permit may be issued by the City Manager, after approval by the City Council, for the firing of certain types of firearms at certain organized events upon proper application by the applicant to the City and upon proof by the applicant to the City Council of sufficient liability insurance coverage for the event. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.150 - Amplified sound. 
    Every activity to which this chapter is applicable shall be conducted in a manner so that any noise produced is not objectionable due to intermittence, beat frequency or shrillness. It is unlawful for sound levels of noise radiating from any electronic source to exceed sixty (60) db(A) at a distance of twenty-five feet (25) from such source. This section applies to radios, television sets, record players, tape players, musical instruments, public address systems, and any other electronic source. This section does not apply to persons participating in an event that has been properly permitted or otherwise sanctioned by the City. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.160 - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It is unlawful for any person to carry, possess or consume any fermented malt beverage, vinous or spirituous liquors within any area of any park or recreational facility unless authorized and permitted by the City Manager, and that such face of the permit must state such authorization. No permit shall be issued for possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages except at Wilcox Park, Florence Mountain Park, Florence River Park and Pioneer Park; and further, no permit shall be issued to minors or to adults at youth-oriented activities of any type. In addition, alcohol may be sold and consumed in Pioneer Park for a City-sanctioned, insured event with a special event permit issued by the City pursuant to the laws of the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
(Ord. No. 5-2009, § 1, 4-6-2009; Ord. No. 3-2012, § 1, 4-16-2012) 
12.24.170 - Sale of alcoholic beverages. 
    It is unlawful to sell malt, vinous or spirituous liquors at any place within the parks except at those places where an existing and current license for the sale thereof shall have been issued pursuant to the laws of the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.180 - Right of appeal. 
    Any person denied a permit pursuant to this chapter for use of park facilities may, within ten (10) days from the date of the action, appeal such action to the City Manager by filing with the City Manager an appeal in writing setting forth the basis for such appeal. The City Manager shall hear the appeal and may sustain or overrule the action. If the person does not find the decision of the City Manager to be satisfactory, he/she may appear before the City Council at its next regular meeting time. The City Council may sustain or overrule the action of the City Manager. The decision of the City Council is final. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
12.24.190 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Violation of any section of this chapter by any person, firm or corporation shall be deemed a civil infraction and shall be subject to a fine not exceeding four hundred ninety-nine dollars ($499.00) in addition to applicable court costs. Each such violation shall be deemed to be separate infraction hereunder. 
(Ord. 23-93 § 1(part), 1993). 
Chapter 12.28 - TREES AND PUBLIC PROPERTY[4] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
 For statutory provisions authorizing cities to regulate the planting of trees in public places, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-702(1)(a)(I) (1975 Supp.); for additional provisions concerning trees, see Ch. 8.40 of this code. 

12.28.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
A.  "Owner" means the record owner, whether a person, firm or corporation, any agent or representative of the record owner, and any occupant of any lot or parcel of land within the city of Florence. 
B.  "Parking" means that portion of any deeded or platted street or other road which is adjacent to, but not physically occupied by, a roadway. 
C.  "Person" means any natural person, firm or corporation, or any agent or representative of any natural person, firm or corporation. 
D.  "Public place" means and includes any street, alley, parking, parkway or other area in the City of Florence dedicated, deeded, used or held for public use. 
(Ord. 466 § 1, 1960). 
12.28.020 - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to trim, prune or remove any tree located in any public place, including any parking adjacent to the premises of any owner or private property, without first securing a permit to do so from the City Manager. Each such permit, which shall be issued without charge, shall state the type of work for which the permit is given, the variety, number and location of the trees to which such permit relates, and the expiration date of such permit. It shall be issued upon the condition that the permit, in the performance of such work, shall comply with all regulations issued by the City Manager relating to the trimming, pruning and removal of trees. 
(Ord. 466 § 2, 1960). 
12.28.030 - City-owned trees. 
    All trees, plants and shrubbery upon and in the parkings immediately adjacent to public city buildings, grounds and parks, shall be the responsibility of the City, and shall be planted, trimmed and taken care of, or removed, by proper employees of the City, acting under the direction of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 466 § 3, 1960). 
12.28.040 - Trees on parkings--Abutting property owner responsibility. 
    All trees and shrubbery on parkings (that area lying between the curbline and the property line) abutting on privately owned land or lots within the City of Florence, shall be deemed to be the property of the owners of the lands or lots so abutted, and the owner or owners of such property shall be held responsible for the proper care, trimming or removal of any such trees, plants or shrubbery when care, trimming or removal is deemed necessary for the public health and safety or for the protection of curbs, sidewalks, water laterals or other public improvements. When such care, trimming or removal is determined by the City Manager to be necessary, the owner of the property shall be notified of the work required to be done. In case the required work is not completed within a reasonable length of time, or in case of emergency, the City Manager shall proceed to have the work done forthwith and all cost of the work so performed shall be paid by such property owner. 
(Ord. 466 § 4, 1960). 
12.28.050 - Tree trimmer's license-Required. 
    No person shall engage in or solicit the business of trimming, pruning or removal of trees within the City of Florence without first obtaining a license therefor from the City Manager of the City of Florence. No such license shall be issued unless evidence is filed with the City Manager that there is then in force a public liability and property damage insurance policy or policies issued by a reputable insurance carrier authorized to do business in the State of Colorado insuring the operations of such applicant for such amounts, in such form, and for such protection to the public as shall be required by the regulations of the City Manager. The fee for such license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per year, or fraction thereof, payable annually in advance, and each license shall expire on December thirty-first (31st) of the year in which the same is issued. 
(Ord. 466 § 5, 1960). 
12.28.060 - Tree trimmer's license-Revocation. 
    Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to revocation by the Council of Florence for any violation of this chapter, or for the violation of any rules and regulations adopted or issued thereunder, upon the written complaint of any person, including any administrative official of the City of Florence; or by the Council of Florence upon its own motion; provided, however, that no such license shall be revoked except after a hearing thereon by the Council of Florence, due notice of which shall be given to such licensee, who shall have an opportunity to be present, to be represented by counsel, and to be heard with relation thereto. 
(Ord. 466 § 6, 1960). 
12.28.070 - Promulgation of rules. 
    The City Manager shall, with the approval of the Council of Florence, issue such rules and regulations as may be required for the orderly, safe and effective trimming, pruning and removal of trees. 
(Ord. 466 § 7, 1960). 
Chapter 12.32 - UNION HIGHLAND CEMETERY[5] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
 For statutory provisions on municipal cemeteries, see CRS 1973 § 31-25-701 et seq. (1975 Supp.)
