12.32.010 - Administration and supervision of cemetery. 
    The administration and supervision of the Union Highland Cemetery (referred to in this chapter as "the cemetery") shall be by direction of the City Manager through a Superintendent appointed by him, and such other persons as may be necessary for the care and maintenance of cemetery. 
(Ord. 581 § 1, 1975). 
12.32.020 - Rules and regulations governing cemetery. 
    The City Council of the City of Florence shall adopt rules and regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this section governing the cemetery, which rules and regulations shall be on file and available for public examination in the office of the City Clerk. Failure to comply with any rule or regulation promulgated under this section shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 581 § 2, 1975). 
12.32.030 - Duties of Superintendent. 
    It shall be the duty of the Superintendent to dig graves, supervise funerals, set monuments or markers, supervise all decorations of lots and graves, plant and care for all vegetation, maintain and repair driveways and walks, endeavor to prevent the defacing, destruction or damage of monuments, markers and other property in the cemetery and carry out and enforce the rules and regulations of the cemetery. After each burial the Superintendent shall report to the City Clerk in writing in detail the location of the grave. 
(Ord. 581 § 3, 1975). 
12.32.040 - Map and records of cemetery-Burial permits. 
    It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to keep a map and the records of the cemetery and issue required permits. No permits shall be issued without the name and address of the lot owner and the lot and block number for which application is made. Burial permits shall be addressed to the Superintendent giving the lot and block number for burial and the time of the funeral. The City Clerk shall require application for all burial permits to be made at least eight (8) working hours before the funeral and shall not issue permits for funerals less than one (1) hour apart. 
(Ord. 581 § 4, 1975). 
12.32.050 - Applications for burial spaces-Contract for sale of space. 
    Applications for the purchase of burial spaces shall contain a description of the space, purchase price and method of payment, and when executed by the purchaser and the City it shall become a binding contract of purchase and sale. Upon payment of the full purchase price to the City, a cemetery deed by the City, executed by the Mayor conveying the space free and clear of all encumbrances shall be executed and delivered to purchaser. 
(Ord. 581 § 5, 1975). 
12.32.055 - Types of lots. 
    There shall be two (2) types of burial spaces for lots within the cemetery. Perpetual care lots are those lots designated by the City Manager as receiving watering and mowing services from the City of Florence for so long as the City is able to provide water. Dry lots are those lots designated by the City Manager as not including watering and mowing by the City of Florence. The size of burial spaces or lots and the charges therefor shall at all times be provided for by the rules and regulations adopted by the City Council of the City of Florence pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2-80, 1980: Ord. 581 § 19, 1975). 
12.32.060 - Price of spaces. 
    The sale price of grave spaces, including perpetual care of all spaces shall be governed by the rules and regulations of the cemetery. 
(Ord. 581 § 6, 1975). 
12.32.070 - Transfer, assignment or conveyance of property right in cemetery. 
    No transfer, assignment or conveyance of any property right or interest in the cemetery shall be valid without the consent in writing of the City. The City shall not consent to the transfer of any property right or interest in the cemetery upon which there is an indebtedness due the City of Florence. 
(Ord. 581 § 7, 1975). 
12.32.080 - Selling lots or spaces for resale. 
    No lot or space shall be sold to or purchased by a funeral director or other persons for purposes of resale or speculation. 
(Ord. 581 § 8, 1975). 
12.32.090 - When rights and interest in lot or space revert to city. 
    In the event a lot or space is vacated by reason of bodies being removed therefrom, all right and interest in the lot or space shall revert to the City. 
(Ord. 581 § 9, 1975). 
12.32.100 - Interments. 
    Application and permission for interment, interment charges and payment, and permissible use of burial space shall be governed by the rules and regulations of the cemetery. It shall be conclusively presumed, unless written notification to the contrary is filed with the City Clerk, that the purchase of any space in the cemetery is being acquired for family use, and the City shall have the right, without obtaining any interment permit from the owners, to allow interment in such space of any member of the family of the owners. 
(Ord. 581 § 10, 1975). 
12.32.110 - Erection of monuments, markers and vaults. 
    All monuments or markers shall be placed at least six (6) inches inside the space lines and shall be made of granite, marble or real bronze and shall be erected upon a foundation. Erection, construction, specifications, materials and placing of marker foundations, monuments, vaults and corner stones shall be governed by the rules and regulations of the cemetery. 
(Ord. 581 § 11, 1975). 
12.32.120 - Fences, railings, decorations and planting vegetation. 
    Fences, railings, hedges and other obstructions and decorations other than flowers, vases, wreaths and flags are prohibited, and will be removed without notice. All decoration of lots or spaces and planting of vegetation within the cemetery shall be under the control, supervision and direction of the Superintendent, who will be governed by the rules and regulations of the cemetery. 
(Ord. 581 § 12, 1975). 
12.32.130 - Fees for disinterring bodies. 
    Fees for opening graves, disinterring bodies, and use of equipment shall be governed by the rules and regulations of the cemetery. 
(Ord. 581 § 13, 1975). 
12.32.140 - Prohibitions within cemetery. 
    No person in the cemetery shall: 
A.  Drive or ride any machine or animal on lots, lawns or walks without permission from the Superintendent; 
B.  Drive an automobile or other vehicle in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour or such lesser speed as shall be prudent under the conditions and circumstances then existing; 
C.  Discard any litter or other unsightly articles in the cemetery; 
D.  Cause any employee to do work for lot owners without an order from the Superintendent or give to any employee any valuable consideration to do work for a lot owner; 
E.  Do work on the grounds, except by permission of the Superintendent; 
F.  Perform or cause to be performed a burial in the cemetery on Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday without a special permit therefor issued by the City Manager; 
G.  Hunt or in any way disturb the birds or fowl or discharge any firearms, fireworks or other missiles within or over any portion of the cemetery or around the gates, fences or roads adjoining the same, except as a part of military funerals or similar occasions; 
H.  Take any animal or permit any animal to be taken into the cemetery; 
I.  Deface, damage, destroy or injure any monuments, markers or other property or thing in the cemetery. 
(Ord. 581 § 14, 1975). 
12.32.150 - Closing driveways-Establishing grades. 
    The City of Florence shall have the right to close any walk or driveway in the cemetery heretofore existing or hereafter constructed and to establish grades. 
(Ord. 581 § 15, 1975). 
12.32.160 - Nonliability of City of Florence for acts of trespassers. 
    The City of Florence shall not be liable for any act of lot owners, visitors, licensees or trespassers within the cemetery or for any damage to person or property while within the cemetery. 
(Ord. 581 § 16, 1975). 
Chapter 12.36 - CAMPING ON PROPERTY WITHOUT CONSENT 
Sections: 

12.36.010 - Camping on property without consent prohibited-Exceptions. 
A.  No person shall camp within any park, parkway, recreation area, public open space, ditch or drainage canal, or other city owned property or city managed property, without having obtained a permit from the city manager as provided in Chapter 12.24. 
B.  No person shall camp within any private property without first having obtained permission of the owner, or agent of the owner, of the private property. 
C.  This section does not apply to any dwelling unit in the city as defined at Section 17.08.015. 
(Ord. No. 16-2016, 11-7-2016). 
12.36.020 - Definitions. 
A.  "Camp" means to reside or dwell temporarily in a place, with shelter, and conduct activities of daily living such as eating or sleeping in such place, but does not include napping or picnicking during the day or when the park or other public place is open pursuant to Chapter 12.24. "Camp" does not include temporary residence associated with the performance of a governmental service by emergency responders or relief workers in accordance with any disaster relief plan adopted by the city or other public agency. 
B.  "During the day" means from one (1) hour after sunrise until sunset. 
C.  "Shelter" includes, without limitation, any cover or protection from the elements other than clothing. 
(Ord. No. 16-2016, 11-7-2016). 
12.36.030 - Testimony as prima facie evidence. 
    Testimony by the city manager or his designee that he or she is the person who grants permission to camp on property indicated in Section 12.36.010, and that no such permission was granted by him or her, is prima facie evidence of that fact. 
(Ord. No. 16-2016, 11-7-2016). 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapter 13.04 - WATERWORKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
 For statutory provisions on city water service, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-708 (1975 supp). 

13.04.003 - Exchange of the right to receive a water tap for land and water rights acquisitions. 
    The City Council may authorize the exchange of the right to receive a water tap or water taps for easements, water rights, or other property acquisition for the purpose of extending or expanding the water facilities of the City under the following conditions, which shall be considered to be minimum requirements: 
A.  All such agreements must be in writing and approved by the City Council; 
B.  Notwithstanding the limitations contained in this chapter, the City Council may authorize periods beyond one year, but not to exceed five (5) years, for the physical connection of the water tap; 
C.  A user who is physically connected shall pay the monthly minimum fees and any other applicable fees as set forth in the ordinances, resolutions, and regulations except as is otherwise specifically provided in the agreement; 
D.  The agreement must provide that the person or entity receiving the water tap must either pay the charge for the water tap at the time of the agreement, or alternatively agree to pay any fee or charge which may applicable at the time of the later physical connection to the water system; 
E.  The agreement may provide for additional terms and conditions not inconsistent with those set forth herein. 
(Ord. 22-90, 1990). 
13.04.010 - Definitions. 
    Authority. The City is a governmental subdivision of the State of Colorado and a body corporate with those powers of a public or quasi-municipal corporation, that are specifically granted, or necessary or incidental to those powers specifically granted for carrying out the objectives and purposes of the City. 
    "Availability of service charge" means that charge that is also referred to as "debt retirement fee" payable monthly for each water tap or equivalent thereof. 
    "Board" and "City Council" means the City Council of the City of Florence. 
    "Branching main line" means a line which usually does not loop back to the central water distribution grid, carries fire flow and water for service mains, sized six (6) inches or larger, and which shall include an isolation valve and means of flushing. 
    "Bulk water" means water sold by the City of Florence to users who haul or transport such water as opposed to water which the City delivers through water lines. 
    "Commercial user" means a user who produces a product or service to the public in a commercial district. 
    "Constructor" means the landowner, developer, subdivider or agency actually paying for the construction of lines or other facilities. 
    "Contractor" means any person, firm or corporation authorized by the City to perform work and to furnish materials within the City. 
    "Core charge (also called a 'tap fee')" means the fee adopted by the City which is charged for connecting to the City's water system. 
    "Curbstop" means a valve placed in the customer's service line located at or near the property line for the purpose of shutoff by the City of Florence. 
    "Customer" means any person, company, corporation, homeowners' association or similar entity authorized to connect and to use the public water system under a permit issued by the City. 
    "Debt retirement" means a fixed cost assessed per unit whether serviced or not. 
    "Developer" means any person or entity who owns land or is subdividing land, for resale or is seeking to have land served by the City, whether or not such land is included within the City's boundaries. 
    "City" means the City of Florence, Colorado. 
    "City Engineer" means that person or firm who has been authorized by the City to perform engineering services for the City. 
    "Dwelling unit" means one or more habitable rooms arranged, occupied, or intended or designed to be occupied by not more than one family with facilities for living, cooking, sleeping and eating. 
    "Equivalent dwelling unit" or "single-family equivalent dwelling unit" means a use which is estimated to have an impact upon the water or sewer system equal to that of the average dwelling unit. 
    "Industrial user" means a user who occupies a space in an industrial zone. 
    "Late charges" means charges assessed by virtue of a failure to make timely payment. 
    "City Manager" means the person appointed by the City Council, for the position of City Manager. If absent, the City Manager may appoint someone to act on his behalf. 
    "Meter" means a city-approved device used to measure water consumption by the customer for water billing purposes. 
    "Meter setting" means a water meter and associated devices required by the City to "meter" water use and protect the municipal water system. This may include the "pit, vault, or structure" designed to contain and protect these devices. 
    "Permit" means the written permission to connect to the water main of the City pursuant to the rules and regulations of the City, and shall be revocable upon change of use as defined in the zoning ordinances of the property being served by such main. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity of any nature, whether public or private. 
    "Pipefinder" means a device used to locate metal water conduits, or metal tracer wires used on nonmetal water conduits. 
    "Premises" means that property which is not considered public right-of-way, containing municipal water use, water carrying devices or meter settings. 
    "Prepaid tap" means fees collected prior to physical installation of a water tap. 
    "Public water system" means any water line, appurtenances, accessories or portion thereof owned and maintained by the city. 
    "Service line" means any pipe, line or conduit, including curbstop, used to provide water service from the main line to a building or dwelling unit. A service line is not the property of the city, and the city shall have no liability whatsoever in respect thereto from the customer's property line to the point of use, regardless of the meter setting. 
    "Service main" means a water line six (6) inches or smaller that services one (1) or more service lines or taps which does not loop back to transmission or branch lines, does not carry fire flow, nor does it extend beyond twelve hundred (1200) lineal feet. If extension beyond twelve hundred (1200) lineal feet is required, or future development is anticipated, sizing shall be as a branch main line. 
    Shall - May. Whenever "shall" is used herein, it shall be construed as a mandatory direction; whenever "may" is used herein, it shall be construed as a permissive but not mandatory direction. 
    "Stop and waste valve" means plumbing valve at the customer's end of the "service line", for the customer's use, prior to any customer branch piping or water use. 
    "Superintendent" means that person appointed by the City Manager to supervise the operation and maintenance of the City water facilities. 
    "Tap" or "water connection" means the connecting of the service line from the structure which it is to serve to the public water system, either directly to a public main line or indirectly through a private main line. 
    "Tracer wire" mans a metallic wire installed for the length of a plastic pipe for the purpose of making such pipe capable of detection. 
    "Transmission main line" means a conduit to provide water for branching and service water mains, which is six (6) inches or larger, capable of conveying fire flow, branch and service main water demands. 
    "Travel charge" means a charge assessed for travel to customers for whom the City provides services at the request of the customer other than normal installation and maintenance of City equipment, property and lines. It also includes travel required for customers who fail to comply with the City's requirements, thereby causing the City to do the work necessary for customer's compliance. When required, the travel charge shall be in addition to the actual costs of the work done. 
    "Wholesale water use" means a person or entity that purchases treated water for resale to other consumers. 
    Any other term. Any other term not herein defined shall be defined as presented in the "Glossary Water and Sewage Control Engineering" A.P.H.A., A.W.W.A., A.S.C.E. and F.W.S.A. latest editions, a copy of which is available for inspection. 
(Ord. 2-90 § l(part), 1990). 
13.04.020 - Application for water service. 
A.  Anyone requesting water service shall be required to complete an "agreement for water service," an application and pay all fees required before action will be taken by the City Manager on a request for water service. If the applicant is dissatisfied with action taken by the City Manager, he may request that the City Council review said action. The Council shall have the right to review and revise the action taken by the City Manager. There shall be no appeal from the action taken by the City Council. If the application is accepted, the applicant shall agree and shall be deemed to have consented to comply with all ordinances and regulations in effect as well as those subsequently adopted. 
B.  Application for service does not bind the applicant to "use the service." Such applications shall be retained, along with fees paid, by the City for a period of three hundred sixty-five (365) days. If the applicant has not then requested a service connection, the application shall be deemed to be withdrawn. The City may retain the fees paid until a refund is requested in writing, however, debt retirement fees from the date of application and a handling charge of ten percent (10%) of application fee shall be retained. A new application shall then be required. Any refunds shall be made without interest. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.030 - Rescission of approval. 
    The Council reserves the right to rescind any approval previously granted for water service, before service has been provided. 
(Ord. 2-90 § l(part), 1990). 
13.04.040 - Denial of application. 
    The City reserves the exclusive right to deny any water service application for any reason which may include but are not limited to the following: 
A.  The service applied for would create an excessive seasonal or other demand on the facilities; 
B  There exists an unresolved obligation between the City and the applicant; 
C.  There is not provided adequate documentation of easements for water lines serving the property; 
D.  Connection of the water system to applicant's existing plumbing would constitute a cross-connection to an unsafe water supply; 
E.  There is a material misrepresentation in the application as to the property or fixtures contained in the property; 
F.  There has been a misrepresentation concerning use to be made of water; 
G.  In the judgment of the City Council, service to the property is not reasonably feasible based on engineering and economic considerations. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.049 - Water meter replacement and service line responsibility. 
A.  All owners, users, and/or occupants of property or premises served with municipal water shall keep and repair all service lines upon their premises and property up to the border of any adjoining curb or street in place, including stop-cocks and connecting lines, at their own expense, regardless of the location of the municipal water meter. 
B.  If a service line or associated devices on the customers property are found to be defective or damaged, the City Manager shall require the owner to "upgrade," or pay for the City to "upgrade" such service line to include items such as accurate metering devices, proper metering location, proper fittings and meter pit, or proper service line sizing under the following guidelines: 
1.  Following a meter test (Section 13.04.180) owner or city requested, the City will bear fifty percent (50%) of the total cost to "upgrade" the metering set, which could include water meter, meter setter, meter pit, meter pit cover, associated valves, piping and related labor costs. The intent of this section is to assist water users with nonuniform meter settings to upgrade to uniform standards. The City will diligently minimize such costs for both parties, and maintain a uniform standard. 
2.  The owner may make arrangements to pay their fifty percent (50%) share of the total cost over twelve (12) equal, continuous, monthly payments for a ten percent (10%) accounting charge added to the owners' share. 
3.  Service lines are defined as any pipe, line or conduit, including curbstop, used to provide water service from the main line to a building or dwelling unit. The City shall have no monetary liability whatsoever in respect thereto from the customer's property line to the point of use, regardless of the meter setting and such water charges for water metered by a defective or leaking service line are the sole responsibility of the owner at all times. However, the City has sole responsibility for that portion of the service line from the water main tap to the edge of the customer's property line. 
4.  Changes in customer's equipment or service (Section 13.04.140) or conditions affecting the meter pit (Section 13.04.260) are the sole responsibility of the owner. 
C.  1.  After a new water tap has been performed and meets a uniform standard, or a meter setting has been "upgraded" to such a standard, the owner has full and complete responsibility to pay for costs to maintain such meter setting to such uniform standards set by the City Council including the responsibility to maintain the water meter to the standard as set by the meter test. The City will, on the owners behalf, act as the owners agent to the manufacturer of the water meters and equipment to seek manufacturer warranty repair or replacement of that equipment installed, to minimize such cost to the owner. 
2.  The City will at all times supply all related equipment and material for connection to the municipal water system to maintain a uniform standard, except the customer's service line from the meter setting to the customer's point of use. 
(Ord. 13-90, 1990). 
13.04.050 - Commercial and industrial users. 
    Industrial or commercial users within or without the City may make application for a contract with the City in which rates, terms and conditions of use and manner of payment shall be specified. Nothing herein shall require the City to enter into such a contract. 
(Ord. 2-90 § l(part), 1990). 
13.04.060 - Water line extensions-Conditions. 
    No water main, pipe or water meter and related fitting shall be extended, constructed, installed or attached to the City water system unless the same are extended under a public street or other public right-of-way or utility easement dedicated or otherwise created for the benefit of the public or under private premises to which the City shall, by private easement, right-of-way or permission, have the right to install and maintain such water line or lines. 
(Ord 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.070 - Water main line extensions-Submission of plans. 
A.  City water mains and service lines shall not be extended unless the applicant for the water service pays in advance to the City the complete cost of installation. In addition to such charges and tap fees, the applicant for water service may be required to provide a water main line or lines as determined by the City Manager based upon projected usage, and City looping requirements. At a minimum, transmission or branch water mains shall not be less than six (6) inches in diameter, shall contain at least one (1) valve to isolate the main extension from the water system, and shall have at least one (1) fire hydrant at the end of the extension for flushing and fire protection. Additional valves, hydrants, and increased pipe diameters may be required, depending on the length of such main line extensions. If a service main is allowed, it shall include an isolation valve from the branch main and a means of flushing. 
B.  All owners, subdividers, contractors and builders shall submit to the City Manager detailed plans for any proposed utility installations which shall include capacities, sizes, location of mains, fittings, fire hydrants, tanks, pumps and pump houses, and the location of loopings and grids to existing City mains. The materials for installation and the labor costs for installation of all required items shall be at the sole expense of the owner, subdivider, contractor or builder. The capacity, size and material of all required items to be installed, their locations, and the manner and specification for their installation shall be determined by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 2-90 §1(part), 1990). 
13.04.080 - Water service lines-Extensions, pressure required, installation requirements. 
A.  Existing water service lines shall not be extended, or added onto, unless written permission is obtained from the City Manager. A water service line shall not extend more than two hundred fifty (250) feet beyond the main line physical tap connection, unless through proper pipe sizing, or other provisions, a residual pressure at the customer's point of use is at least twenty-five (25) pounds per square inch gauge (PSIG) when eighty percent (80%) of the metering device's rated flow in the service line is present. 
B.  Plastic service lines may be used, if a tracer wire is provided to locate such a service line in the future. 
C.  All service lines shall have a shutoff valve accessible at the point of use, before any branch piping, to provide a means for maintenance and emergency shutoff. A travel charge as set forth herein shall be levied if the City is required to utilize City valves for such a purpose. 
(Ord. 2-90 §1(part), 1990). 
13.04.085 - Water main rebate agreements for line extensions within the corporate limits of the city. 
A.  The City Council may, from time to time, enter into contracts with persons whereby a portion of the cost of the installation of an eight (8) inch or larger water main extension, or enlargement of an existing line to eight (8) inches or larger, over a distance of at least four hundred (400) feet within the corporate City limits of the City of Florence, as required by the City and paid for by such persons may be recovered by the persons who paid for the same, on an equitable pro-rata basis, from water users who subsequently tap such water main as extended or enlarged at right angles to such water main. Such contracts shall be known as "Water Main Rebate Agreements." 
B.  No water main rebate agreement shall be prepared or executed by the City unless such agreement is requested in a written application, the form of which shall be provided by the City Manager, and filed by the person or persons entitled to request such agreement, within three (3) months from the date the subject water main extension or enlargement is accepted by the City as determined by the records of the City Engineer. Such date shall be the "acceptance date." 
C.  No water main rebate agreement shall be executed by the City until the City Engineer has received and reviewed complete and accurate records and supporting documentation showing the actual cost of the water main extension or enlargement that will be the subject matter of the agreement. Such records and documentation must be received within six (6) months of the acceptance date. Any application for a water main rebate agreement which is not supported by such records and supporting documentation shall be an incomplete application. An incomplete application shall be void and of no force and effect. 
D.  No water main rebate agreement shall have a term which ends later than on the fifth anniversary date (termination date) of the acceptance date provided for in subsection B of this section. Following the end of such term, the City shall have no further obligation and the other party or parties shall have no rights, under such agreement other than those accruing prior to the termination date. 
E.  Every water main rebate agreement executed by the City shall be recorded at the expense of the applicant who shall pay such recording costs prior to the recording of the agreement. Unless recorded, no such agreement shall be binding upon the City. 
F.  No water main rebate agreement shall impose upon the City a duty to collect refund amounts with respect to any new connection to the enlarged or extended water main from the person making such new connection unless the application for the agreement was received by the City prior to the time such new connection was authorized by the City. 
G.  Every water main rebate agreement shall provide that the City's obligations under such agreement shall be limited to the City's using its best efforts to collect pro-rated refund amounts from those who connect to the extended or enlarged water main after the written application for the agreement has been received by the City and prior to the termination date provided for in the agreement. The City may charge the party or parties to the agreement a fee for collecting and distributing said refund amounts. 
H.  Every water main rebate agreement shall also provide that the City shall not be liable to the other party or parties to the agreement for any failure by the City to have collected the appropriate refund amount from a person connecting to the extended or enlarged water main, except that the City may be liable with respect to such refund amount if it is proven by clear and convincing evidence in a legal proceeding that such refund was not distributed after collection as a result of fraud. 
I.  Each party to any such agreement must provide to the City, prior to preparation and execution of the water main rebate agreement, his or her current address and give the City written notice of any change of address occurring during the term of the agreement. Funds collected by the City pursuant to a water main rebate agreement that are not claimed by the party entitled to receive such funds within one (1) year of the City's sending notice of the receipt of such funds to such party at the last known address of such party shall be forfeited to, and become the exclusive property of, the City. The last known address of any such party shall be the address stated in the agreement or the last address communicated to the City by the written notice of change of address required under this subsection. 
J.  All calculations of refunds to be collected by the City and distributed to any party or parties under a water main rebate agreement shall be made by the City Engineer under the following formula: 
Total costs of constructing a line 
Total linear feet of line constructed = Total price per foot Total Price per Foot 
2 = Price per foot of frontage  
Total line frontage of property to be served x Price per foot of frontage = Rebate Amount OR One-half of local engineer's per foot cost used in estimating x Total line frontage of property to be served = Rebate Amount Whichever figure is lower.  
    For purposes of the above calculation, total cost shall not include equipment depreciation, interest on borrowed money, or labor overtime. Calculations of refund amounts shall be based upon the length of frontage of the property of any water user receiving new service from whom rebate amounts are collectable whose property abuts the right-of-way or easement containing the extended or enlarged water main. 
K.  Water main rebate agreements are assignable by the developer with the written consent of the City Council, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. Such assignment shall be in writing and subscribed to by the developer and the City. 
(Ord. 19-2006 §1, 2006). 
13.04.090 - Service outside city. 
    Water service to customers outside of the City limits is a privilege, not a vested right, and may be granted, terminated or reduced at such time as the City Council determines that the supply of treated water is not sufficient to provide such service. Water service outside the City may, in the discretion of the City, be conditioned upon an agreement by the owner of said property to consent to or apply for annexation to the City when said property shall be available for annexation. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.100 - Sale of untreated water. 
    The City shall not sell untreated water except for construction use. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.110 - Regional plant investment fund. 
    Fees shall be assessed for the Regional Plant Investment Fund as agreed by contract between the City of Florence, Town of Williamsburg and Town of Coal Creek. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.130 - Classification of customers. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following classifications are provided: 
A.  Single-family Dwelling Unit. A single-family dwelling shall be construed as a living unit suitable for occupancy by one (1) or more individuals of a family, and forming a separate unit from any other dwelling unit; consisting of one (1) or more habitable rooms arranged, occupied, or intended or designed to be occupied by not more than one (1) family with facilities for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
B.  Multiple-family dwellings. A multiple-family dwelling shall consist of a single structure containing more than one single-family dwelling unit. 
C.  Hotels and Motels. A hotel, motel or lodge shall be defined as a unit providing overnight sleeping facilities for transient usage. 
D.  Mobile Homes. Mobile homes shall be classified as any unit capable of being transported on wheels behind a standard power unit, and which can be moved on normal streets, roads and highways. Said unit must be suitable for living quarters and provide for normal domestic sanitary conveniences. 
E.  Cafes, Restaurants, Bars and Private Clubs. Cafes, restaurants, bars and private clubs shall include any establishment providing food or beverage service to the general public or to private membership, and where charges for such service of goods and beverages are made. Such units shall be classified by the square footage therein. An area of one thousand (1000) square feet shall be equivalent to a single-family dwelling unit. 
F.  Filling Stations and Garages. Filling stations and garages shall be defined as service outlets providing for the servicing of motor vehicles. Monthly fees shall be based on tap size and water usage. 
G.  Commercial Laundries. Public laundries, as used herein, shall refer to coin-operated laundries and drying facilities for clothing and textile use, as well as commercial facilities where such services are provided for the customer on a fee basis. Monthly fees shall be based on tap size and water usage. 
H.  Schools. Schools are defined as any private or public institution established and utilized for the instruction of individuals, and where said units are to be operational for a period of six (6) months or longer. Charges shall be based on tap size and water usage. 
I.  Hospitals. Hospitals shall be defined as either private or public institutions with overnight facilities provided for care of patients. Charges shall be based on tap size and water usage. 
J.  Other Industrial and Commercial Uses. All other commercial and industrial users shall be charged based on tap size, water usage and any other criteria set forth in the ordinances. 
(Ord. 2-90 § l(part), 1990). 
13.04.140 - Change in customer's equipment or service. 
    No change in the customer's equipment or service shall be made without prior written approval by the City. Any change in a customer's equipment or service which in the City Manager's evaluation significantly increases the water flow requirement or total quantity of water required by the customer shall require a redetermination of the tap fee and monthly service charge, and the customer shall then be responsible for payment of any additional tap fee and service charge so determined. The redetermined tap fee shall allow a credit for previously paid tap fees. Changes in a customer's equipment or service which results in a decrease in the service provided by the City shall not, however, result in a reduction or refund of tap fees. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.150 - Excessive customer demand. 
    Any use which requires twenty thousand (20,000) gallons of water during a twenty-four (24) hour period must be authorized by the City Manager. The City Manager may impose requirements as to the time of day of the water usage and any other requirement deemed necessary by the City Manager to provide water service to all customers. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.160 - Nonliability of city. 
    The City shall not be responsible to the water user for any breakage or defect of service pipes or cocks, or any damage caused thereby, nor for any failure in the water supply. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.170 - Water shortages. 
    At any time, when in the judgment of the City Council a shortage of water as supplied by the City waterworks of the City of Florence shall seem imminent or likely, the City Council shall, by resolution, provide rules and regulations restricting the quantity of water to be used, and the hours and manner of its use. Under emergency circumstances the City Manager may impose temporary restrictions. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.180 - Meter test. 
    When the owner of any premises complains of a defective meter, the City Manager or his assignee, upon request, may machine test the meter. A meter shall be deemed to be working properly when it measures with a range of plus or minus two percent (2%) of actual usage. If the machine test shows the meter to be working properly, a service charge of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be assessed for all yoke-type meter assemblies and meters situated in the basement of buildings and homes. Where the meter must be dug up to be tested, the charge for testing shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) and the meter reading shall be used to compute excess water charges. If the tested meter is in excess of plus or minus two percent (2%) of actual usage, the water meter shall be replaced, and a credit to the customer's account computed on the test results shall be given for a three (3)-month period prior to the testing. A travel charge shall be levied for work that is performed at the customer's request. 
(Ord. 2-90 § l(part), 1990). 
13.04.190 - City to tap and inspect water mains and equipment. 
    In all cases, the City, or its designee, shall make the physical connection of the tap to the water main and shall provide the material and equipment from the water main to the meter setting and shall at all times have the right to inspect the same. A curbstop valve shall be located at or near the customer's property line. All of these services and materials shall be at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. 2-90 § l(part), 1990). 
13.04.200 - Master meter station-Taps on regional water system. 
    A metered water tap, with the size determined by the City Manager, shall be utilized when connections are made to the Florence Water System under the following circumstances: 
A.  The connection or service is outside of the Florence City limits; 
B.  The developer or political entity does not have another water main supply; 
C.  The master meter station and tap, including but not limited to cross-connection, pressure reduction, or check valve protection devices are needed to protect the equipment and water quality of the Florence Water System; 
D.  An application for a master meter station has been made to the City of Florence Administration, reviewed by the Regional Water Advisory Committee, and approved by the Florence City Council. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.210 - Taps-Meters. 
    Each single-family dwelling and each unit of a two-family dwelling shall be required to have a separate tap and shall have a separate meter. Each individual structure such as a hotel, motel or rooming house shall be required to have a separate tap and shall have a separate meter. Each business or commercial unit shall be required to have a separate tap and shall have a separate meter. Apartments owned by one (1) owner are not required to have separate meters unless converted to units of separate ownership including, but not limited to townhomes and condominiums. Where two (2) or more dwelling or business units are being served by a single meter, each user shall pay the minimum applicable monthly charge as set by resolution and the record owner of the property shall pay all charges for excess water. 
(Ord. 2-90 § l(part), 1990). 
13.04.220 - Branching main line meters. 
A.  Installation of main line metering devices shall be required at the expense of the subdivider, contractor or customers being served by the branching main line, if any of the following circumstances are present: 
1.  The branching main line serves an area that is not to be looped back to the central distribution grid at the time of installation, regardless of future plans to do so; 
2.  The water entering the branching main line is to be sold or billed by another entity; 
3.  The branching main line is to enter an area such as an industrial complex, multiple-use area, or other grounds where numerous taps are to be utilized, even if each tap has a separate metering device; 
4.  The branching main lines are eight (8) inches in diameter or larger. 
B.  Branching main line meters are to be used to determine billing accuracy of service line meters, leak detection and future consumption planning. Metering devices are to be sized and rated so as to provide for fire flow, and be capable of being serviced and tested without disrupting normal service. 
C.  In the event a developer, who has paid the requisite fee for a tap connection to a branching main line and/or installed a branching main line meter to serve a parcel of land, changes the development plan to include individual lots with service line tap connections, the City Council may, at its sole discretion, allow the developer a credit against the amount paid for the branching main line tap connection for the cost of individual lot service line tap connections at the then current rates under the following circumstances: 
1.  Individual lot service line tap connections must be applied for and installed by developer within one (1) year of the date of approval of the final plat pursuant to the Florence Subdivision Regulations, unless a further period of time is granted at the discretion of the City Council. 
2.  Developer must agree to abandon the branch main line tap connection and forfeit any right to the branching main line meter and appurtenances in favor of the City, the same to become the sole property of the City; 
3.  Said credit applies only to service line tap connections serving individual lots created from land that was the subject of the original proposed development; and 
4.  Developer enters into a written agreement with the City for the credit as herein provided, said agreement to be ratified by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. 9-2008 § 1, 2008; Ord. 16-2006 § 1, 2006; Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.230 - Special devices required. 
A.  The City Manager or his designee shall determine whether a customer must have a pressure regulating valve and a backflow prevention device and also determine the type and specifications of any necessary device to be installed. The customer shall pay for the required material, devices and installation of the required pressure regulating valve and backflow prevention device. If such installation is not completed within thirty (30) days of notice to customer of the requirement, the City shall make such installation and bill the cost thereof, as set forth herein, and may disconnect customer's water service and file a lien on customer's property for nonpayment as permitted by law. 
B.  All installations not performed by the City are subject to City inspection and approval, and must be installed in a location that provides access for maintenance, testing and repairs. 
C.  The owner is required to perform annually, or pay the City to perform at least annually, all tests as required by law on any backflow prevention device installed in accordance with this section. If the owner undertakes the inspection, he or she must submit a copy of the test results to the City yearly. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
(Ord. No. 3-2016, § 1, 2-16-2016) 
13.04.240 - Access to premises. 
    The City Manager, Water Superintendent or designee, upon showing proper identification, shall have access at reasonable hours to any premises where water is used, for the purpose of inspection and examination of the water system. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.250 - Maintenance of water lines and water meters. 
A.  No alteration or disconnection in or about any conduit, service pipe or water cock, or any other apparatus connected therewith shall be made by any person without first obtaining written permission of the City Manager or his designee. 
B.  The City Manager shall for cause shown have authority to direct that municipal water meters be moved or placed at a location upon or approximate to the boundary line of the owner, user or occupant. 
C.  Water service may be interrupted to make repairs or for other necessary purposes. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.260 - Meter pits. 
    Meter pits shall be clearly marked at all times. Customers shall not conceal, obstruct, or damage the devices therein. A fee shall be assessed to move a metering pit or meter location at the request of the customer. The customer shall pay a deposit for charges prior to such action. The City shall also assess a fee to the customer to move a meter pit when, in the opinion of the City Manager, the present location is resulting in damage to the meter assembly or creating a safety hazard. The customer shall then be assessed a fee for moving said meter pit. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.270 - Water rates. 
    The rates and charges to be collected for the allowance and use of water inside or outside of the Florence City limits and for other related water service charges shall be determined by resolution approved by the Florence City Council for such purpose. The current application resolution shall be kept and may be inspected at the City Clerk's office. It is the policy of the City that the water rates encompass reasonable and necessary expenses for debt retirement, capital and operating costs of the water system, including the acquisition of water, the treatment and storage of water, and the connection with each of said functions. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.280 - Water billing-Adjustments and allowances. 
A.  All users shall pay monthly that amount billed to the user for water consumption and any other fees at the rate then required by resolution duly adopted. 
B.  A monthly minimum fee shall be paid by each user or equivalent user physically attached to the water system, with additional charges as set forth in Section 13.04.310. 
1.  If water service is not physically disconnected to the customer, the minimum fee shall include fees for debt retirement, and the fee set by resolution for an allowance of water. 
2.  If water service has been interrupted by a City-controlled valve or means, but not physically disconnected from the water system, the minimum fee shall include fees for debt retirement, but not water use. 
3.  The owner can request a voluntary abandonment. Thereafter if the service is physically disconnected, minimum fees are not required. Such taps shall be declared "abandoned" and a new tap or physical connection fee shall be required for reconnection to the water system. 
C.  Payment for debt retirement is required for each space in a privately owned mobile home park regardless of whether the space is then occupied by a mobile home. If the mobile home space is not occupied by a mobile home the City will not charge a turn-on or turn-off fee if water service at the spaces is controlled by the mobile home park for turning on or turning off the water. Mobile homes not in privately owned parks shall be considered single-family residences and billed as a normal water tap. 
(Ord. 2-90 § l(part), 1990). 
13.04.290 - Water billings-Adjustments for non-use while physically connected to the system. 
    In the event more than one (1) unit is supplied with water by one (1) tap or meter, one (1) of the units is not receiving water service, and the property owner wants to receive a credit on his water billing to reflect such lack of use, then the following procedure shall be followed: 
A.  At the time a non-use is to begin, the property owner shall advise the City Clerk in writing on forms supplied by the City entitled "Application for Declaring a Non-Use of Water Service." This application shall grant to the City the right of entry upon the designated premises to determine whether water is being used. 
B.  The property owner shall pay a fee of ten dollars ($10.00), together with the Application for Declaring a Non-Use. 
C.  The City Clerk shall advise the City Manager of the application and he or she shall cause an investigation to be made to determine whether it is feasible to place a physical impediment to water use in the premises or unit in which the property owner does not intend to use water. If it is feasible in the opinion of the City Manager to install such an impediment, the same shall be done to the specifications required by the City Manager at the expense and direction of the property owner; provided, however, that the reasonable cost shall not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) per unit. 
D.  The City Manager shall also cause periodic inspections of the premises or units which are the subject of the application to be made for the purpose of determining whether the premises is not using water services. 
E.  In the event that there is tampering of the installed physical impediment to water service or in the event inspection reveals that the designated premises or unit is using water service, then the application shall be denied, the fee forfeited, and no credit allowed on the water billing. 
F.  At the end of each calendar month, but during said month, a property owner who has previously submitted an Application for Declaring a Non-Use and paid the required fee shall advise the City Clerk whether the premises or unit has used water at any time during that entire month. If there has been no use of water during the entire month unless otherwise provided herein, the City Clerk shall then allow the property owner a credit equal to the monthly minimum charge for that same month; provided, however, that the property owner shall in any event continue to pay the monthly debt retirement fee for any unit capable of receiving water. 
G.  In the event that a property owner wilfully misrepresents the water use status of a unit or premises, that same person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of up to three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisonment for up to ninety (90) days or both such fine and imprisonment. In addition, all credits previously granted to said property owner shall be reassessed. 
H.  A new application and fee shall be required each time an owner requests a non-use status at the premises or unit. 
(Ord. 3-90, 1990). 
13.04.300 - Bulk water charges. 
    The rates, regulations and charges to be collected for water sold to bulk water haulers shall be determined by resolution approved by the City Council. Such resolution shall be available for inspection at the City Clerk's office. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.310 - Excess water billing. 
    Water above the monthly minimum gallonage allowance as established by resolution shall be billed monthly when the meter reading has been completed. Such charges shall be set by resolution by the Florence City Council. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.320 - Responsibility for charges. 
    The owner of property served with City water shall be responsible for payment of charges for water services supplied by the City. However, payments may be accepted from tenants on such property. All unpaid accounts for water and all other service assessments shall constitute a lien against the subject property and in the event of nonpayment shall be certified to the Fremont County Treasurer for collection in like manner as are general property taxes. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.330 - Water tap charges and applications. 
A.  Charges for new water taps served by the City shall be determined by resolution approved by the City Council. A copy of said resolution shall be available for inspection at the City Clerk's office. In addition to such tap charges, the owner or person requesting such new service shall pay the actual cost of the installation, including the cost of the meter and all fittings and equipment necessary for installation and the cost of the labor required. Applications for all water taps must be on the forms provided at the office of the City Clerk by the owner of the property to be served or by his agent. 
B.  Water service outside the municipal limits shall require prior approval by the City Council. No water taps shall be authorized outside the City limits unless the applicant shall obtain and transfer to the City of Florence raw water rights which are acceptable to the City and can be utilized by the City of Florence in accordance with a schedule to be approved by resolution. A copy of such schedule shall be kept at the City Clerk's office. All Union Ditch water shares transferred to the City of Florence shall be accompanied by a signed and notarized "Dryup Covenant and Affidavit" by the owner of the water share(s) stating that the historically irrigated property shall not be irrigated in the future by Union Ditch water shares except through the use of water purchased from and delivered through the Municipality's municipal water system or pursuant to further water court proceedings. Water tap fees shall be established in accordance with the "Agreement on Water Fees" between the City of Florence and the towns of Coal Creek and Williamsburg dated November 9, 1982, and as the same may have been amended by agreement between the municipalities if said agreement is applicable. 
C.  The debt retirement fee for all regional water projects and the Florence water system shall be assessed for all taps issued, whether water service is being provided or not. Debt retirement is a fixed cost and is applicable to all taps. Monthly debt service fees for all water services shall begin and be payable at the beginning of the next normal billing cycle following the approval of the "Agreement for Water Service," whether or not the physical connection to the water system has been performed. 
(Ord. 4-99, 1999; Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
(Ord. No. 18-2009, § 1, 11-16-2009) 
13.04.340 - Schedules of attachment. 
    The City shall adopt by resolution schedules setting forth water tap fees and charges, travel and labor charges, deposits for physical connections, tap and meter sizes and location. 
(Ord. 20-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.350 - Nonpayment of charges-Turning off water. 
    For a violation of any rule, regulation or section of this chapter and for the nonpayment of charges, the City reserves the right to turn off the water thirty-six (36) hours after posting notice at the address where service is provided. After the water has been turned off from any service line to the user on account of nonpayment of water charges, the same shall not be turned on until the back charges are paid in full, together with the expense of turning off and on such water. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.360 - Delinquent payments-Billings to owners of premises. 
    When the unpaid water charges are two (2) months in arrears, the account shall be declared delinquent. The City Clerk shall notify the party designated to receive billings as provided in Section 13.04.300, with a final shutoff notice, and the City Manager shall order water service discontinued. The City Manager may extend the time for payment when evidence is presented of serious illness or hardship. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.370 - Due date of charges-Surcharge on delinquent accounts. 
    All utility charges assessed by the City of Florence are due and payable on or before the fifth working day prior to the last working day of the month in which the same are billed. If payment is not made on or before four-thirty (4:30) p.m. on the last working day of the month, then a ten (10) percent surcharge shall be added. Utility bills and other charges shall be mailed to, and paid by, the record owner of the premises served, who shall remain primarily responsible for said bills. However, payments therefor shall be accepted from tenants on such property. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the City of Florence from recovering costs of collection, including, but not limited to, disconnection or reconnection fees, reinstatement charges, or penalties assessed where fraud is involved. 
(Ord. 10-99 § 1, 1999: Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.380 - Notice to discontinue service-Owner requested. 
    Any owner may request that water service be discontinued to his premises. The water meter shall be read and the water turned off at the meter. Until service is restored at the owner's request, no monthly charge shall be imposed commencing the month following the discontinuance of such service except that debt retirement fees shall be assessed. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.390 - Abandoned water taps. 
    Any water tap agreement executed with the City of Florence for the purchase of a water tap from the City shall be deemed abandoned and declared null and void after the expiration of six (6) months following the date of agreement unless the tap has actually been made and installed. With respect to such water tap agreements dated before February 1985, such agreements shall be deemed null and void unless request was made, by the holder or owner thereof, to the City for installation of a tap within six (6) months after February 1985. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.400 - Tampering with meter. 
    No person shall tamper with a water meter or alter, change or attempt to alter, change or impede its reading, or in any way interfere with the natural flow of water through such meter. Any person who shall furnish water to another premises or who shall bypass the water meter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In such case, the City may immediately interrupt service. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.410 - Unauthorized connection fee. 
    An unauthorized connection fee equal to twice the normal tap fee due shall be payable by persons tapping onto the City's lines without prior payment of all required fees and approval of application. Service shall be immediately interrupted. Service shall not be restored until the owner is in compliance with all City ordinances, rules and regulations. Violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.420 - Revocation of service. 
A.  Service provided pursuant to any application may be discontinued for any of the following reasons: 
1.  Nonpayment of fees ten (10) days after a written notice has been sent advising the customer of the nonpayment; 
2.  Misrepresentation in the application as to property or fixtures contained in the property, or use to be made of the water supply system; 
3.  Use of water for any other property or purpose other than those described in the application; 
4.  Wilful waste through improper or defective pipes, fixtures, meters or for failure to maintain the connection service lines or fixtures in good order; 
5.  Wilful damage or alterations of any service pipes, meter, curbstop, or other facility or appliance controlling or regulating the water supply; 
6.  Violation of any of the City's rules and regulations. 
B.  If service is disconnected pursuant to this section, it shall not be reconnected until twenty-four (24) hours after resolution of the event leading to said discontinuance of service. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1(part), 1990). 
13.04.500 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to protect the City from contaminants or pollutants that could enter the distribution system by backflow from a customer's water supply system through the service connection. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.501 - Authority. 
A.  The authority to implement this program is contained in the state statute, legislation, regulations, and acts including but not limited to Article 1-114 and Article 1-114.1 of Title 25 of C.R.S. § 39 of 5 CCR 1002-11, Colorado Primary Drinking Water Regulations, and the Colorado Plumbing Code. 
B.  The City shall have the authority to survey all service connections within the distribution system to determine if the connection is a cross-connection. 
C.  The City shall have the authority to control all service connections within the distribution system if the connection is a cross-connection. 
D.  The City may control any service connections within the distribution system in lieu of a survey as long as the service connection is controlled with an air gap or reduced pressure zone backflow prevention assembly. 
E.  The City may collect fees for the administration of this program as set forth and adjusted from time to time by resolution of the City Council. 
F.  The City shall maintain records of cross-connection surveys and the installation, testing and repair of all backflow prevention assemblies installed for containment and containment by isolation purposes. Except as otherwise provided herein, the City shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.502 - Applicability. 
    The regulations contained in Section 13.04.500 et seq. apply to all commercial, industrial and multi-family residential service connections within the City and to any persons outside the City who are, by contract or agreement with the City, users of the City. This chapter does not apply to single-family-residential service connections unless the City becomes aware of a cross connection at the single family connection. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.503 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions will apply to this Chapter 4, Sections 500 et seq. 
    "Active date" means the first day that a backflow prevention assembly or backflow prevention method is used to control a cross-connection in each calendar year. 
    "Air gap" is a physical separation between the free flowing discharge end of a potable water supply pipeline and an open or non-pressure receiving vessel installed in accordance with standard AMSE A112.1.2. 
    "Backflow" means the undesirable reversal of flow of water or mixtures of water and other liquids, gases or other substances into the City's distribution system from any source or sources other than its intended source. 
    "Backflow contamination event" means backflow into a City from an uncontrolled cross connection such that the water quality no longer meets the Colorado Primary Drinking Water Regulations or presents an immediate health and/or safety risk to the public. 
    "Backflow prevention assembly" means any mechanical assembly installed at a water service line or at a plumbing fixture to prevent a backflow contamination event, provided that the mechanical assembly is appropriate for the identified contaminant at the cross-connection and is an in-line field-testable assembly. 
    "Certified cross-connection control technician" means a person who possesses a valid Backflow Prevention Assembly Tester certification from one (1) of the following approved organizations: American Society of Sanitary Engineering (ASSE) or the American Backflow Prevention Association (ABPA). If a certification has expired, the certification is invalid. 
    "Containment" means the installation of a backflow prevention assembly at any connection to the City that supplies an auxiliary water system, location, facility, or area such that backflow from a cross-connection into the City is prevented. 
    "Controlled" means having a properly installed, maintained, and tested or inspected backflow prevention assembly or that prevents backflow through a cross connection. 
    "Cross connection" means any connection that could allow any water, fluid, or gas such that the water quality could present an unacceptable health and/or safety risk to the public, to flow from any pipe, plumbing fixture, or a customer's water system into the City's distribution system or any other part of the public water system through backflow. 
    "Multi-family" means a single residential connection to the City's distribution system from which two (2) or more separate dwelling units are supplied water. 
    "Single-family" means: 
i.  A single dwelling which is occupied by a single family and is supplied by a separate service line; or 
ii.  A single dwelling comprised of multiple living units where each living unit is supplied by a separate service line. 
    "Uncontrolled" means not having a properly installed and maintained and tested or inspected backflow prevention assembly or backflow prevention method, or the backflow prevention assembly or backflow prevention method does not prevent backflow through a cross connection. 
    "Water supply system" means a water distribution system, piping, connection fittings, valves and appurtenances within a building, structure, or premises. Water supply systems are also referred to commonly as premise plumbing systems. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.504 - Requirements. 
A.  The City of Florence requires all commercial, industrial, and multi-family service connections to have a RPZ (reduced pressure zone) back-flow prevention assembly installed downstream of the meter or as close to that location as deemed practical by the City. This also applies to any single-family residences with a known cross-connection. The customer will have forty-five (45) days from time of notice to install the RPZ back-flow prevention assembly. If the RPZ cannot be installed within forty-five (45) days, the City will take action to remove or control the cross-connection, suspend service to the cross-connection, or receive an alternative compliance schedule from the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment. 
B.  In no case shall it be permissible to have connections or tees between the meter and the containment backflow prevention assembly (RPZ). 
C.  Backflow prevention assemblies and methods shall be installed in a location which provides access for maintenance, testing and repair. 
D.  Reduced pressure zone backflow preventers shall not be installed in manner subject to flooding unless deemed appropriate by the City. 
E.  Provisions shall be made to provide adequate drainage from the discharge of water from reduced pressure zone backflow prevention assemblies. Such discharge shall be conveyed in a matter which does not impact waters of the state. 
F.  All assemblies shall be protected to prevent freezing. Those assemblies used for seasonal services may be removed in lieu of being protected from freezing. The assemblies must be reinstalled and then tested by a certified cross-connection control technician upon reinstallation. 
G.  Where a backflow prevention assembly is installed on a water supply system using storage water heating equipment such that thermal expansion causes an increase in pressure, a device for controlling pressure shall be installed. 
H.  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested at the time of installation and on an annual schedule thereafter. Such tests must be conducted by a Certified Cross-Connection Control Technician. 
I.  The City shall require inspection, testing, maintenance and as needed repairs and replacement of all backflow prevention assemblies. 
J.  All costs for design, installation, maintenance, testing and as needed repair and replacement are to be borne by the customer. 
K.  No grandfather clauses exist except for pre-existing fire sprinkler systems where the installation of a backflow prevention assembly will compromise the integrity of the fire sprinkler system. 
L.  For new buildings, all building plans must be submitted to the City and approved prior to the issuance of water service. Building plans must show: 
1.  Water service type, size and location. 
2.  Meter size and location. 
3.  RPZ backflow prevention assembly size and location. 
4.  Fire sprinkler system(s) service line, size and type of backflow prevention assembly. 
a.  All fire sprinkling lines shall have a minimum protection of an approved double check valve assembly for containment of the system. 
b.  All glycol (ethylene or propylene), or antifreeze systems shall have an approved reduced pressure zone backflow preventer for containment. 
c.  Dry fire systems shall have an approved double check valve assembly installed upstream of the air pressure valve. 
d.  In cases where the installation of a backflow prevention assembly will compromise the integrity of the fire sprinkler system the City can chose to not require the backflow protection. The City will measure chlorine residual at a location representative of the service connection once a month and perform periodic bacteriological testing at the site. If the City suspects water quality issues, the City will evaluate the practicability of requiring that the fire sprinkler system be flushed periodically. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.505 - Inspection, testing and repair. 
A.  Backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested by a Certified Cross- Connection Control Technician upon installation and tested at least annually, thereafter. The tests shall be made at the expense of the customer. 
B.  As necessary, backflow prevention assemblies or methods shall be repaired and re-tested or replaced and tested at the expense of the customer whenever the assemblies are found to be defective. 
C.  Testing gauges shall be tested and calibrated for accuracy at least once annually. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.506 - Reporting and recordkeeping. 
A.  Copies of records of test reports, repairs and retests, or replacements shall be kept by the customer for a minimum of three (3) years. 
B.  All copies of records of test reports, repairs and retests shall be submitted to the City by mail, facsimile or e-mail by the testing company or testing technician or customer within thirty (30) days of occurrence. 
C.  Information on test reports shall include, but may not be limited to; 
1.  Assembly type; 
2.  Assembly location; 
3.  Assembly make, model and serial number; 
4.  Assembly size; 
5.  Test date; and 
6.  Test results including all results that would justify a pass or fail outcome; 
7.  Certified cross-connection control technician certification agency; 
8.  Technician's certification number; 
9.  Technician's certification expiration date; 
10.  Test kit manufacturer, model and serial number; 
11.  Test kit calibration date. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.507 - Right of entry. 
    A properly credentialed representative of the City shall have the right of entry to survey any and all buildings and premises for the presence of cross-connections for possible contamination risk to and for determining compliance with this chapter. This right of entry shall be a condition of water service in order to protect the health, safety and welfare of customers throughout the City's distribution system. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.508 - Compliance. 
A.  Customers shall cooperate with the installation, inspection, testing, maintenance, and as needed repair and replacement of backflow prevention assemblies with the survey process. For any identified uncontrolled cross-connections, the City shall complete one (1) of the following actions: 
1.  Control the cross-connection via RPZ backflow prevention assembly. 
2.  Remove the cross-connection. 
3.  Suspend service to the cross-connection. 
B.  The City shall give notice in writing to any owner whose plumbing system has been found to present a risk to the City's distribution system through an uncontrolled cross-connection. The notice and order shall state that the owner must install an RPZ backflow prevention assembly at each service connection to the owner's premises to contain the water service. The notice and order will give a date by which the owner must comply. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.509 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided in any and all applicable statutes, laws, and regulations including but not limited to, under the provisions of Chapter 1.12 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
13.04.510 - Conflict with other codes. 
    If a dispute or conflict arises between the Colorado Plumbing Code as adopted herein, and any plumbing, mechanical, building, electrical, fire or other code adopted by the State, then the most stringent provisions of each respective code shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 01-22-2019A, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
Chapter 13.08 - IRRIGATION[2] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
 For statutory provisions authorizing cities to regulate the distribution of water for irrigating and other purposes, see CRS 1973 § 31-15-708(1)(a) (1975 Supp.) 

13.08.010 - Use of irrigation water not a municipal function. 
    The City Council declares that the use of irrigation water within the City is an individual shareholder or ditch company function and not a municipal function; provided, however, the City Council shall have the right to control the flow of irrigation water within the City to the extent necessary to eliminate any conditions dangerous or damaging to the City or property therein. The individual shareholders and the ditch company shall be responsible for protection against damage to the City streets, sidewalks and alleys. 
(Ord. 13-78 Art. 2 § 1, 1978). 
13.08.020 - Obstructing ditch. 
    It is unlawful for any person to throw or discharge into any ditch or lateral within the City, any obnoxious substance, including refuse, waste, trash or garbage. 
(Ord. 13-78 Art. 2 § 2, 1978). 
13.08.030 - Interfering with ditch. 
    No person shall, without proper authority, interfere with or trespass upon any irrigation ditch, headgate, irrigation box, waterwheel or other thing relating thereto, located within the City of Florence, Colorado. 
(Ord. 32-78 § 1, 1979). 
13.08.040 - Placement of irrigation boxes. 
    No person shall place an irrigation box under any sidewalk, street or other public way within the City of Florence without first obtaining permission therefor from the City Manager. Upon application to the City Manager for such permission, the City Manager may, at his option, cause the work to be done by the City with the costs therefor, to be borne by the party making such application, 
(Ord. 32-78 § 2, 1979). 
Chapter 13.12 - DELINQUENT UTILITY BILLS 
Sections: 

13.12.010 - Due date of charges-Surcharge on delinquent accounts. 
    All utility charges assessed by the City of Florence are due and payable on or before the fifth working day prior to the last working day of the month in which the same are billed. If payment is not made on or before four-thirty (4:30) p.m. on the last working day of the month, then a ten (10) percent surcharge shall be added. Utility bills and other charges shall be mailed to, and paid by, the record owner of the premises served, who shall remain primarily responsible for such bills. However, payments therefor shall be accepted from tenants on such property. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the City of Florence from recovering costs of collection, including, but not limited to, disconnection or reconnection fees, reinstatement charges, or penalties assessed where fraud is involved. 
(Ord. 11-99 § 1, 1999: Ord. 12-80 § 1, 1980: Ord. 601 § 1, 1977). 
13.12.020 - Creation of property lien. 
    All unpaid accounts for utility and other service assessments shall constitute a lien against the subject property and shall be certified to the Fremont County Treasurer for collection in like manner as are general property taxes. 
(Ord. 601 § 2, 1977). 
Chapter 13.16 - WATER CONSERVANCY DISTRICT* 
Sections: 

13.16.010 - Consent to inclusion. 
    Consent is given to the inclusion of the City of Florence, Colorado, a municipal corporation, within the boundaries of the proposed Water Conservancy District by whatever name known and to taxation by such district. 
(Ord. 450 § 1, 1957). 
13.16.020 - Authorization to Mayor. 
    The Mayor and the City Manager are authorized and directed to sign and execute such documents as may be required therefor, and the same shall be attested by the City Clerk. 
(Ord. 450 § 2, 1957). 
Chapter 13.18 - DUTY OF FRANCHISEES TO REIMBURSE THE CITY FOR COSTS INCURRED BY THE CITY IN INVESTIGATING, NEGOTIATING AND APPROVING FRANCHISES, AMENDMENTS THERETO AND PROPOSED TRANSFERS OF FRANCHISES 
Sections: 

13.18.010 - Notice and application for franchise authority. 
A.
